The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): CIV E 444 . Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required: Copy of transcript.Principles of open channel flow. Analysis and problems of critical, uniform, gradually-varied, and rapidly-varied flows. Flow over weirs and spillways. Bridge, culvert and multiple openings hydraulics and modeling. Channel transitions. Design and environmental problems. Workshops on river analysis system (HEC-RAS 4.0). Maximum Credits: 3

CIV E 531.course_name: Pipe Flow and Water Distribution Systems
CIV E 531.course_description: CIV E 531 - Pipe Flow and Water Distribution Systems  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CIV E 444 . Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required: Copy of transcript.Principles of pressurized pipe flow. Estimation and management of water demand and water supply systems. Analysis of network distribution elements and network modeling. Design of distribution systems, their operation and maintenance, asset management, and financial appraisal. Maximum Credits: 3

CIV E 545.course_description: CIV E 545 - Field Methods in Hydrology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and two hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): CIV E 220  and CIV E 445  with a grade of C (2.0) or better. Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required: Copy of transcript.Equipment, field methods, and techniques used to study hydrologic systems and water resources, to include local streams and watersheds in California. Tools provided to design and implement field studies and interpret data. Maximum Credits: 3

CIV E 580.course_description: CIV E 580 - Traffic Engineering Design  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CIV E 481 . Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required: Copy of transcript.Sizing and configuration of highway facilities based on capacity analysis. Traffic signal design, impact and mitigation studies, parking, safety design. Maximum Credits: 3

CIV E 596.course_description: CIV E 596 - Advanced Civil Engineering Topics  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.Modern developments in civil engineering.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units for any combination of Civil Engineering 496, 499 and 596 applicable to a bachelor’s degree.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Credit for 596 and 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser.

CIV E 605.course_description: CIV E 605 - Prestressed Concrete Structures  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CIV E 421  with minimum grade of C.Fundamental concepts of prestressed concrete theory. Design applications to various types of structures. Maximum Credits: 3

CIV E 607.course_description: CIV E 607 - Dynamics of Structures  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CIV E 521  with minimum grade of C.Dynamic disturbances, structures with variable degelastic beams; continuous beams, rigid frames, floor systems. Energy methods in structural dynamics. Maximum Credits: 3

CIV E 608.course_description: CIV E 608 - Earthquake Engineering  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CIV E 607 .Elements of seismology. Methods of analysis for earthquake loads. Procedures and code provisions for the design of earthquake- resistant structures. Maximum Credits: 3

CIV E 610.course_description: CIV E 610 - Finite Element Analysis of Structures  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CIV E 321  with minimum grade of C.General procedure, various types of finite elements; analysis and design of isotropic and orthotropic plates and shells, deep beams, and shear walls using finite element technique; use of digital computers for solutions. Application to civil engineering structures. Maximum Credits: 3

CIV E 612.course_description: CIV E 612 - Advanced Concrete Materials  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): CIV E 421 .Microstructure and cracking behavior of concrete. Theory and application of high strength and fiber reinforced concrete. Concrete durability additives and fiber reinforced plastic reinforcement for concrete. Innovative applications of advanced concrete materials. Includes a laboratory project. Maximum Credits: 3

CIV E 620.course_description: CIV E 620 - Traffic Flow and Control  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CIV E 481  or C P 625 , with minimum grade of C.Advanced treatment of traffic flow and control issues. Highway capacity and traffic flow characteristics, traffic flow modeling, intersection control, freeway control systems, intelligent transportation systems. Maximum Credits: 3

CIV E 621.course_description: CIV E 621 - Transportation Demand Analysis  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CIV E 481  or C P 625 , with minimum grade of C.Travel demand modeling with emphasis on application to growing metropolitan areas; four-step travel demand forecasting; disaggregate, behavioral, and activity-based approaches; recent methodological developments; transportation-land use interactions. Maximum Credits: 3

CIV E 622.course_description: CIV E 622 - Mass Transit Engineering  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CIV E 481  or C P 625 , with minimum grade of C.Transit system characteristics, analysis of demand for transit services, transit system planning, scheduling, analysis and design. Maximum Credits: 3

CIV E 625.course_description: CIV E 625 - Intelligent Transportation Systems  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNO - Letter (No Cr/NC) Prerequisite(s): Recommended prerequisites are CIV E 481 and CIV E 160 (or any similar introductory stat course) or instructor approval.Intelligent transportation systems impacts on safety, mobility, and environment. Utilization of transportation technologies in advanced transportation management centers, connected and automated vehicles, crash prevention systems, and congestion pricing systems. Machine learning problem and its applications in intelligent transportation systems.

CIV E 631.course_description: CIV E 631 - Spatial Hydrology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CIV E 445  with a minimum grade of C or graduate standing.Integration of spatial data analysis and hydrologic modeling. Quantification of spatially distributed hydrologic characteristics. Decomposition of drainage network systems to support quasi-distributed hydrologic modeling. Quantification of hydrologic impacts due to model resolution, altered land use conditions, and modeling techniques. Maximum Credits: 3

CIV E 632.course_description: CIV E 632 - Computational Hydraulics and Hydrology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CIV E 445  and CIV E 530 .Computational methods applied to hydraulics and hydrology. Explicit and implicit schemes for solving hyperbolic problems. Method of characteristics. One- and two-dimensional nonsteady open channel flow simulation. Maximum Credits: 3

CIV E 633.course_description: CIV E 633 - Environmental Hydrology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CIV E 445  and ENV E 355 .Hydrosphere function, hydroclimatology, hydrographic characteristics, desertification, hydroecology, salinity modeling and management, stream and lake restoration, and case studies. Maximum Credits: 3

CIV E 634.course_description: CIV E 634 - Surface Water Hydrology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CIV E 445 .Hydrologic systems. Physical hydrology. Kinematic wave theory. Diffusion and dynamic wave theories. Watershed and stream channel routing. Hydrologic simulation. Maximum Credits: 3

CIV E 638.course_description: CIV E 638 - Sedimentation Engineering  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CIV E 444  with minimum grade of C.Hydraulics of sediment transport; erosion and sedimentation problems; river mechanics and morphology; mathematical modeling of river hydraulics; sediment transport and river channel changes. Design and environmental problems; erosion control and river training. Maximum Credits: 3

CIV E 639.course_description: CIV E 639 - Stormwater Management and Green Infrastructure  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CIV E 444  or equivalent.Stormwater management regulations, urban hydrology and hydraulics, stormwater quality and receiving-water impacts, design of drainage systems and Green Infrastructure, and state-of-the-art computer modeling of stormwater systems.  Maximum Credits: 3

CIV E 640.course_description: CIV E 640 - Advanced Soil Mechanics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CIV E 462  and CIV E 463  with minimum grades of C.Advanced theories of soil mechanics applied to geotechnical and environmental engineering. Classification of terrestrial and marine soils, compaction, consolidation, expansion, stress distribution, strength, permeability and seepage, site improvement, and remediation. Maximum Credits: 3

CIV E 641.course_description: CIV E 641 - Advanced Foundation Engineering  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CIV E 462  and CIV E 463  with minimum grades of C.Advanced theories of soil bearing capacity, settlement, and stress distribution applied to design of shallow and deep foundations and earth retaining structures. Subsurface exploration and dewatering methods. Maximum Credits: 3

CIV E 642.course_description: CIV E 642 - Groundwater Seepage and Earth Dams  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CIV E 462  and CIV E 463  with minimum grades of C.Groundwater seepage and contaminant transport in saturated and unsaturated soils. Flow nets for homogeneous and layered soils. Design and stability analysis of embankments and earth dams. Maximum Credits: 3

CIV E 644.course_description: CIV E 644 - Soil Dynamics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CIV E 462  and CIV E 463  with a minimum grade of C.Behavior of soil and soil-structure systems under dynamic loading. Applications include dynamic earth bearing capacity and pressure, soil spring constants for machine foundation design, liquefaction analysis, site response spectra, and seismic stability of slopes. Case histories discussed. Maximum Credits: 3

CIV E 696.course_description: CIV E 696 - Advanced Topics in Civil Engineering  Units: 2-3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Intensive study in specific areas of civil engineering.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 12Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Credit for 596 and 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser.

CIV E 697.course_name: Traffic Signal Systems Operations and Control
CIV E 697.course_description: CIV E 697 - Traffic Signal Systems Operations and Control  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.State-of-the-art traffic signal system control to include advanced traffic control strategies, incorporation of surface street systems into Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS), signal system design and operations, and traffic simulation techniques. Maximum Credits: 3

CIV E 730.course_description: CIV E 730 - Advanced Topics in Water Engineering  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CIV E 530  and consent of instructor.Advanced treatment of several fields in water engineering to include time series analysis, hydromodification, and online hydrologic modeling. Maximum Credits: 3

CIV E 781.course_description: CIV E 781 - Seminar in Transportation Engineering  Units: 2-3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Minimum grade point average of 3.0 and consent of instructor.An intensive study in transportation engineering. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.

CIV E 797.course_description: CIV E 797 - Independent Research  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of graduate adviser.Independent research in civil and environmental engineering. Maximum Credits: 3Maximum Credit Statement: three units applicable to a master’s degree.

CIV E 798.course_description: CIV E 798 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of staff; to be arranged with department chair and instructor. Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 3Maximum Credit Statement: three units applicable to a master’s degree.

CIV E 799A.course_description: CIV E 799A - Thesis or Project  Units: 3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): An officially appointed thesis committee and advancement to candidacy.Preparation of a project or thesis for the master’s degree. Maximum Credits: 3

CIV E 799B.course_description: CIV E 799B - Thesis or Project Extension  Units: 0 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Prior registration in Thesis or Project 799A with an assigned grade symbol of RP.Registration required in any semester or term following assignment of RP in Course 799A in which the student expects to use the facilities and resources of the university; also student must be registered in the course when the completed thesis or project is granted final approval. Maximum Credits: 0

CIV E 799C.course_description: CIV E 799C - Comprehensive Examination Extension  Units: 0 Grading Method: Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Completion or concurrent enrollment in degree program courses.Registration required of students whose only requirement is completion of the comprehensive examination for the master’s degree. Registration in 799C limited to two semesters.

CLASS 101G.course_description: CLASS 101G - Ancient Greek I  Units: 5 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Beginning classical Greek. Basic grammar, vocabulary. Maximum Credits: 5Note: Classics includes courses in Greek and Latin as well as non-language courses. Greek course numbers have a G suffix; Latin courses have an L suffix. No credit will be given for Classics 101G, CLASS 202G , CLASS 303G , CLASS 304G  taken out of sequence.

CLASS 101L.course_description: CLASS 101L - Latin I  Units: 5 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Beginning classical Latin. Basic grammar, vocabulary. Maximum Credits: 5Note: Classics includes courses in Greek and Latin as well as non-language courses. Greek course numbers have a G suffix; Latin courses have an L suffix. No credit will be given for Classics 101L, CLASS 202L , CLASS 303L , CLASS 304L  taken out of sequence. Not open to students with credit in Classics 250L.

COMP 526.course_description: COMP 526 - Computational Methods for Scientists  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): MATH 252  and MATH 254 .Translating mathematical problem descriptions to computer programs. Introduction to Unix system. Maximum Credits: 3

COMP 536.course_description: COMP 536 - Computational Modeling for Scientists  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): MATH 151 .Models, computational tools, errors, system dynamics, growth, stability, multicompartment models, Euler’s, Runge-Kutta methods, system dynamics, infectious disease, enzyme kinetics, environmental cycles, cardiovascular system, metabolism, global warming, empirical models, HIV, population distributions, diffusion, HPC. Maximum Credits: 3

COMP 596.course_description: COMP 596 - Advanced Topics in Computational Science  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.Selected topics in computational science.  May be repeated with the approval of the instructor. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units of 596 applicable to a bachelor’s degree.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree. Credit for 596 and 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser.

COMP 600.course_description: COMP 600 - Seminar  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.An intensive study in advanced computational science.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 6Note: Topic to be announced in the Class Schedule.

COMP 602.course_description: COMP 602 - Organizational Development  Units: 2  Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.Contemporary organizational and leadership theory and practice through personal reflection, team assessment and feedback, and case analysis. Nature of change, forces for change, and impact of change in organizations and individuals. Organizational processes, structures and cultures, and effect on organization’s performance.

COMP 605.course_description: COMP 605 - Scientific Computing  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: CS 605 . Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing and knowledge of the C programming language or FORTRAN or COMP 526 .Parallel programming using message passing to include high performance computing and MPI language extensions. Maximum Credits: 3

COMP 607.course_description: COMP 607 - Computational Database Fundamentals  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.Data-processing techniques, software, database design, implementation, and manipulation. Maximum Credits: 3

COMP 612.course_description: COMP 612 - Scientific Fundamentals and Ethics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: BIOMI 612 . Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.Oral and written research presentation skills development. Responsible conduct of research and ethics training. Authorship, collaboration, data management, peer review, and publication. Maximum Credits: 3

COMP 626.course_description: COMP 626 - Applied Mathematics for Computational Scientists  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): MATH 252  and MATH 254 .Linear algebra, differential equations and stability theory, and analytical methods for partial differential equations within the context of computational science. Maximum Credits: 3

COMP 670.course_description: COMP 670 - Seminar: Problems in Computational Science  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.Applications of computational science in solving problems using a variety of methods. Problems selected from biology, chemistry, physics, and other fields. Maximum Credits: 3

COMP 671.course_description: COMP 671 - Problem Solving Techniques  Units: 3  Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.Data abstraction and problem solving skills.

COMP 696.course_description: COMP 696 - Selected Topics in Computational Science  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.Intensive study in specific areas of computational science.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 12Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Credit for 596 and 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser.

COMP 705.course_description: COMP 705 - Advanced Parallel Computing  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Same As: CS 705 . Prerequisite(s): COMP 605  [or CS 605 ].Libraries, numerical methodology, optimization tools, visualization of results, MPI and GPU computing models. Applications conducted on CSRC student cluster and NSF XSEDE computing resources. Maximum Credits: 3

COMP 797.course_description: COMP 797 - Research  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Six units of graduate level computational science courses.Research in computational science. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.

COMP 798.course_description: COMP 798 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of staff; to be arranged with program director and instructor. Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.

COMP 799A.course_description: COMP 799A - Thesis or Project  Units: 3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): An officially appointed thesis committee and advancement to candidacy.Preparation of a project or thesis for the master’s degree. Maximum Credits: 3

COMP 799B.course_description: COMP 799B - Thesis or Project Extension  Units: 0 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Prior registration in Thesis or Project 799A with an assigned grade symbol of RP.Registration required in any semester or term following assignment of RP in Course 799A in which the student expects to use the facilities and resources of the university; also student must be registered in the course when the completed thesis or project is granted final approval. Maximum Credits: 0

COMP 799C.course_description: COMP 799C - Comprehensive Examination Extension  Units: 0 Grading Method: Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Completion or concurrent enrollment in degree program courses.Registration required of students whose only requirement is completion of the comprehensive examination for the master’s degree. Registration in 799C limited to two semesters.

COMP 800.course_description: COMP 800 - Seminar  Units: 3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to the doctoral program.Topics in different areas of computational science. Maximum Credits: 3

COMP 810.course_description: COMP 810 - Colloquium in Computational Science  Units: 1 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to the doctoral program.Discussions on advances in computational science research. Course to be taken every semester. Maximum Credits: 1

COMP 894.course_name: Supervised Research, Qualifying Examination, and Dissertation Proposal
COMP 894.course_description: COMP 894 - Supervised Research, Qualifying Examination, and Dissertation Proposal  Units: 3-9 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to the doctoral program and consent of instructor.Research and preparation for qualifying examination. Maximum Credits: 9

COMP 896.course_description: COMP 896 - Practicum  Units: 1-9 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to the doctoral program.Independent investigation in general area of field of dissertation. Conducted in industry or national laboratory under faculty supervision. Maximum Credits: 36

COMP 897.course_description: COMP 897 - Doctoral Research  Units: 1-9 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to the doctoral program.Independent investigation in general field of dissertation. Maximum Credits: 36

COMP 898.course_description: COMP 898 - Doctoral Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Advancement to candidacy. Individual study leading to study and research required for doctoral dissertation.  Maximum Credits: 3

COMP 899.course_description: COMP 899 - Doctoral Dissertation  Units: 1-15 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): An officially constituted dissertation committee and advancement to candidacy.Preparation of the dissertation for the doctoral degree. Enrollment is required during the term in which the student plans to graduate. Maximum Credits: 15

COMPE 160.course_description: COMPE 160 - Introduction to Computer Programming  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 150 .Computer organization and operation. Binary representation of information. Fundamentals of computer programming using a C family language: data types, selection and iteration structures, functions, arrays, pointers, scope and duration of variables. Systematic design and development of computer programs. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Prerequisites will be enforced in all undergraduate computer engineering and electrical engineering courses numbered 100 through 599. A copy of an official transcript will be accepted as proof. For corequisites, an enrollment confirmation form will be accepted.

COMPE 260.course_name: Data Structures and Object-Oriented Programming in C++
COMPE 260.course_description: COMPE 260 - Data Structures and Object-Oriented Programming in C++  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): COMPE 160  with a grade of C (2.0) or better. Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 245 .Data structures using object-oriented programming in C++. Disciplined approach to design, coding, and testing using OOP, teach use and implementation of data abstractions using data structures. Arrays, linked lists, stacks, queues, trees. Sorting, searching, recursive algorithms. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Prerequisites will be enforced in all undergraduate computer engineering and electrical engineering courses numbered 100 through 599. A copy of an official transcript will be accepted as proof. For corequisites, an enrollment confirmation form will be accepted.

COMPE 270.course_description: COMPE 270 - Digital Systems  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 151 .Modelling, analysis and design of digital systems, primarily at the Logic Design level. Combinational and sequential networks. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Prerequisites will be enforced in all undergraduate computer engineering and electrical engineering courses numbered 100 through 599. A copy of an official transcript will be accepted as proof. For corequisites, an enrollment confirmation form will be accepted.

COMPE 271.course_description: COMPE 271 - Computer Organization  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): COMPE 160  with a grade of C (2.0) or better. Grade of C- (1.7) or better in COMPE 270 .Organization and operation of computer hardware and software. Operating system shell and services. Program design and development. Input-output programming. Multi-module and mixed-language programming. Assembler and C language. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Prerequisites will be enforced in all undergraduate computer engineering and electrical engineering courses numbered 100 through 599. A copy of an official transcript will be accepted as proof. For corequisites, an enrollment confirmation form will be accepted.

COMPE 361.course_description: COMPE 361 - Advanced Programming  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): COMPE 260  and COMPE 271  with a grade of C- (1.7) or better in each course.Object Oriented Programming (OOP) using Python. Advanced programming concepts. Graphical User Interface (GUI) and event-driven programming. Scientific programming and data visualization. Note: Prerequisites will be enforced in all undergraduate computer engineering and electrical engineering courses numbered 100 through 599. A copy of an official transcript will be accepted as proof. For corequisites, an enrollment confirmation form will be accepted.

COMPE 375.course_description: COMPE 375 - Embedded Systems Programming  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): COMPE 271  with a grade of C- (1.7) or better.Embedded system architecture; IO programming using parallel ports, serial ports, timers, and D/A and A/D converters; interrupts and real-time programming; program development and debugging tools; C language and assembler. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Prerequisites will be enforced in all undergraduate computer engineering and electrical engineering courses numbered 100 through 599. A copy of an official transcript will be accepted as proof. For corequisites, an enrollment confirmation form will be accepted.

COMPE 470.course_description: COMPE 470 - Digital Circuits  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): COMPE 270  with a grade of C- (1.7) or better.Design of digital electronic systems using commercially available high-speed digital devices and circuits. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Prerequisites will be enforced in all undergraduate computer engineering and electrical engineering courses numbered 100 through 599. A copy of an official transcript will be accepted as proof. For corequisites, an enrollment confirmation form will be accepted.

COMPE 470L.course_description: COMPE 470L - Digital Logic Laboratory  Units: 1 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): COMPE 470  and E E 330L .Hands-on experience in characterization and application of standard digital integrated circuit devices. Maximum Credits: 1Note: Prerequisites will be enforced in all undergraduate computer engineering and electrical engineering courses numbered 100 through 599. A copy of an official transcript will be accepted as proof. For corequisites, an enrollment confirmation form will be accepted.

COMPE 475.course_description: COMPE 475 - Microprocessors  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): COMPE 375  with a grade of C- (1.7) or better. COMPE 470 .Fundamentals and practice of modern processor design, including branch prediction, context switching, data and control hazards, exception handling, instruction set architecture, microarchitecture design, memory hierarchy, multi-core processors, multi-threading, parallelism, performance measurements, pipeline processors, out-of-order execution. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Prerequisites will be enforced in all undergraduate computer engineering and electrical engineering courses numbered 100 through 599. A copy of an official transcript will be accepted as proof. For corequisites, an enrollment confirmation form will be accepted.

COMPE 491W.course_description: COMPE 491W - Senior Design Project A  Units: 2 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  One lecture and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): COMPE 361, COMPE 375, E E 330L. Credit or concurrent registration in COMPE 470.Develop project plans, work on a team, acquire project management skills, develop and evaluate the forms of communication engineers encounter in their profession. Develop critical reading and writing skills for engineering documents. The importance of professional ethics and ethical practice.Formerly numbered COMPE 491. Note: Not open to students with credit in COMPE 491 or COMPE 492.

COMPE 492W.course_description: COMPE 492W - Senior Design Project B  Units: 2 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  One lecture and three hours of activity.Prerequisite(s): COMPE 491W.Supervised team-based capstone design project to provide integrative design experience for seniors to demonstrate a working project. Develop critical reading and writing skills by exploring how content contributes to effectiveness in engineering documents.Formerly numbered COMPE 492. Note: Not open to students with credit in COMPE 491 or COMPE 492.

COMPE 496.course_description: COMPE 496 - Advanced Computer Engineering Topics  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.Modern developments in computer engineering. Maximum Credits: 9Maximum Credit Statement: nine units for any combination of Computer Engineering 496 and 596 applicable to a bachelor’s degree.Note: Prerequisites will be enforced in all undergraduate computer engineering and electrical engineering courses numbered 100 through 599. A copy of an official transcript will be accepted as proof. For corequisites, an enrollment confirmation form will be accepted. See Class Schedule for specific content.

COMPE 499.course_description: COMPE 499 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Approval of project adviser and department chair. Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6Note: Prerequisites will be enforced in all undergraduate computer engineering and electrical engineering courses numbered 100 through 599. A copy of an official transcript will be accepted as proof. For corequisites, an enrollment confirmation form will be accepted.

COMPE 560.course_description: COMPE 560 - Computer and Data Networks  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): COMPE 271  and E E 410  with a grade of C- (1.7) or better in each course.Wide area and local area networks, multi-layered protocols, telephone systems, modems, and network applications. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Prerequisites will be enforced in all undergraduate computer engineering and electrical engineering courses numbered 100 through 599. A copy of an official transcript will be accepted as proof. For corequisites, an enrollment confirmation form will be accepted.

COMPE 561.course_description: COMPE 561 - Windows Database and Web Programming  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): COMPE 361  with a grade of C- (1.7) or better.Programming applications involving file systems, relational databases, Structured Query Language (SQL), ADO.NET, client-server architecture, multithreading sockets, web servers, web browsers, web services, ASP.NET, Hypertext Markup Language (HTML), and Extensible Markup Language (XML). Maximum Credits: 3Note: Prerequisites will be enforced in all undergraduate computer engineering and electrical engineering courses numbered 100 through 599. A copy of an official transcript will be accepted as proof. For corequisites, an enrollment confirmation form will be accepted.

COMPE 565.course_description: COMPE 565 - Multimedia Communication Systems  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Credit or concurrent registration in COMPE 560 .Design and implementation of multimedia communication systems. Image compression, JPEG, VQ, cell-B standards. Video and audio compression standards, MPEG, MPEG-2, H.26X, G.72X. Data storage systems and multimedia requirements. Networking requirements and networks as multimedia carriers. Transport and network protocols for carrying multimedia over data networks. Multimedia system design, scheduling, congestion control, traffic shaping, buffer management. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Prerequisites will be enforced in all undergraduate computer engineering and electrical engineering courses numbered 100 through 599. A copy of an official transcript will be accepted as proof. For corequisites, an enrollment confirmation form will be accepted.

COMPE 570.course_description: COMPE 570 - VLSI System Design  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): COMPE 470  with a grade of C (2.0) or better.VLSI systems at the architectural level for digital signal processing applications: feedforward and feedback systems, fixed-point and floating-point representations, folding, iteration bound, parallel architectures, pipelining, retiming, unfolding, wave and asynchronous pipelining.Formerly numbered Electrical Engineering 672. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Prerequisites will be enforced in all undergraduate computer engineering and electrical engineering courses numbered 100 through 599. A copy of an official transcript will be accepted as proof. For corequisites, an enrollment confirmation form will be accepted.

COMPE 571.course_description: COMPE 571 - Embedded Operating Systems  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): COMPE 260  with a grade of C- (1.7) or better. COMPE 375 .Real-time kernel, basic kernel services, threading and synchronization, preemptive multithreading, mutexes, spin locks, critical sections, priority scheduling, interrupts, RTOS implementation, memory management, task management, intertask communications. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Prerequisites will be enforced in all undergraduate computer engineering and electrical engineering courses numbered 100 through 599. A copy of an official transcript will be accepted as proof. For corequisites, an enrollment confirmation form will be accepted.

COMPE 572.course_description: COMPE 572 - VLSI Circuit Design  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): COMPE 271  with a grade of C- (1.7) or better. E E 330 .Design of digital integrated circuits based on CMOS technology; characterization of field effect transistors, transistor level design and simulation of logic gates and subsystems; chip layout, design rules, introduction to processing; ALU architecture. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Prerequisites will be enforced in all undergraduate computer engineering and electrical engineering courses numbered 100 through 599. A copy of an official transcript will be accepted as proof. For corequisites, an enrollment confirmation form will be accepted.

COMPE 596.course_description: COMPE 596 - Advanced Computer Engineering Topics  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.Modern developments in computer engineering.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Maximum Credit Statement: nine units for any combination of Computer Engineering 496 and 596 applicable to a bachelor’s degree.Note: Prerequisites will be enforced in all undergraduate computer engineering and electrical engineering courses numbered 100 through 599. A copy of an official transcript will be accepted as proof. For corequisites, an enrollment confirmation form will be accepted. See Class Schedule for specific content. Credit for 596 and 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser.

CS 100.course_description: CS 100 - Computer Science Principles  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Satisfaction of the SDSU Mathematics/Quantitative Reasoning Assessment requirement.Capabilities and applications of computers. Algorithmic problem-solving methods and computer programming. Using computers to examine questions from other fields of study. Practical and theoretical limits to computation. Machine intelligence and heuristic problem solving. Social and legal impact of computers. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 150.course_description: CS 150 - Introductory Computer Programming  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Credit or concurrent registration in CS 150L .Computing methodology, process, and computational problem solving. Algorithm Design; program design, development, and testing. Not open to students with credit in CS 107 . Maximum Credits: 3

CS 150L.course_description:
CS 150L - Introductory Computer Programming Laboratory  Units: 1 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Three hours of laboratory. Prerequisite(s): Credit or concurrent registration in CS 150 .Programming experiences designed to demonstrate and reinforce concepts through active experimentation and programming exercises.
  Maximum Credits: 1

CS 160.course_description: CS 160 - Intermediate Computer Programming  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CS 150  and credit or concurrent registration in CS 160L .Advanced computing methodology, process, and computational problem solving. Programming environment and data structures. Object-oriented program design and development. Binary trees, linear lists, maps, queues, recursion, stacks. Not open to students with credit in CS 108 . Maximum Credits: 3

CS 160L.course_description:
CS 160L - Intermediate Computer Programming Laboratory  Units: 1 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s):  CS 150  and credit or concurrent registration in CS 160 .Programming experiences designed to demonstrate and reinforce concepts through active experimentation and programming exercises.
  Maximum Credits: 1

CS 200.course_name: Introduction to Data Science and Python
CS 200.course_description: CS 200 - Introduction to Data Science and Python  Units: 4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Basic data analysis with Python to include confidence intervals, regression, and sampling. Data structures, displaying data, and programming constructs. Maximum Credits: 9Note: Not open to Computer Science majors.

CS 210.course_description: CS 210 - Data Structures  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CS 160.  Representations and operations on basic data structures. Arrays, linked lists, stacks, queues, and recursion; binary search trees and balanced trees; hash tables, dynamic storage management; introduction to graphs. An object oriented programming language will be used.Formerly numbered CS 310. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 240.course_description: CS 240 - Computer Organization  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Credit or concurrent registration in CS 160 .Organization and assembly language to include CPU, logic circuits, and memory. Data representation, interrupts, looping and addressing techniques, macros, and traps. Not open to students with credit in CS 237 . Maximum Credits: 3

CS 250.course_description: CS 250 - Introduction to Software Systems  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CS 240 .Alternatives analyses, information management, networking and communications, parallel and distributed processing, principles and practices, security and encryption. Ethical, legal, and social issues in computing. Modeling will be used to capture and explore designs. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 296.course_description: CS 296 - Experimental Topics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected topics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

CS 299.course_description: CS 299 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6

CS 301.course_description: CS 301 - Computers and Society  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Completion of the General Education requirement in Foundations of Learning II.A., Natural Sciences and Quantitative Reasoning.Impact of computers and computing technology on society: applications, benefits, and risks. Topics include privacy, copyright, computer crime, constitutional issues, risks of computer failures, evaluating reliability of computer models, computers in the workplace, trade and communications in the global village. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Not open to computer science majors or to students with credit in CS 440 .

CS 320.course_description: CS 320 - Programming Languages  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CS 160  and CS 160L .Principles of high-level programming languages, including formal techniques for syntax specification and implementation issues. Languages studied should include at least C++, FORTRAN, and LISP. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 370.course_description: CS 370 - Computer Architecture  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CS 240 .Logic gates, combinational circuits, sequential circuits, memory and bus system, control unit, CPU, exception processing, traps and interrupts, input-output and communication, reduced instruction set computers, use of simulators for analysis and design of computer circuits, and traps/interrupts. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 420.course_description: CS 420 - Advanced Programming Languages  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CS 210 . Concurrent programming, logic programming, object-oriented programming. Implementation issues.Formerly numbered CS 520. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 440.course_name: Social, Legal, and Ethical Issues in Computing
CS 440.course_description: CS 440 - Social, Legal, and Ethical Issues in Computing  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CS 160  and CS 160L .Impact of computers, applications, and benefits, copyright, privacy, computer crime, constitutional issues, risks of computer failures, evaluating reliability of computer models, trade and communications in the global village, computers in the workplace, responsibilities of the computer professional. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Not open to students with credit in CS 301 .

CS 450.course_description:
CS 450 - Introduction to Artificial Intelligence  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CS 210 , MATH 254 , STAT 250 .First-order logic. Heuristic and uninformed search. Deep neural networks, hierarchical clustering, k-means, linear regression, support vector machines. Image classification and object tracking. Language models, parsing, speech generation.
 Formerly numbered CS 550. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 460.course_description: CS 460 - Algorithms  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CS 210  and MATH 245 .Algorithms for solving frequently occurring problems. Analysis techniques, divide and conquer algorithms with applications, graph problems, greedy algorithms. Introduction to NP complete problems.Formerly numbered CS 560. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 470.course_description: CS 470 - UNIX System Administration  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CS 370 .Installing the UNIX operating system on a UNIX workstation, adding user accounts, backing up and restoring user files, installing windows, adding network capabilities, adding printers and other peripherals. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 480.course_description: CS 480 - Operating Systems  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CS 210 , CS 370,  and instructor consent. File system, I/O management, interprocess communication, memory management, processes and threads, program structures, thread synchronization, virtual memory.Formerly numbered CS 570.

CS 490.course_description: CS 490 - Senior Seminar  Units: 1 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Two hours of activity. Prerequisite(s): Fifteen units of upper division computer science courses.Preparation and delivery of oral presentations on advanced topics in computer science. General principles of organization and style appropriate for presenting such material. Maximum Credits: 1

CS 496.course_description: CS 496 - Experimental Topics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected topics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

CS 497.course_description: CS 497 - Undergraduate Research Seminar  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Six hours of laboratory and one hour with adviser.Prerequisite(s): CS 460 , or CS 480 , minimum grade point average of 3.3, and consent of instructor.Designing and carrying out independent research in one of the areas of computer science. Literature search, technical report writing, and oral presentation of results. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 498.course_description: CS 498 - Undergraduate Honors Thesis  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CS 497  and consent of instructor.Directed research in computer science and completion of honors thesis. Thesis to be presented at the annual SDSU Research Symposium and/or defended before a committee of faculty. Maximum Credits: 6

CS 499.course_description: CS 499 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6

CS 503.course_description: CS 503 - Scientific Database Techniques  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNO - Letter (No Cr/NC) Prerequisite(s): CS 210  and MATH 245 .Fundamental data models for handling scientific data, including flat file, indexed compressed files, relational databases, and object oriented databases, and their associated query technologies; e.g. file formats, input/output libraries, string searching, structured query language, object-oriented structured query language, hypertext markup language/common gateway interface, and other specialized interfaces. Designed for computational science students. Note: Computer science majors and minors must obtain adviser approval. See CS 514 . Not open to students with credit in CS 514.

CS 514.course_description: CS 514 - Database Theory and Implementation  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CS 210  and MATH 245 .Database systems architecture. Storage structures and access techniques. Relational model, relational algebra and calculus, normalization of relations, hierarchical and network models. Current database systems. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 530.course_description: CS 530 - Systems Programming  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CS 210  and CS 240 .Design and implementation of system software. Relationship between software design and machine architecture. Assemblers, compilers, debuggers, editors, linkers and loaders, macro processors. Object oriented concepts and programming fundamentals. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Not acceptable for the M.S. degree in computer science.

CS 532.course_description: CS 532 - Software Engineering  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CS 250 .Theory and methodology of programming complex computer software. Analysis, design, and implementation of programs. Team projects required. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 537.course_description: CS 537 - Programming for GIS  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CS 210  or GEOG 484 .Customization of Geographic Information Science application development platforms with emphasis on object oriented programming and component architecture. Prominent examples are Map Objects with Visual Basic, Map Objects with Java. Considerable programming effort required, especially in Graphical User Interface development. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 540.course_description: CS 540 - Software Internationalization  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CS 210 .Principles, techniques, and resources for design and implementation of software localizable to multiple languages and/or cultures, including detailed examination of internationalization features provided by one or more widely used modern programming languages. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 545.course_description: CS 545 - Introduction to Web Application Development  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CS 210 .World Wide Web application development. Client-side and server-side scripting, CSS, Javascript, PHP and CGI programming with Perl, XHTML. Application integration with SQL database systems. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 546.course_description: CS 546 - Human Computer Interfaces  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CS 210  and CS 420 .Common interface idioms and support available for loose integration into aesthetically appealing and practical, efficient interaction between humans and machine. Editors, browsers, games, networking sites, posting boards, etc. Principles that are ubiquitous among tools for HCI development. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 547.course_name: Programming and Scripting Languages for Web Applications
CS 547.course_description: CS 547 - Programming and Scripting Languages for Web Applications  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CS 210  and CS 320 .Principles and practice of dynamic and scripting and functional languages used in web applications. Basic language concepts, data structures in dynamic languages, code structure, code quality, testing, string manipulation, dynamic code generation. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 549.course_description: CS 549 - Machine Learning  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CS 210  and MATH 254 .Algorithms and computer methods for machine learning. Supervised methods: convolutional neural networks, feedforward neural networks, linear regression, logistic regression, support vector machine; unsupervised methods: dimensionality reduction, k-means clustering, subspace learning. Applications in classification, regression and visualization. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 553.course_description: CS 553 - Neural Networks  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CS 210  and MATH 254 .Computer algorithms and methods for neural networks. Convolutional networks, feedforward networks, generative adversarial networks, graphical neural networks, recurrent neural networks; backward propagation, computational graph, regularization, stochastic gradient descent; autoencoder networks and deep structure models. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 556.course_description: CS 556 - Robotics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CS 450 , MATH 254 , and familiarity with Matlab programming language.Robotic systems and their components. Spatial descriptions and transformations. Kinematics and inverse kinematics of robots. Robotic programming and simulation environments to include Matlab Robotics Toolbox. Mobile robots. Trajectory tracking and control. Path planning. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 558.course_description: CS 558 - Computer Simulation  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CS 210  and STAT 550 .Methodology of simulation for discrete and continuous dynamic systems. State-of-the-art programming techniques and languages. Statistical aspects of simulation. Students will design, program, execute, and document a simulation of their choice. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 559.course_description: CS 559 - Computer Vision  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CS 210  and MATH 254 .Algorithms and computer methods for processing of images, edge detection and filtering in spatial domain, FFT and filtering, frequency domain analysis of images, image compression, low level image processing, neighborhood operations, segmentation. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 561.course_name: Deep Learning for Natural Language Processing
CS 561.course_description: CS 561 - Deep Learning for Natural Language Processing  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC - Letter (Cr/NC OK) Prerequisite(s): CS 450 .Approaches on deep neural networks. Common tasks, modern programming frameworks, and state-of-the-art models.

CS 562.course_description: CS 562 - Automata Theory  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): MATH 245 .Definition of finite automata. Classification of finite automaton definable languages. Minimization of finite automata. Nondeterministic finite automata. Sequential machines with output. Regular sets and expressions. Introduction to grammars. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 572.course_description: CS 572 - Microprocessor Architecture  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CS 370  and knowledge of the C programming language.Architecture of state-of-the-art microprocessor. Internal pipeline, internal cache, external cache, and memory management. Programming a uniprocessor. Communication among computers in a distributed environment. Architecture and programming of a multiprocessor system. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 574.course_description: CS 574 - Computer Security  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CS 480  and MATH 245 .Principles of computer security and application of principles to operating systems, database systems, and computer networks. Topics include encryption techniques, access controls, and information flow controls. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 576.course_description: CS 576 - Computer Networks and Distributed Systems  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Credit or concurrent registration in CS 480 .Basic networking concepts to include seven-layer reference model, transmission media, addressing, subnetting and supernetting, networking devices, LANs and WANs, internetworking, distributed processing, and client-server model. Basic concepts and protocols of TCP/IP protocol suite and basic Internet services. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 577.course_name: Principles and Techniques of Data Science
CS 577.course_description: CS 577 - Principles and Techniques of Data Science  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CS 210 , MATH 254 , and STAT 250 .Data classification, cleaning, common representation and operations, dimensionality reduction, hypothesis testing, life cycle, regression, statistical inference, and visualization. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 578.course_description: CS 578 - Wireless Networks  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CS 210 .Current and future protocols, fundamental theories, low power Internet of things and wireless sensor networks. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 581.course_description:
CS 581 - Computational Linguistics  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC - Letter (Cr/NC OK) Same As: LING 581 . Prerequisite(s): 
 CS 320  or CS 420  and LING 571  or LING 572  or BDA 572 .Basic concepts in computational linguistics including regular expressions, finite-state automata, finite-state transducers, weighted finite-state automata, and n-gram language models. Applications to phonology, orthography, morphology, syntax. Probabilistic models. Statistical techniques for speech recognition.

CS 582.course_description: CS 582 - Introduction to Speech Processing  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CS 210 .Fundamentals of speech processing and speech recognition. Physical aspects of speech production and perception. Mathematical models for speech recognition. Corpus development: data collection, processing, and evaluation. Applications of speech processing and associated research topics. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 583.course_description: CS 583 - 3D Game Programming  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CS 210 .Development of programming skills using software environment of a game engine and its scripting language. 3D concepts for game play, modeling, and programming. Roles needed in software development team. Contrast creation of original 3D object models for game world with incorporation of pre-created generic models. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 596.course_description: CS 596 - Advanced Topics in Computer Science  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.Selected topics in computer science.  May be repeated with the approval of the instructor. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units of 596 applicable to a bachelor’s degree.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree. Credit for 596 and 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser.

CS 600.course_name: Methods in Bioinformatics, Medical Informatics, and Cheminformatics
CS 600.course_description: CS 600 - Methods in Bioinformatics, Medical Informatics, and Cheminformatics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Same As: BIOMI 600 . Prerequisite(s): Three units of calculus and graduate standing.Computer, mathematical, and engineering techniques for bioinformatics, cheminformatics, and medical informatics. Techniques used in microarray data analysis, gene and protein sequence alignment, and classification techniques in medical decision making. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 601.course_description: CS 601 - Graduate Seminar  Units: 1 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to the M.S. degree program in Computer Science.Attend a minimum of seven technical talks organized by the departments of Computer Science, Electrical and Computer Science, and Mathematics and Statistics, and short report writing about each talk. The particular talks to attend must be approved by the course instructor.

CS 605.course_description: CS 605 - Scientific Computing  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: COMP 605 . Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing and knowledge of the C programming language or FORTRAN or COMP 526 .Parallel programming using message passing to include high performance computing and MPI language extensions. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 608.course_description: CS 608 - Programming Problems in Bioinformatics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: BIOMI 608 . Prerequisite(s): CS 210  with a grade of C (2.0) or better.Coding bioinformatics algorithms for biological data analysis. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 609.course_description: CS 609 - Computational Genomics and Bioinformatics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: BIOMI 609 . Prerequisite(s): CS 503  or CS 514  and classified graduate standing.Biological and genomic data. Application of computational algorithms to biological questions. Post-genomic techniques in annotation and comparison of microbial and eukaryotic genome sequences. Maximum Credits: 6

CLASS 120.course_name: English Words from Latin and Greek
CLASS 120.course_description: CLASS 120 - English Words from Latin and Greek  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Latin and Greek words and bases and their English derivatives. Etymology, word analysis and construction, language history, and structure. Maximum Credits: 3

CLASS 140.course_description: CLASS 140 - Introduction to Classics  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Survey of Greek and Roman art, literature, drama, sculpture, and institutions. Influence on our culture today. Contemporary relevance of epic heroes, tragic heroines, gods and goddesses. Impact of political thought. Maximum Credits: 3

CLASS 202G.course_description: CLASS 202G - Ancient Greek II  Units: 5 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CLASS 101G .Continuing classical Greek. Grammar, vocabulary, syntax. Preparation for CLASS 303G . Maximum Credits: 5Note: Classics includes courses in Greek and Latin as well as non-language courses. Greek course numbers have a G suffix; Latin courses have an L suffix. No credit will be given for CLASS 101G , 202G, CLASS 303G , CLASS 304G  taken out of sequence.

CLASS 202L.course_description: CLASS 202L - Latin II  Units: 5 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CLASS 101L .Continuing classical Latin. Grammar, vocabulary, syntax. Preparation for CLASS 303L . Maximum Credits: 5Note: Classics includes courses in Greek and Latin as well as non-language courses. Greek course numbers have a G suffix; Latin courses have an L suffix. No credit will be given for CLASS 101L , 202L, CLASS 303L , CLASS 304L  taken out of sequence. Not open to students with credit in Classics 250L.

CLASS 296C.course_description: CLASS 296C - Experimental Topics in Classics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected topics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.
