CS 790.course_description: CS 790 - Practicum in Teaching of Computer Science  Units: 1 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Award of graduate teaching associateship in computer science and classified graduate standing.Supervision in teaching computer science. Lecture writing, style of lecture presentation and alternatives, test and syllabus construction, and grading system. Not applicable to an advanced degree. Required for first semester GTA’s.

CS 792.course_description: CS 792 - Curricular Practical Training  Units: 1 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Approval of graduate adviser and SDSU International Student Center and classified graduate standing.Supervised work experience. Maximum Credits: 3Maximum Credit Statement: three units applicable to a master’s degree in computer science.

CS 797.course_description: CS 797 - Research  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Six units of graduate level computer science courses and classified graduate standing.Research in computer science. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.

CS 798.course_description: CS 798 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Classified graduate standing and consent of staff; to be arranged with department chair and instructor. Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.

CS 799A.course_description: CS 799A - Thesis or Project  Units: 3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): An officially appointed thesis committee and advancement to candidacy.Preparation of a project or thesis for the master’s degree. Maximum Credits: 3

CS 799B.course_description: CS 799B - Thesis or Project Extension  Units: 0 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Classified graduate standing and prior registration in Thesis or Project 799A with an assigned grade symbol of RP.Registration required in any semester or term following assignment of RP in Course 799A in which the student expects to use the facilities and resources of the university; also student must be registered in the course when the completed thesis or project is granted final approval. Maximum Credits: 0

CS 799C.course_description: CS 799C - Comprehensive Examination Extension  Units: 0 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Classified graduate standing and completion or concurrent enrollment in degree program courses.Registration required of students whose only requirement is completion of the comprehensive examination for the master’s degree. Registration in 799C limited to two semesters. Maximum Credits: 0

CON E 101.course_description: CON E 101 - Construction and Culture  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Cultural context of construction, emphasizing its centrality in evolution and expansion of built environments as expressions of ethical and historical value systems. Relationship between culture, geography, construction materials, and built expressions of cultural legacy. Interdependence of built environment and society. Maximum Credits: 3

CON E 102.course_description: CON E 102 - Fundamentals of Construction Management  Units: 1 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Construction industry and its projects. Functions of main actors and phases of construction projects. Tasks performed by construction managers and how they relate to and impact projects. Common processes and technologies in construction management field. Maximum Credits: 1

CON E 201.course_description: CON E 201 - Construction Concepts and Building Codes  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Concepts of control and information exchange in construction. Purpose and function of fundamental information flows, function, and development of construction-related codes and standards to protect public health and safety, compliance with requirements, and design using codes. Maximum Credits: 3

CON E 215.course_description: CON E 215 - Virtual Design and Construction  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and two hours of activity.Building information modeling (BIM). Connectivity to other aspects of the construction enterprise to include estimating, planning, and scheduling deployment. Constructability review. Maximum Credits: 3

CON E 240.course_description: CON E 240 - Introduction to Construction Materials  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): PHYS 180A . Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required: Copy of transcript.Properties of materials used for construction to include aggregate, ceramic, concrete asphalt, decorative and finish materials, soil, steel aluminum, and wood. Key material properties and material performance. Maximum Credits: 3

CON E 262.course_description: CON E 262 - Soil Mechanics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): MATH 150  and PHYS 180A  with a grade of C (2.0) or better in each course. Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required: Copy of transcript.Formation of soils. Classification of soils and their behavior. Compaction, consolidation, permeability, strength, and swelling. Maximum Credits: 3

CON E 280.course_description: CON E 280 - Construction Methods  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  One lecture and six hours of laboratory.Components and methods of construction including earthwork; foundations; wood, steel, and concrete construction; roofing and cladding; interior construction. Field experience in conducting and/or observing construction operations. Concepts of production in a construction setting. Maximum Credits: 3

CON E 296.course_description: CON E 296 - Experimental Topics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected topics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

CON E 301.course_description: CON E 301 - Construction Ethics, Law, and Contracts  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CON E 101 , CON E 201 , PHIL 101 . Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required: Copy of transcript.Legal and ethical environment of construction. Study of documents and common procedures in construction administration and their legal and ethical contexts for general contractors and subcontractors. Contract documentation, claim in various construction delivery methods. Maximum Credits: 3

CON E 312.course_name: Mechanical and Electrical Principles for Construction
CON E 312.course_description: CON E 312 - Mechanical and Electrical Principles for Construction  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): MATH 150 . For construction engineering majors: PHYS 196 . For construction management majors: PHYS 180B . Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required: Copy of transcript.Engineering principles for mechanical, electrical, plumbing systems. Thermodynamics, energy principles, psychometrics. Electrical theory, circuits, motors. Static and dynamic principles for fluids, pipe flow. Mechanical and plumbing equipment. Maximum Credits: 12

CON E 320.course_description: CON E 320 - Construction Estimating  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): CON E 280  and MATH 150 . Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required: Copy of transcript.Identifying and estimating time and cost requirements for construction operations based on drawings and specifications. Use computer applications for estimating. Maximum Credits: 3

CON E 330.course_description: CON E 330 - Principles of Engineering Economy  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): MATH 150 . Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required: Copy of transcript.Mathematics of finance applied to engineering and managerial decision making. Framework for cost management in engineering and construction.Formerly numbered Construction Engineering 430. Maximum Credits: 3

CON E 340.course_name: Analysis and Design of Construction Operations
CON E 340.course_description: CON E 340 - Analysis and Design of Construction Operations  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CON E 320  and CON E 330 . Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required: Copy of transcript.Properties and methods for use of construction equipment and integration into production system. Assessment of equipment needs and selection. Site utilization and layout planning, incorporating efficiency and safety of operations.Formerly numbered Construction Engineering 310. Maximum Credits: 3

CON E 350.course_description: CON E 350 - Construction Project Controls  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CON E 280 , CON E 330 , and ACCTG 201 . Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required: Copy of transcript.Characteristics of the construction industry and impacts on project controls. Associated costs in business and construction projects. Lease or buy decisions, pricing of change orders, progress payments, and schedules of values. Maximum Credits: 3

CON E 400.course_description: CON E 400 - Preconstruction Management  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CON E 350  and B A 350 . Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required: Copy of transcript.Addressing general conditions, organizing site logistics, and project start-up. Assembling teams and defining contractual scopes of work. Organizing the pursuit of projects. Phases related to building a proposal. Maximum Credits: 3

CON E 401.course_description: CON E 401 - Construction Planning and Scheduling  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): For construction engineering majors: CIV E 160  and credit or concurrent registration in CON E 320 . For civil engineering majors: CIV E 160  and CIV E 321 . For construction management majors: credit or concurrent registration in CON E 320  and STAT 119 . Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required: Copy of transcript.Fundamentals of scheduling logic including critical path method, deterministic and probabilistic scheduling, and impact of constraints. Development of construction plan and representation in schedule format using common computer applications used in industry. Maximum Credits: 3

CON E 479.course_description: CON E 479 - Construction Materials  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): CHEM 202  (or CHEM 200 ) and CIV E 301  (or M E 304 ). Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required: Copy of transcript.Selection, design and control of mixes of portland cement and asphalt concrete. Properties of these and other materials used in construction. Maximum Credits: 3

CON E 480.course_description: CON E 480 - Design of Temporary Structures  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CIV E 321  and CIV E 462 . Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required: Copy of transcript.Design of structures for temporary support of constructed work, including scaffolding and formwork, bracing, and excavations. Influence of codes and standards on the design process, selection of degrees of safety, and concepts of liability. Maximum Credits: 3

CON E 495.course_description: CON E 495 - Capstone Design Project  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  One lecture and six hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): Credit or concurrent registration in CON E 590  and for construction engineering majors: CON E 480 . For construction management majors: CON E 400 . Open to majors in construction engineering and construction management. Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required: Copy of transcript.Application of engineering principles, design and management techniques to construction projects. Maximum Credits: 3

CON E 499.course_description: CON E 499 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Individual study in the area of construction engineering. Maximum Credits: 3

CON E 520.course_description: CON E 520 - Environmentally Conscious Construction  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNO - Letter (No Cr/NC) Prerequisite(s): CON E 312  for construction engineering and construction management majors; CIV E 444  for civil engineering and environmental engineering majors. Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required: Copy of transcript.Design and design processes to target a sustainable structure. Construction practices associated with protection of environment. Application of industry standards for environmental and energy performance of buildings. Impacts on selection of methods, materials, and equipment for construction. Design of procurement and management systems to support environmentally conscious building. Commissioning and startup.Formerly numbered CON E 420 Note: Not open to students with credit in CON E 420.

CON E 590.course_description: CON E 590 - Construction Management and Safety  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CON E 330  and CON E 401 . Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required: Copy of transcript.Management and control of critical project processes for construction projects. Definition, planning, and execution of projects based on plan, estimate, and bid documentation. Fundamentals of construction safety planning, design, and requirements.Formerly numbered Construction Engineering 490. Maximum Credits: 3

CON E 650.course_description: CON E 650 - Construction Labor Productivity  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CON E 301  and CON E 401 . Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required: Copy of transcript. Graduate standing or instructor consent.Definition of productivity measures and factors that affect productivity of construction labor. Quantification techniques of labor productivity in construction. Note: Open only to graduate students and advanced undergraduates with instructor approval.

CON E 651.course_name: Project Production System Design in Construction
CON E 651.course_description: CON E 651 - Project Production System Design in Construction  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CON E 650  or Construction Engineering 310, CON E 401 , and 490. Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required: Copy of transcript.Theory of project production system design. Relation to production management theories, productivity improvement techniques, data gathering techniques to support process evaluation. Civil design and construction operations but also applicable to other industries. Maximum Credits: 3

CON E 652.course_description: CON E 652 - Construction Operations Modeling and Technology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Construction Engineering 310, CON E 401 , CON E 651 , and CIV E 220 . Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required: Copy of transcript.Modeling and optimizing construction projects and constructed works. Abstraction of projects, process mapping, and activity quantification. Theories of queuing and batching. Numerico-physical modeling of construction operations in time and space. Systems integration. Maximum Credits: 3

CON E 653.course_description: CON E 653 - Construction Scheduling  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CON E 301  and CON E 401 . Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required: Copy of transcript.Construction planning, scheduling and evaluation of planning techniques, labor, and equipment leveling, expecting cost and crashing, resource loading, what if scenarios, and use of scheduling in delay analysis. Maximum Credits: 3

CON E 654.course_description: CON E 654 - Construction Claims  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CON E 301 . Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required: Copy of transcript.Basic foundations construction claims process starting with an understanding of contractual basis for construction claims through final resolution of claims. Clauses that form the basis for claims; recognition of claims, communicating claims elements, pricing claims, and methods for resolving claims. Maximum Credits: 3

CON E 655.course_description: CON E 655 - Project Design and Portfolio Management  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CON E 651  or CIV E 495 ; and ENV E 320  or ENV E 355 . Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required: Copy of transcript.Techniques for project selection, definition, design management and value generation, including consideration of ROI, feasibility, and portfolio diversification. Incorporation of life-cycle considerations into all levels of design, including concepts of sustainability. Owner, designer, and contractor perspectives. Maximum Credits: 3

CSP 150.course_name: Adversity, Resilience, and the Science of Well-Being
CSP 150.course_description: CSP 150 - Adversity, Resilience, and the Science of Well-Being  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and one hour of discussion.Adversity, resilience, and well-being from physiological, psychological, and sociological perspectives. Personal reflection and skill acquisition to support development in different contexts and across life stages. Maximum Credits: 3

CSP 240.course_description:
CSP 240 - Career Development and Life Design  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Career decision-making and life planning to adapt to the changing world of work. Impact of social class identity on career development and life design. Goal to facilitate personal fulfillment, satisfying interpersonal relationships, and well-being.
  Maximum Credits: 3

CSP 300.course_description: CSP 300 - Stress Management and Life Planning  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Effects of stress on physical and psychological states and life choices. Stress management practices that contribute to optimal health and productive life planning. Maximum Credits: 3

CSP 320.course_description: CSP 320 - Counseling Skills and Practice  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Basic counseling skills with focus on how they affect and may be applied within cultural interactions and for social change. Maximum Credits: 3

CSP 400.course_description: CSP 400 - Counseling and the Helping Professions  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Serves as an introduction to the field of counseling and introduces the student to those professions considered to be helping professions. Maximum Credits: 3

CSP 401.course_description: CSP 401 - Quest for Identity  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Impact of interpersonal, social, and cultural variables on understandings of self, relationships, and the world. Social construction of multiple identities. Meaning and salience of fluid identity development. Maximum Credits: 3

CSP 420.course_name: The Influence of Media on Counseling and Wellbeing
CSP 420.course_description: CSP 420 - The Influence of Media on Counseling and Wellbeing  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC - Letter (Cr/NC OK) Impact of media on personal wellbeing. Meaning and salience of media and popular culture, social construction of media in society, and the convergence of media and counseling. Note: This course satisfies the general education cultural diversity requirement.

CSP 460.course_description: CSP 460 - Counseling and Social Change  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Role counselors and helping professionals play in addressing social justice issues pertaining to race and ethnicity, disability, gender and sexual orientation, socioeconomic disadvantage and research. Maximum Credits: 3

CSP 496.course_description: CSP 496 - Experimental Topics  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected topics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

CSP 499.course_description: CSP 499 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Open only to senior and graduate students in education who have shown ability to work independently. Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6

CSP 585.course_name: The Black Experience: Counseling and Contemporary Social Movements
CSP 585.course_description: CSP 585 - The Black Experience: Counseling and Contemporary Social Movements  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division or graduate standing.Major African-centered theories that guide evidence-based practices in mental health and how historical events and systems of structural inequalities impact global contemporary social movements. Maximum Credits: 3

CSP 596.course_description: CSP 596 - Selected Studies  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.A series of lecture and discussion sessions centering on current problems in counseling and guidance. Designed to serve the needs of any person desiring to keep informed of developments in this area.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Credit for 596 and 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser.

CSP 600.course_description: CSP 600 - Cross-Cultural Counseling Communication Skills  Units: 2 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Concurrent registration in CSP 600L .Concepts underlying effective cross-cultural counseling practice and interpersonal communication. Development of skills basic to practice of counseling, consultation, and marriage-family therapy. Maximum Credits: 2

CSP 600L.course_description: CSP 600L - Cross-Cultural Counseling Prepracticum  Units: 1 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Credit or concurrent registration in CSP 600 .Development of self-understanding. Cross-cultural communication skills needed for becoming an effective counselor.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 1Maximum Credit Statement: three units applicable to a master’s degree in counseling.

CSP 601.course_name: Theoretical Foundations of Counseling and Marriage and Family Therapy
CSP 601.course_description: CSP 601 - Theoretical Foundations of Counseling and Marriage and Family Therapy  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CSP 600  and CSP 600L .Counseling and marriage and family therapy theories and their impact on the practices of counselors, school counselors, school psychologists, marriage-family therapists and their clients. Approaches and applications for counseling and therapy. Research on counseling and marriage and family therapy. Maximum Credits: 3

CSP 602.course_name: Knowledge Justicia: Mental Health Care and The Decolonial Option
CSP 602.course_description: CSP 602 - Knowledge Justicia: Mental Health Care and The Decolonial Option  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Spanglish Decolonial Healing Advanced Certificate.Key concepts of the modernity/coloniality/decoloniality project from Abya Yala (Latin America) in relation to the hidden colonial foundations of the Western mental health care system, its evidence, regulations, institutions and actors. Note: Taught in Spanish and Spanglish.

CSP 603.course_name: Language Justicia, Spanglish and Mental Health
CSP 603.course_description: CSP 603 - Language Justicia, Spanglish and Mental Health  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Credit or concurrent registration in CSP 602.Spanglish as a linguistic borderland for decolonial healing praxis. Raciolinguistics examination of the colonial formation of Western therapeutic frameworks and interventions in standard English. Note: Taught in Spanish and Spanglish.

CSP 604.course_name: The Coloniality of Gender, The Colonial Difference and Mental Illnesses
CSP 604.course_description: CSP 604 - The Coloniality of Gender, The Colonial Difference and Mental Illnesses  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CSP 602.Decolonial analysis of mental illness and its treatment from the perspective of the colonial matrix of power. Gender, race, culture and mental illness as systems of oppression of the colonial difference. Note: Taught in Spanish and Spanglish.

CSP 605.course_name: Decolonizing the Temporality, Grammar and Aesthetics of Healing
CSP 605.course_description: CSP 605 - Decolonizing the Temporality, Grammar and Aesthetics of Healing  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CSP 602 and CSP 603; credit or concurrent enrollment in CSP 604.Epistemic decolonization of healing by delinking from the Eurocentric individual body, emotions, cognition, meaning making and behaviors. Decolonial aesthetics and grammar. Ancestral, human and non-human, and communal sentipensares to articulate and re-write healing responses to the colonial wound. Note: Taught in Spanish and Spanglish.

CSP 606A.course_name: Professional Issues in Mental Health Practice: California Law and Ethics for Marriage and Family Therapy
CSP 606A.course_description: CSP 606A - Professional Issues in Mental Health Practice: California Law and Ethics for Marriage and Family Therapy  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CSP 600  and CSP 600L .Legal, ethical, and professional issues in counseling and marriage and family therapy practice, research, and training. Cultural underpinnings and clinical implications of legal and ethical codes. Maximum Credits: 3

CSP 606B.course_name: Professional Issues in Mental Health Practice: Community-Based Block
CSP 606B.course_description: CSP 606B - Professional Issues in Mental Health Practice: Community-Based Block  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CSP 600  and CSP 600L .Legal, ethical, and professional issues in counseling and marriage and family therapy practice, research, and training. Cultural underpinnings and clinical implications of legal and ethical codes. Maximum Credits: 3

CSP 609.course_description: CSP 609 - Family Life Cycle Development  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CSP 600  and CSP 600L .Family development examined within sociocultural and temporal contexts. Addresses predictable and crisis transitions and implications for family therapy treatment. Maximum Credits: 3

CSP 610C.course_description: CSP 610C - Determinants of Human Behavior: Development  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Implications of theory and research in behavioral sciences for the understanding of human behavior. Maximum Credits: 3

CSP 612.course_description: CSP 612 - Restorative Practices and Conflict Transformation  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.Compare and contrast retributive and restorative practices. Concepts, history, principles, and theory of restorative practices. Restorative tools in building strong relationships. Utilization of trauma informed care. Maximum Credits: 3

CSP 615.course_name: Seminar in Multicultural Dimensions in Counseling
CSP 615.course_description: CSP 615 - Seminar in Multicultural Dimensions in Counseling  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Issues, insights, and techniques for improving effectiveness in working with culturally diverse populations. Maximum Credits: 3

CSP 618.course_name: Mental Health Recovery and the DSM: A Social Justice Perspective
CSP 618.course_description: CSP 618 - Mental Health Recovery and the DSM: A Social Justice Perspective  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CSP 601 .Descriptions of mental health disorders within biological, individual, familial, and larger social contexts. Focus on Diagnosis and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders classification system and relationship to family functioning. Maximum Credits: 3

CSP 619.course_name: Foundations in Ecosystemic Thinking and School Psychology
CSP 619.course_description: CSP 619 - Foundations in Ecosystemic Thinking and School Psychology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to school psychology program.Education and professional development of multiculturally competent, ecosystemic school psychologists involved in the lives of students, families, and schools. Maximum Credits: 3

CSP 620.course_name: Foundations of the Professional School Counselor Leader
CSP 620.course_description: CSP 620 - Foundations of the Professional School Counselor Leader  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to school counseling program.Comprehensive school counseling to include historical perspective of school counseling policies, practices, future leadership directions, role and function of professional school counselor leader. Current trends in school counseling. Maximum Credits: 3

CSP 621.course_name: Social Justice Democratic Theory, Processes, and Skills
CSP 621.course_description: CSP 621 - Social Justice Democratic Theory, Processes, and Skills  Units: 2 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Concurrent registration in CSP 621L .Multicultural community counseling and social justice practice, to include democratic processes, community-building, and professional communication skills. Social change through working with people in communities, increasing self- and other-awareness, and relationship building. Fulfills licensure requirements for LPCC. Maximum Credits: 2

CSP 621L.course_name: Social Justice Democratic Theory, Processes, and Skills Laboratory
CSP 621L.course_description: CSP 621L - Social Justice Democratic Theory, Processes, and Skills Laboratory  Units: 1 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Concurrent registration in CSP 621 .Supervised practice in multicultural community counseling and social justice practice, to include democratic processes, community- building, and professional communication skills. Social change through working with people in communities, increasing selfand other-awareness, and relationship building. Fulfills licensure requirements for LPCC. Maximum Credits: 1

CSP 623.course_description: CSP 623 - Ecobehavioral Assessment - Intervention  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Concurrent registration in CSP 730  or CSP 740 .Theory and concepts underlying ecobehavioral assessment - intervention in multicultural schools. Functional assessment of individual student behavior in contexts of classroom and culture. Development of behavior support plans in collaboration with teachers. Implementing and evaluating ecobehavioral consultation. Maximum Credits: 3

CSP 624.course_name: Learning, Achievement, and Instruction for School Counselors
CSP 624.course_description: CSP 624 - Learning, Achievement, and Instruction for School Counselors  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CSP 620 .Classroom management strategies and techniques. Curriculum design, lesson plan development, assessment tools, and instructional strategies for delivering school counseling core curriculum (academic, college/career, personal/social) in diverse schools. Maximum Credits: 3

CSP 625.course_name: Marriage and Family Therapy Theories and Best Practices I
CSP 625.course_description: CSP 625 - Marriage and Family Therapy Theories and Best Practices I  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CSP 601 .Historical and empirical foundations of marriage and family therapy. Classic systemic theoretical models of practice from vantage point of assessment. Related change strategies and techniques. Maximum Credits: 3

CSP 626.course_name: Marriage and Family Therapy Theories and Best Practices II
CSP 626.course_description: CSP 626 - Marriage and Family Therapy Theories and Best Practices II  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CSP 625 .Contemporary marriage and family therapy theories including: post-modern ideas, such as narrative therapy and collaborative language systems, integrative and evidence-based approaches; alternative approaches to family therapy, such as coaching and mediation. Maximum Credits: 3

CSP 630.course_name: Social Justice and Holistic School Systems for School Counselors
CSP 630.course_description: CSP 630 - Social Justice and Holistic School Systems for School Counselors  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CSP 620 .Historical and current holistic school systems and role of professional school counselor. Ecosystemic and social justice theory and models; practical implications for providing school counseling services for individual students in multicultural schools. Maximum Credits: 3

CSP 635.course_name: Sexuality and Intimacy in Couple and Family Therapy and Counseling
CSP 635.course_description: CSP 635 - Sexuality and Intimacy in Couple and Family Therapy and Counseling  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CSP 621  and CSP 621L  or CSP 625 , or consent of instructor.Approaches to understanding sexual functioning and intimacy through multicultural, historical, and relational clinical theory frameworks. Specific sexual issues presented in therapy, treatment planning, and intervention. Fulfills marriage and family therapy and LPCC licensure requirements. Maximum Credits: 3

CSP 636.course_description: CSP 636 - Mental Health Recovery  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.Constructions of pathology and mental health, mental health recovery movement, and multicultural considerations in counseling. Maximum Credits: 3

CSP 637.course_name: Counseling and Marriage and Family Therapy Theories I
CSP 637.course_description: CSP 637 - Counseling and Marriage and Family Therapy Theories I  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.Foundational counseling theories and practical application to multicultural communities. Historical development of marriage and family therapy theories from a social constructionist and postmodern framework. Maximum Credits: 3

CSP 638.course_name: Counseling and Marriage and Family Therapy Theories II
CSP 638.course_description: CSP 638 - Counseling and Marriage and Family Therapy Theories II  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.Continuing examination of counseling and marriage and family therapy theories and applications from social constructionist and postmodern frameworks. Maximum Credits: 3

CSP 639.course_name: Law and Ethics in the Counseling Profession
CSP 639.course_description: CSP 639 - Law and Ethics in the Counseling Profession  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.Legal and ethical standards in the counseling profession through a multicultural lens. Personal values in ethical decision making. Maximum Credits: 3

CSP 640.course_name: Testing and Assessment for Marriage and Family Therapists
CSP 640.course_description: CSP 640 - Testing and Assessment for Marriage and Family Therapists  Units: 2 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): ED 690 .Theory and application of individual and relationship assessment instruments in marriage and family therapy practice. Test development processes. Cultural factors in testing and interpretation. Current uses of tests in mental health, educational, and legal institutions. Maximum Credits: 2

CSP 642.course_name: Multicultural Assessment in Individual and Community Counseling
CSP 642.course_description: CSP 642 - Multicultural Assessment in Individual and Community Counseling  Units: 2 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): ED 690 .Theory and practice of individual assessment measures from a multicultural and social justice perspective in community counseling. Test development processes. Social justice and cultural factors in testing and interpretation. Current uses of tests in community settings. Fulfills licensure requirements for LPCC. Maximum Credits: 2

CSP 642L.course_name: Multicultural Assessment in Individual and Community Counseling Laboratory
CSP 642L.course_description: CSP 642L - Multicultural Assessment in Individual and Community Counseling Laboratory  Units: 1 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): ED 690 .Supervised practice and application of individual assessment measures from a multicultural and social justice perspective in community counseling. Test development processes. Social justice and cultural factors in testing and interpretation. Current uses of tests in community settings. Fulfills licensure requirements for LPCC. Maximum Credits: 1

CSP 645.course_name: College Planning and Career Development P-16
CSP 645.course_description: CSP 645 - College Planning and Career Development P-16  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CSP 620 .College planning, career readiness, and career technical education P-16. Technology promoting equity, access, and opportunity for culturally diverse populations to post secondary options. Maximum Credits: 3

CSP 650.course_name: Trauma and Crisis Counseling in Multicultural Community Context
CSP 650.course_description: CSP 650 - Trauma and Crisis Counseling in Multicultural Community Context  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): CSP 601 ; CSP 621  and CSP 621L  or CSP 625 , or consent of instructor.Multicultural and social justice; crisis and trauma counseling and therapy to include historical and philosophical origins of current theories and practices and implications for multidisciplinary treatment. Trauma and diversity. Maximum Credits: 3

CSP 652.course_description: CSP 652 - Trauma-Informed Care in Multicultural Contexts  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.Current trends in explaining traumatic experience. Discourses surrounding trauma and how they have developed. Recovery and restorative practices. Trauma-informed care practices and principles in diverse contexts. Maximum Credits: 3

ED 885.course_name: Seminar in Educational Program Planning and Evaluation
ED 885.course_description: ED 885 - Seminar in Educational Program Planning and Evaluation  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to educational leadership doctoral program.Effective monitoring of and evaluating systems for educational program improvement and policymaking. Maximum Credits: 3

ED 895.course_description: ED 895 - Seminar  Units: 1-8 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to the doctoral program or consent of the graduate coordinator.Investigation of a particular topic or issue, emphasis on empirical research in education. Maximum Credits: 8Maximum Credit Statement: eight units applicable to an advanced degree.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content.

ED 897.course_description: ED 897 - Doctoral Research  Units: 1-15 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to the doctoral program.Independent investigation in the general field of the dissertation. Maximum Credits: 15

ED 899.course_description: ED 899 - Doctoral Dissertation  Units: 1-15 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): An officially constituted dissertation committee and advancement to candidacy.Preparation of the dissertation for the doctoral program. Enrollment is required during the term in which the dissertation is approved. Maximum Credits: 15

ED 970.course_description: ED 970 - Teaching Event Assessment  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Admission to teacher education or dual language and English learner education multiple or single subject credential program and credit or concurrent registration in DLE 960 , TE 903 , or TE 961 .Tasks required for performance assessment teaching event: context of learning, planning instruction and assessment, instructing students and supporting learning, assessing student learning, and reflecting on teaching and learning.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 3Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Open only to students completing their final semester of student teaching.

ED 997.course_description: ED 997 - Special Topics in Education  Units: 0.5-6 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.Designed to meet the needs of teachers who wish to develop or continue the study of a current topic.  May be repeated with new content.

EDL 496.course_description: EDL 496 - Experimental Topics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected topics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

EDL 499.course_description: EDL 499 - Special Study  Units: 1-3  Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Open only to senior and graduate students in education who have shown ability to work independently. Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6

EDL 596.course_description: EDL 596 - Topics in Educational Leadership  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected problems in educational leadership.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units of 596 applicable to a bachelor’s degree.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree. Credit for 596 and 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser.

EDL 600.course_description: EDL 600 - Organizational and Systems Leadership  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to Preliminary Administrative Services Credential program and classified graduate standing.Educational administration and leadership as a profession. Related organizational concepts and management theories. Principles and competencies for leadership and administrative practice as each relates to the aspiring school administrator. Maximum Credits: 3

EDL 601.course_description: EDL 601 - Systems Leadership  Units: 6 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Four lectures and four hours of activity.Prerequisite(s): Admission to Preliminary Administrative Services Credential program and classified graduate standing.Systems and organizational structures that support school vision and goals. Regulatory and legal contexts involved with the management of fiscal, human, and material resources. Effective communication, enhancing capacity, and ethical decision-making in challenging conditions. Maximum Credits: 6

EDL 610.course_description: EDL 610 - Visionary Leadership  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to Preliminary Administrative Services Credential program and classified graduate standing.Concepts and techniques of leadership, analysis of factors and practice in procedures of individual and group leadership as applied to preK-12 educational environments. Maximum Credits: 3

EDL 615.course_description: EDL 615 - Leading Equity in Schools  Units: 6 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to M.A. degree.Supporting equity for students in preK-12 schools through leadership roles. Common biases and inequities that affect students based on ability, gender, national origin, race, religion, and sexual orientation. Systems design for reducing inequities for all learners. Maximum Credits: 6

EDL 616.course_name: Leading Teams to Use Evidence-Based Practices
EDL 616.course_description: EDL 616 - Leading Teams to Use Evidence-Based Practices  Units: 6 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to M.A. degree.Evaluation of sources of evidence, identification of best practices, and needs assessment. Accessing research to improve uses of evidence-based practices and implementation science. Maximum Credits: 6

EDL 617.course_description: EDL 617 - Mentoring, Coaching, and Collaboration  Units: 6 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to M.A. degree.Leadership and institutional improvement. Adult learning theory models and methods to improve collaboration between communities, families, and schools. Maximum Credits: 6

EDL 618.course_description: EDL 618 - Organizational Engagement  Units: 6 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to M.A. degree.Invitational education and implementation science. Designing professional learning opportunities and leading communities for improvement and increased engagement. Maximum Credits: 6

EDL 630.course_description: EDL 630 - School Improvement Leadership  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to Preliminary Administrative Services Credential program and classified graduate standing.Analyzing data to identify opportunities for school improvement. Appropriate and effective school improvement theories and strategies. Communication skills and leading others in improvement and monitoring of these efforts. Maximum Credits: 3

EDL 635.course_description: EDL 635 - Change Leadership  Units: 6 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Four lectures and four hours of activity.Prerequisite(s): Admission to Preliminary Administrative Services Credential program and classified graduate standing.Development and implementation of a shared vision of learning and growth. Involvement of community, parents, and staff in school visioning and improvement processes. Collection and analysis of data to identify strategies for school improvement. Maximum Credits: 6

EDL 640.course_description: EDL 640 - Community Leadership  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to M.A. degree or tier 1 credential program; EDL 600  and EDL 610 .Increasing family and community involvement in schools. Improving student achievement through using educational leadership strategies and resources. Maximum Credits: 3

EDL 650.course_description: EDL 650 - Professional Learning and Growth Leadership  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to Preliminary Administrative Services Credential program and classified graduate standing.Model professional growth development. Principles of adult learning; identify and facilitate appropriate professional growth opportunities for staff. Collaboration with others to achieve mission of improving teaching and learning. Maximum Credits: 3

EDL 651.course_description: EDL 651 - Instructional Supervision and Adult Learning  Units: 6 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Four lectures and four hours of activity.Prerequisite(s): Admission to Preliminary Administrative Services Credential program and classified graduate standing.Adult learning theory and professional growth development, assessment of quality instruction, collaborative practices to improve teaching and learning. Maximum Credits: 6

EDL 652.course_description: EDL 652 - Seminar in Instructional Leadership  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to Preliminary Administrative Services Credential program and classified graduate standing.Improvement of instruction through application of principles and practices in assessment of teaching competency; development of teaching profiles; leadership skills in working with teachers to improve performance. Maximum Credits: 3

EDL 655.course_name: Communication, Problem Solving, and Decision Making in PK12
EDL 655.course_description: EDL 655 - Communication, Problem Solving, and Decision Making in PK12  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to Preliminary Administrative Services Credential program and classified graduate standing.Educational leadership principles and practices for communication, problem solving, and decision making in preK-12 schools and educational organizations. Maximum Credits: 3

EDL 660.course_description: EDL 660 - Field Experience in Educational Leadership  Units: 1-6 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to Preliminary Administrative Services Credential program.Supervised field experience in schools or other educational settings. Monthly sessions with university faculty. Application to take this course must be made during preceding semester. Maximum Credits: 10Maximum Credit Statement: 10 units of which 4 units are applicable to a master’s degree.

EDL 680.course_description: EDL 680 - Seminar in PreK-12 Educational Administration  Units: 2-6 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.Educational administration in preK-12 schools and school districts. Field experience when appropriate.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content.

EDL 690.course_name: PK-12 Needs Assessment & Program Evaluation I
EDL 690.course_description: EDL 690 - PK-12 Needs Assessment & Program Evaluation I  Units: 2 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to Master of Arts in Educational Leadership or Master of Arts in Teacher Leadership program.Needs assessment and program evaluation to inform practice and amplify student impact. Students establish project focus and frame inquiry work for the EDL 690-691-692 sequence. Review extant data, understand opportunity and develop inquiry plan to guide data collection effort. Maximum Credits: 2

EDL 691.course_name: PK-12 Needs Assessment & Program Evaluation II
EDL 691.course_description: EDL 691 - PK-12 Needs Assessment & Program Evaluation II  Units: 2 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): EDL 690 .Implementation of PK-12 needs assessment or program evaluation inquiry plans developed in EDL 690 . Instrument design and development, followed by data collection. Iterative inquiry and continuous review of findings against guiding questions, adaptation of efforts to achieve inquiry objective. Maximum Credits: 2

EDL 692.course_name: Data for PK-12 Program Design, Appreciation, and Improvement
EDL 692.course_description: EDL 692 - Data for PK-12 Program Design, Appreciation, and Improvement  Units: 2 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): EDL 691 .Analysis and reporting of needs assessment and program evaluation findings. Examine qualitative and quantitative data as framed by inquiry plan. Author and present findings, including strengths, recommendations for improvement, and implications for leaders. Reflect on inquiry process for future application. Maximum Credits: 2

EDL 696.course_description: EDL 696 - Advanced Topics in Educational Leadership  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Intensive study in specific areas of educational leadership.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 12Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Credit for 596 and 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser.

EDL 707.course_description: EDL 707 - Educational Law and Finance  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Completion of a graduate degree and approval of department.Legal and financial aspects of educational administration including implications for policy formulation in the areas of personnel, instruction, and resource management. Maximum Credits: 3

EDL 720.course_name: Human Resource Development in PreK-12 Educational Organizations
EDL 720.course_description: EDL 720 - Human Resource Development in PreK-12 Educational Organizations  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Completion of a graduate degree and approval of department.Human resource management in preK-12 educational administration including selection and evaluation of staff, contract management, and staff development. Personnel managerial styles, staff leadership, and motivation techniques as to morale and productivity. Analysis of educational personnel systems and employee assistance programs. Maximum Credits: 3

EDL 755.course_name: Governance and Policy Development in PreK-12 Learning Organizations
EDL 755.course_description: EDL 755 - Governance and Policy Development in PreK-12 Learning Organizations  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Completion of a graduate degree and approval of department.Development of preK-12 educational policy and impact of politics in governance and administration; control functions of federal, state, and local agencies; influence of lay citizens and special interest groups; roles of judiciary, employee organizations and students. Maximum Credits: 3

EDL 760.course_description: EDL 760 - Practicum in PreK-12 Educational Organizations  Units: 2-6 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.Internship for preK-12 educational administrators. Application to take this course must be made in the preceding semester by preregistration with the credential program coordinator. Released time may be required.  May be repeated. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: 12 units applicable to the Professional Administrative Services Credential.

EDL 798.course_description: EDL 798 - Special Study  Units: 1-6 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of staff; to be arranged with department chair and instructor.May involve fieldwork. Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.

EDL 830.course_description: EDL 830 - Leadership for Learning  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to educational leadership doctoral program.Models of curriculum, instruction, and school organization. The leader’s role and responsibility in developing evidence-based decision making cultures that promote student achievement. Maximum Credits: 3

EDL 880.course_name: Seminar in Topics in Educational Leadership
EDL 880.course_description: EDL 880 - Seminar in Topics in Educational Leadership  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to educational leadership doctoral program.Topical issues in field of educational leadership that have broad implications for research and practice in educational leadership. Maximum Credits: 3Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to Ed.D. in educational leadership.

EDL 890.course_name: Foundations of PK-12 Research and Evaluation I
EDL 890.course_description: EDL 890 - Foundations of PK-12 Research and Evaluation I  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to Ed.D. Degree, PK-12 Concentration.Foundational knowledge in research and program evaluation. Introduction to qualitative and quantitative methods, including their application to empirical research and program evaluation. Application of skills professionally and to an original research or program evaluation to fulfill doctoral program requirements. Maximum Credits: 3

EDL 891.course_name: Foundations of PK-12 Research and Evaluation II
EDL 891.course_description: EDL 891 - Foundations of PK-12 Research and Evaluation II  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): EDL 890 .Advanced exploration of research and program evaluation. Qualitative, quantitative, and program evaluation including mixed methods design. Methodology planning, instrument design, data analysis planning. Application of skills professionally and to an original research or program evaluation to fulfill doctoral program requirements. Maximum Credits: 3

EDL 892.course_name: Application of PK-12 Research and Evaluation
EDL 892.course_description: EDL 892 - Application of PK-12 Research and Evaluation  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): EDL 891 .Continued exploration of research and program evaluation design. Qualitative, quantitative, and program evaluation including mixed methods design. Formulation of an initial research or program evaluation methodology to address a researchable problem or program evaluation.

EDL 899.course_description: EDL 899 - Doctoral Dissertation  Units: 1-15 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Advancement to candidacy and an officially constituted dissertation committee.Preparation of the dissertation for the doctoral degree. Enrollment is required during the term in which the dissertation is approved. No unit credit allowed toward advanced degree. Maximum Credits: 15

E E 200.course_description: E E 200 - Analytical Methods for Electrical Engineers  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): MATH 151  with a grade of C (2.0) or better.Complex analysis, Laplace transform with electrical engineering applications, linear algebra, multivariable calculus, ordinary differential equations, and power series. Maximum Credits: 3

E E 204.course_description: E E 204 - Principles of Electrical Engineering  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): MATH 151  and PHYS 196  with a grade of C (2.0) or better in each course.Circuit analysis, phasor diagrams, single-phase and three-phase power, semiconductor devices and applications, and energy conversion devices. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Prerequisites will be enforced in all undergraduate electrical engineering courses numbered 100 through 596. A copy of an official transcript will be accepted as proof. For corequisites, an enrollment confirmation form will be accepted. Not acceptable for electrical or computer engineering majors.

E E 210.course_description: E E 210 - Circuit Analysis I  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): MATH 151  and PHYS 196  and PHYS 196L  with a grade of C (2.0) or better in each course.Circuit analysis by reduction methods, Thevinin and Norton’s equivalence, mesh current and nodal voltage analysis. Transient analysis of first-order circuits and use of phasors for steady-state sinusoidal analysis. Operational amplifier models, impedance, power. Computer software tools for circuit analysis. Note: Prerequisites will be enforced in all undergraduate electrical engineering courses numbered 100 through 596. A copy of an official transcript will be accepted as proof. For corequisites, an enrollment confirmation form will be accepted.

E E 296.course_description: E E 296 - Experimental Topics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected topics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

E E 300.course_name: Computational and Statistical Methods for Electrical Engineers
E E 300.course_description: E E 300 - Computational and Statistical Methods for Electrical Engineers  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): E E 210  with a grade of C (2.0) or better.Random signals and events in electrical engineering. Introduction to basic probability, discrete and continuous random variables, joint random variables. Application of probabilistic models and concepts to engineering; data analysis and point estimation using computer-aided engineering tools. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Prerequisites will be enforced in all undergraduate electrical engineering courses numbered 100 through 596. A copy of an official transcript will be accepted as proof. For corequisites, an enrollment confirmation form will be accepted.

E E 310.course_description: E E 310 - Circuit Analysis II  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): E E 200  with a minimum grade of C- (1.7) and E E 210  with a grade of C (2.0) or better and either MATH 252  or MATH 254 .Transient and frequency response of RLC circuits. Mutual inductance, network analysis using Laplace transformations, network functions, stability, convolution integrals, Bode diagrams, two-port networks, computer analysis of circuits. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Prerequisites will be enforced in all undergraduate electrical engineering courses numbered 100 through 596. A copy of an official transcript will be accepted as proof. For corequisites, an enrollment confirmation form will be accepted.

E E 330.course_description: E E 330 - Fundamentals of Engineering Electronics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): E E 210  with a grade of C (2.0) or better.Application of diodes JFETs, MOSFETs, and BJTs in typical electronic circuits. Analysis and design of rectifiers, filters, and simple amplifiers using transistors and operational amplifiers. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Prerequisites will be enforced in all undergraduate electrical engineering courses numbered 100 through 596. A copy of an official transcript will be accepted as proof. For corequisites, an enrollment confirmation form will be accepted.

Maximum Credits: 1Note: Prerequisites will be enforced in all undergraduate electrical engineering courses numbered 100 through 596. A copy of an official transcript will be accepted as proof. For corequisites, an enrollment confirmation form will be accepted.

E E 340.course_description: E E 340 - Electric and Magnetic Fields  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. MATH 252  and E E 200  with a grade of C- (1.7) or better in each course.Electrostatic and magnetostatic field theory using vector notation; Coulomb’s Law, Gauss’ Law and potential theory. Solutions to Poisson’s and Laplace’s equations; capacitance and inductance. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Prerequisites will be enforced in all undergraduate electrical engineering courses numbered 100 through 596. A copy of an official transcript will be accepted as proof. For corequisites, an enrollment confirmation form will be accepted.
