FIN 696.course_description: FIN 696 - Seminar in Selected Topics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Intensive study in specific areas of finance.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 12Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Credit for 596 and 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser.

FIN 705.course_description: FIN 705 - Seminar in Estate Planning  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): B A 674 .The scope and nature of estate planning. Identification and analysis of the environmental factors and those aspects of federal and state law affecting estate planning and taxation. Estate taxation and social policy. Maximum Credits: 3

FIN 797.course_description: FIN 797 - Research  Units: 3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Advancement to candidacy.Research in the area of finance. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.

FIN 798.course_description: FIN 798 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of staff; to be arranged with department chair and instructor. Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.

FRENC 100A.course_description: FRENC 100A - Elementary French I  Units: 5 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Interactive introduction to speaking, reading, and writing French in a cultural context. Essential language structures for communication at the novice level. Maximum Credits: 5Note: Taught in French. Native speakers of French will not receive credit for taking lower division courses except with advance approval from the department. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division French course taught in French. No credit will be given for French 100A, FRENC 100B , FRENC 210 , FRENC 221  taken out of sequence.

FRENC 100B.course_description: FRENC 100B - Elementary French II  Units: 5 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): FRENC 100A  or two years of high school French.Continuation of FRENC 100A . Maximum Credits: 5Note: Taught in French. Native speakers of French will not receive credit for taking lower division courses except with advance approval from the department. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division French course taught in French. No credit will be given for FRENC 100A , FRENC 100B, FRENC 210 , FRENC 221  taken out of sequence. FRENC 201  may only be taken after completing FRENC 100B, but may be taken in any order with the other 200-level courses.

FRENC 201.course_description: FRENC 201 - Readings in French  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): FRENC 100B  or three years of high school French.Emphasis on reading. Maximum Credits: 3Note: See Class Schedule for emphasis offered: Readings in French Culture, Readings in Francophone Culture, or Readings in Business French. French majors, minors, and International Business majors are encouraged to enroll concurrently in FRENC 210 . Taught in French. Native speakers of French will not receive credit for taking lower division courses except with advance approval from the department. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division French course taught in French. FRENC 201 may only be taken after completing FRENC 100B , but may be taken in any order with the other 200-level courses.

FRENC 210.course_description: FRENC 210 - French Grammar  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): FRENC 100B  with a grade of C (2.0) or better or three years of high school French.Comprehensive survey of French grammar at the intermediate level. Analysis and use of typical French structures. Maximum Credits: 3Note: French majors, minors, and International Business majors are encouraged to enroll concurrently in FRENC 201 . Taught in French. Native speakers of French will not receive credit for taking lower division courses except with advance approval from the department. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division French course taught in French. No credit will be given for FRENC 100A , FRENC 100B , 210, FRENC 221  taken out of sequence.

FRENC 221.course_description: FRENC 221 - Speaking and Writing French  Units: 4 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): FRENC 210  with a grade of C (2.0) or better.Prose models, tone, and register; speaking practices, written composition and oral expression. Maximum Credits: 4Note: Taught in French. Native speakers of French will not receive credit for taking lower division courses except with advance approval from the department. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division French course taught in French. No credit will be given for FRENC 100A , FRENC 100B , FRENC 210 , 221 taken out of sequence.

FRENC 296.course_description: FRENC 296 - Experimental Topics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected topics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree. Taught in French. Native speakers of French will not receive credit for taking lower division courses except with advance approval from the department. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division French course taught in French.

FRENC 301.course_description: FRENC 301 - Advanced Grammar and Composition  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): FRENC 221  with a grade of C (2.0) or better.Advanced grammar and stylistics, intensive writing practice focused on a theme in French culture. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Not open to students with eight or more years of schooling in institutions where French was the sole or primary medium of instruction. French 301 and FRENC 302  may be taken concurrently. Taught in French. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division French course taught in French.

FRENC 302.course_description: FRENC 302 - Advanced Grammar and Translation  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): FRENC 221  with a grade of C (2.0) or better.Advanced grammar and comparative stylistics of French and English, taught through translation. Maximum Credits: 3Note: FRENC 301  and 302 may be taken concurrently. Taught in French. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division French course taught in French.

FRENC 304.course_description: FRENC 304 - Phonetics and Oral Proficiency  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and two hours of activity.Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing in French.Phonetic theory, listening, intonation and transcription practice, corrective phonetic and intonation exercises. Study of varieties of Francophone oral expression. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Taught in French. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division French course taught in French.

FRENC 305A.course_description: FRENC 305A - Survey of French Literature  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Ten units of 200-level French.Important movements, authors, and works in French literature from the Middle Ages to the Revolution. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Taught in French. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division French course taught in French.

FRENC 305B.course_description: FRENC 305B - Survey of French Literature  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Ten units of 200-level French.Important movements, authors, and works in French literature from the Revolution to present. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Taught in French. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division French course taught in French.

FRENC 400.course_description: FRENC 400 - Advanced French in Paris  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Ten units of 200-level French.Development of advanced level proficiency skills through writing and speaking. Offered only through the Paris Semester study abroad program. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Taught in French. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division French course taught in French.

FRENC 421.course_description: FRENC 421 - French Civilization  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Ten units of 200-level French.French civilization from Middle Ages to the present. Artistic, intellectual achievements and cultural movements. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Taught in French. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division French course taught in French.

FRENC 422.course_description: FRENC 422 - Contemporary France  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Ten units of 200-level French.Contemporary France, emphasizing political, economic and social structures as well as artistic, intellectual, and cultural trends. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Taught in French. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division French course taught in French.

FRENC 423.course_description: FRENC 423 - Commercial French  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): FRENC 301 . Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required: Copy of transcript.French commercial practices and language, the enterprise, correspondence, advertising, telecommunications, banking, transportation, import-export, insurance, accounting, stock market, preparation for the Certificate offered by the Paris Chamber of Commerce. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Taught in French. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division French course taught in French.

FRENC 424.course_description: FRENC 424 - French Cinema and Theory  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and two hours of activity.French cinema emphasizing social, political, and cultural changes in modern France. Topics include film theory, the new wave, history in cinema, influence of feminism, French colonialism, race, class, and gender in modern culture. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Taught in English. This course satisfies the general education cultural diversity requirement.

FRENC 465.course_description: FRENC 465 - Africa in Literature and Film  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: AFRAS 465   African cultural history through literature and film. Consistency/variety of African cultural expressions and conventions in literature and film. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Taught in English. This course satisfies the general education cultural diversity requirement.

FRENC 495.course_description: FRENC 495 - French Internship  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing in major and consent of instructor.Practical work experience in a field related to French and Francophone studies. Work done under joint direction of activity sponsor and instructor. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Approved international internships may count towards international requirement for major. Taught in French. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division French course taught in French.

FRENC 496.course_description: FRENC 496 - Topics in French Studies  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Topics in French literature, culture and linguistics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree. May be taught in English. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division French course taught in French.

FRENC 499.course_description: FRENC 499 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): FRENC 302 , FRENC 305A , FRENC 305B . Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6Note: This course is intended only for students who are currently enrolled in or who already have credit for all upper division courses in French available in any given semester. Taught in French. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division French course taught in French.

FRENC 501.course_description: FRENC 501 - Translation  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): FRENC 302 .Stylistic comparison of French and English through translation of a variety of prose styles from English to French and from French to English. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Taught in French. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division French course taught in French.

FRENC 520.course_description: FRENC 520 - French and Francophone Literary Studies  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): FRENC 302  and FRENC 305A  or FRENC 305B .Specialized study of a century, genre, movement or theme in French and Francophone literature.  May be repeated with new title and content. Maximum Credits: 6Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Taught in French. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division French course taught in French.

FRENC 530.course_description: FRENC 530 - French and Francophone Cultural Studies  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): FRENC 302  and FRENC 421  or FRENC 422 .Specialized study of artistic and intellectual trends, customs, and politics in French and Francophone culture.  May be repeated with new title and content. Maximum Credits: 6Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Taught in French. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division French course taught in French.

FRENC 596.course_description: FRENC 596 - Topics in French Studies  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): French 302.Topics in French literature, culture, and linguistics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Maximum Credit Statement: nine units of FRENC 596 Credit for 596 and 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviserNote: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree. Taught in French. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division French course taught in French.

FRENC 621.course_description: FRENC 621 - Critical Methods  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Eighteen upper division units in French.Methods and theories of critical analysis and their application to the works of a major French author or literary genre. Maximum Credits: 3

FRENC 631.course_name: Issues in French and Francophone Studies
FRENC 631.course_description: FRENC 631 - Issues in French and Francophone Studies  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.Study of a theme, theoretical or literary movement, or historical moment.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content.

FRENC 696.course_description: FRENC 696 - Topics in French Studies  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Eighteen upper division units in French.Intensive study in specific areas of French.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 12Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Credit for 596 and 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser.

FRENC 700.course_name: Seminar: A Major French or Francophone Author
FRENC 700.course_description: FRENC 700 - Seminar: A Major French or Francophone Author  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Eighteen upper division units in French.In-depth study of works of a major French or Francophone author. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content.

FRENC 710.course_description: FRENC 710 - Seminar in a Literary Genre  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Eighteen upper division units in French.Study of a specific literary genre, e.g. poetry, novel, theater. Maximum Credits: 3Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content.

FRENC 720.course_name: Seminar in French and Francophone Culture and Civilization
FRENC 720.course_description: FRENC 720 - Seminar in French and Francophone Culture and Civilization  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Eighteen upper division units in French.Study of a specific topic in French and Francophone culture and civilization. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content.

FRENC 798.course_description: FRENC 798 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Advancement to candidacy and approval of graduate adviser. Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 3Maximum Credit Statement: three units applicable to a master’s degree.

FRENC 799A.course_description: FRENC 799A - Thesis  Units: 3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): An officially appointed thesis committee and advancement to candidacy.Preparation of a project or thesis for the master’s degree. Maximum Credits: 3

FRENC 799B.course_description: FRENC 799B - Thesis Extension  Units: 0 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Prior registration in Thesis 799A with an assigned grade symbol of RP.Registration required in any semester or term following assignment of RP in Course 799A in which the student expects to use the facilities and resources of the university; also student must be registered in the course when the completed thesis is granted final approval. Maximum Credits: 0

FRENC 799C.course_description: FRENC 799C - Comprehensive Examination Extension  Units: 0 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Completion or concurrent enrollment in degree program courses.Registration required of students whose only requirement is completion of the comprehensive examination for the master’s degree. Registration in 799C limited to two semesters. Maximum Credits: 0

ED 203.course_description: ED 203 - Foundations of Cultural Competency  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Cultural self-awareness, ethnocentrism, individual biases, institutional oppression, microaggressions, race relations. Historical background of racism. Impacts on current majority-minority relationships.Formerly numbered GEN S 203. Maximum Credits: 3

GEN S 100A.course_description: GEN S 100A - University Seminar  Units: 1 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Open only to freshmen.Provides opportunities to interact with faculty and staff in a small group setting. Students acquire study and interpersonal skills for academic and personal success. Special sessions are offered featuring campus resources including library, advising, career, health and wellness services. Maximum Credits: 1

GEN S 100B.course_description: GEN S 100B - University Seminar: Learning in Communities  Units: 1 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Open only to freshmen.Provides opportunities to interact with faculty and staff in a small group setting. Students acquire study and interpersonal skills for academic and personal success. Special sessions are offered featuring campus resources including library, advising, career, health and wellness services. Maximum Credits: 1

GEN S 100C.course_description: GEN S 100C - University Seminar: Living/Learning Community  Units: 1 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Open only to freshmen.Provides opportunities to interact with faculty and staff in a small group setting. Students acquire study and interpersonal skills for academic and personal success. Special sessions are offered featuring campus resources including library, advising, career, health and wellness services. Maximum Credits: 1

GEN S 147.course_name: Data Literacy: Human Choices Behind the Numbers
GEN S 147.course_description: GEN S 147 - Data Literacy: Human Choices Behind the Numbers  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC How social scientists use data, presentation of empirical analysis, and role of assumptions and choices in analyses. Maximum Credits: 3

GEN S 150.course_name: Building Your Future Self for Success in College and Beyond
GEN S 150.course_description: GEN S 150 - Building Your Future Self for Success in College and Beyond  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC First-year students will meet one another where they are, build community, and explore how the latest interdisciplinary research, strategies, and tools can help cultivate success in academic and life pursuits as they develop and realize their future selves. Maximum Credits: 3

GEN S 170.course_description: GEN S 170 - Introduction to Interdisciplinarity  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC - Letter (Cr/NC OK) Examination of the history of interdisciplinary studies as an academic field. Exploration of elements of academic disciplines and their importance to the interdisciplinary process. Introduction to different models of integration, interdisciplinary research and problem solving. Synthesis of diverse perspectives.

GEN S 200.course_description: GEN S 200 - Professional Experience and Community Service  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Twelve units of college credit, minimum grade point average of 2.0, concurrent participation in professional or community service activity, and approval of course contract.Academic work designed with faculty approval to complement concurrent paid or unpaid professional or community service experience. Maximum Credits: 6Note: Information and course contract forms available in Division of Academic Engagement and Student Achievement, AD-220. Applications must be submitted to the division prior to the end of the first week of classes. May be used to satisfy major or minor requirements only upon written approval of department chair. No combination of General Studies 200 and GEN S 400  in excess of six units may be counted for credit toward a bachelor’s degree.

GEN S 250.course_description: GEN S 250 - Interdisciplinary Topics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Interdisciplinary selected topics course. To enroll contact the faculty adviser of the department offering the course.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 4

GEN S 255.course_description: GEN S 255 - Bounce Back Retention Seminar  Units: 1 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Academic probation students only. All participants sign Institutional Review Board (IRB) consent form.In a highly interactive, small group setting, students learn a variety of skills, such as time management, test taking, class preparedness, and study skills, in order to strengthen performance. Students learn what personal attributes contribute to academic success and learn how to recognize and expand on these characteristics. Maximum Credits: 1

GEN S 260.course_name: Introduction to Peace and Social Justice
GEN S 260.course_description: GEN S 260 - Introduction to Peace and Social Justice  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Personal peace and nonviolent strategies for individual and collective social justice actions. Local, national, and global engagement to include economic, environmental, housing, political, and racial justice. International learning, volunteering, and Peace Corps service. Maximum Credits: 3

GEN S 280.course_description: GEN S 280 - Introduction to Civic Engagement  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Minimum grade point average of 2.0.Civic engagement through service learning. Collective action and global citizenship. Civic dimensions supporting democratic engagement. Civic capacities and literacies for social responsibility. One to two hours of weekly community service required. Maximum Credits: 3

GEOL 100.course_description: GEOL 100 - Planet Earth  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Earth’s global systems. Plate tectonics, earthquakes, and volcanoes; evolution of our planet and life through geologic time; economic resources including fossil fuels and precious minerals; agents of erosion that shape the land. Maximum Credits: 3

GEOL 101.course_description: GEOL 101 - Dynamics of the Earth Laboratory  Units: 1 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): Credit or concurrent registration in GEOL 100 , GEOL 104 , or ENV S 100  [or SUSTN 100 ].Hands-on experience with land forms, rocks, minerals, topographic maps, and aerial photographs. Includes demonstrations and field trips. Designed to accompany and augment GEOL 100  or GEOL 104 . Maximum Credits: 1

GEOL 104.course_description: GEOL 104 - Earth Science  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Earth’s four principal reservoirs and their interconnectedness: solid earth, ocean, atmosphere, and biosphere. How humanity affects and is affected by these reservoirs. Most appropriate for liberal studies majors. Maximum Credits: 3

GEOL 200.course_description: GEOL 200 - Geologic Inquiry and Problem Solving  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): OCEAN 100 ; or GEOL 100  and GEOL 101 ; or GEOL 101  and either GEOL 104  or ENV S 100  [or SUSTN 100 ].Guided inquiry field and laboratory approach to solution of geologic problems. Written reports and oral presentations. Required weekend field trips. Maximum Credits: 3

GEOL 205.course_description: GEOL 205 - Historical Geology  Units: 4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Three lectures and three hours of laboratory. Arrangement for field study during the semester.Prerequisite(s): OCEAN 100 ; or GEOL 100  and GEOL 101 ; or GEOL 101  and GEOL 104 .Evolutionary history of earth as traced through rock and fossil records. Stratigraphic and depositional concepts. Maximum Credits: 4

GEOL 221.course_description: GEOL 221 - Mineralogy  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): OCEAN 100 ; or GEOL 100  and GEOL 101 ; or GEOL 101  and either GEOL 104  or ENV S 100  [or SUSTN 100 ]. Credit or concurrent registration in CHEM 200 . Recommended: GEOL 200 .Practice in determination of common minerals; their geologic environment, utilization, and economic significance. Introduction to optical techniques in mineral identification. Maximum Credits: 3

GEOL 296.course_description: GEOL 296 - Experimental Topics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected topics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

GEOL 300.course_description: GEOL 300 - Geological Data Analysis  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 150 .Theory and techniques of geological data analysis. Elementary programming to model statistical processes. Statistical inference, error propagation, plotting, and curve fitting using geological examples. Maximum Credits: 3

GEOL 301.course_name: Geology of National Parks and Monuments
GEOL 301.course_description: GEOL 301 - Geology of National Parks and Monuments  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Completion of the General Education requirement in Foundations of Learning II.A., Natural Sciences and Quantitative Reasoning. Recommended: GEOL 100 .Geology of a group of national parks and monuments, selected for their geological significance, scenic beauty, and visitor popularity. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Not acceptable to the B.S. degree in geological sciences.

GEOL 303.course_description: GEOL 303 - Natural Disasters  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Completion of the General Education requirement in Foundations of Learning II.A., Natural Sciences and Quantitative Reasoning. Recommended: GEOL 100 .Geologic processes that have dramatically affected the human race: earthquakes, volcanoes, landslides, and floods. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Not acceptable to the B.S. degree in geological sciences, except for the emphasis in environmental geosciences.

GEOL 305.course_description: GEOL 305 - Water and the Environment  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Completion of the General Education requirement in Foundations of Learning II.A., Natural Sciences and Quantitative Reasoning. Recommended: GEOL 100  or GEOG 101 .Movement of fresh water on earth. Hydrologic cycling of water from precipitation, runoff, infiltration, stream and groundwater flow to the ocean. Problems caused by over-use of water resources, urbanization, and water pollution examined with case studies. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Not acceptable to the B.S. degree in geological sciences, except for the emphasis in environmental geosciences.

GEOL 306.course_description: GEOL 306 - Structural Geology  Units: 4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and six hours of laboratory with limited field trips. Prerequisite(s): GEOL 324 ; algebra, trigonometry, and at least high school physics. Highly recommended: First semester college physics.Integrates structural and introductory field geology. Principles, causes, and mechanisms of rock deformation combined with field study. Graphical, computer, and analytical techniques for working with folds and faults are applied in the field. Field observations are presented in geologic maps, cross sections, and reports.

GEOL 307.course_description: GEOL 307 - Geophysics and Field Methods  Units: 4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory and a minimum of three weekends in field during semester.Prerequisite(s): GEOL 306 ; MATH 124  or MATH 150 ; PHYS 180A  or PHYS 195 .Principles and field studies of gravity, magnetic, and seismic techniques applied to structure, dynamics, and shallow environment of the earth. Computer-aided data reduction and interpretation. Maximum Credits: 4

GEOL 324.course_description: GEOL 324 - Petrology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): GEOL 221 .Composition, classification, occurrence, and origin of igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic rocks. Identification of rocks in hand specimen; petrographic analysis of rocks in thin section; modeling and interpretation of petrologic data. Maximum Credits: 3

GEOL 336.course_description: GEOL 336 - Sedimentology and Lithostratigraphy  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): GEOL 200  (not required but recommended for emphases in engineering geology and hydrogeology) and GEOL 205  (not required but recommended for emphases in environmental geosciences and geophysics).Sedimentologic description and interpretation of the textures and structures of sediments and sedimentary rocks. Stratigraphic analysis of stratal succession, age relationships, and correlation on local and global scales. Maximum Credits: 3

GEOL 412.course_name: Processes and Inquiry in the Earth Sciences
GEOL 412.course_description: GEOL 412 - Processes and Inquiry in the Earth Sciences  Units: 4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Three lectures and two hours of activity.Prerequisite(s): Completion of the General Education requirement in Foundations of Learning II.A., Natural Sciences and Quantitative Reasoning.Investigation of processes of inquiry and rational thinking skills characteristic of the earth sciences. Maximum Credits: 4

GEOL 496.course_description: GEOL 496 - Selected Topics in Geology  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.Selected topics in geology and related earth sciences.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 6Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

GEOL 498A.course_description: GEOL 498A - Research Methods and Communication  Units: 1 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Nine upper division units in geological sciences. Cumulative 3.0 GPA and consent of instructor. Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required:  Copy of transcript.Development and testing of scientific hypotheses and their effective communication through oral, written, and visual modes. To be taken prior to registration in GEOL 498B . Maximum Credits: 1

GEOL 498B.course_description: GEOL 498B - Senior Thesis  Units: 2 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.Individual research project, written thesis, and oral presentation done under supervision of professor chosen by student. Maximum Credits: 2

GEOL 499.course_description: GEOL 499 - Special Study  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Acceptable grade average in at least 12 upper division units within the major and consent of staff. Individual study in field, library, laboratory, or museum work.  Maximum Credits: 4

GEOL 502.course_description:
GEOL 502 - Advanced Field Topics  Units: 1-2 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Completion of, or concurrent enrollment in, cognate lecture/laboratory-based disciplinary course.Intensive field-based course focused on a specific disciplinary area of the geological sciences.  May be repeated with new content. 
  Maximum Credits: 4Note: See Schedule of Classes for specific content.

GEOL 505.course_name: Imaging and GIS in Disaster Response
GEOL 505.course_description: GEOL 505 - Imaging and GIS in Disaster Response  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): GEOL 200  or enrollment in homeland security program.Imaging and Geographic Information Systems applications in disaster management. Maximum Credits: 3

GEOL 508.course_description: GEOL 508 - Advanced Field Geology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Nine hours of laboratory involving fieldwork.Prerequisite(s): GEOL 306 .Investigation of individually assigned areas, preparation of geologic maps, geologic sections, and gathering other types of data as appropriate. Students are responsible for cost of food and transportation. Students must safely perform fieldwork under varied weather, terrain, and time conditions.

GEOL 514.course_description: GEOL 514 - Process Geomorphology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): GEOL 306 .Processes shaping and affecting the earth’s surface, and application of resultant land forms in interpretation of geologic structure, stratigraphy, and neotectonics. Maximum Credits: 3

GEOL 521.course_description: GEOL 521 - Petroleum Geology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): GEOL 336 .History of petroleum exploration; statistics of energy use; principles of well logging; theories of petroleum generation, migration, and accumulation; exploration and production techniques; case studies of important oil fields. Maximum Credits: 3

GEOL 530.course_description: GEOL 530 - Geochemistry  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): GEOL 324 ; credit or concurrent registration in CHEM 201 ; MATH 124  or MATH 150 .Fundamental principles of low- and high-temperature geochemistry. Origin of the elements; formation of the solar system; differentiation of the earth; weathering at the earth’s surface; chemistry of natural waters. Laboratory methods applied to geological problems. Maximum Credits: 3

GEOL 538.course_description: GEOL 538 - Notable Historic Earthquakes  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): GEOL 300 .Earthquake magnitude, fault source physics and rupture mechanisms, earthquake location and ground motion estimation, geotechnical aspects, earthquake triggering and geodesy. Maximum Credits: 3

GEOL 550.course_description: GEOL 550 - Engineering Geology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): GEOL 306 .Relationships between geologic processes and works of humans. Topics include rock and soil mechanics, ground water flow, slope stability, seismicity, land subsidence, and evaluation of geologic materials with respect to dam sites, tunnel alignments, and building foundations. Maximum Credits: 3

GEOL 551.course_description: GEOL 551 - Hydrogeology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): GEOL 306  and MATH 124  or MATH 150 .Theory of ground water flow. Exploration for and development of the ground water resource. Aquifer tests, water quality, and water resource management. Occurrence of water in alluvial, sedimentary, volcanic, plutonic, and metamorphic terrains. Maximum Credits: 3

GEOL 560.course_description: GEOL 560 - Earthquake Seismology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): MATH 252 , PHYS 197 . Recommended: MATH 342A .Theory of seismic wave excitation, propagation, and recording. Methods of seismogram interpretation and analysis. Applications to tectonics and earthquake hazard analysis. Maximum Credits: 3

GEOL 580.course_description: GEOL 580 - Seismic Interpretation and 3D Visualization  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): GEOL 306 .Computer-based seismic interpretation, mapping, and modeling in both 2D and 3D. Overview of basic seismic processing. Emphasis on industrial applications, both petroleum and shallow geotechnical. Maximum Credits: 3

GEOL 587.course_description: GEOL 587 - Volcanology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): GEOL 324 .Magma and magma chamber properties. Eruptive mechanisms, volcano types, and a variety of volcanic phenomena associated with Hawaiian, Strombolian, Plinian, Vulcanian, and hydrovolcanic eruptions. Volcanic phenomena applied to classic and historic eruptions.Formerly numbered Geological Sciences 687. Maximum Credits: 3

GEOL 596.course_description: GEOL 596 - Advanced Topics in Geology  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.Advanced special topics in the geological sciences.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units of 596 applicable to a bachelor’s degree.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree. Credit for 596 and 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser.

GEOL 600.course_description: GEOL 600 - Seminar  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Refer to Class Schedule for lecture/laboratory format.Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.An intensive study in advanced geology.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.Note: Topic to be announced in the Class Schedule.

GEOL 630.course_description: GEOL 630 - Selected Topics in Geophysics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.Research topics in seismic, gravity, magnetic, electrical, and electromagnetic methods.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content.

GEOL 633.course_description: GEOL 633 - Quaternary Geology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): GEOL 514 .Quaternary climate, geochronometric dating and soil stratigraphy. Maximum Credits: 3

GEOL 635.course_description: GEOL 635 - Petrology of Terrigenous Rocks  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): GEOL 336 .Thin-section and hand-specimen description and classification of sandstones, conglomerates, and mudrocks. Emphasis on mineralogy, provenance, diagenesis, and paleogeographic reconstructions. Maximum Credits: 3

GEOL 638.course_description: GEOL 638 - Advanced Notable Historic Earthquakes  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): GEOL 300 .Earthquake magnitude, fault source physics and rupture mechanisms, earthquake location and ground motion estimation, geotechnical aspects, earthquake triggering and geodesy. Term project on a selected earthquake including computer-based analysis of source, mechanism, and location. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Not open to students with credit in GEOL 538 .

GEOL 642.course_description: GEOL 642 - Neotectonics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): GEOL 306  and GEOL 514 .Observation, interpretation and significance of late Quaternary crustal deformation. Maximum Credits: 3

GEOL 645.course_description: GEOL 645 - Advanced Structural Geology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): GEOL 306 .Topics in advanced structural geology in the light of petrographic, geophysical, and experimental data, combined with classic field observations. Maximum Credits: 3

GEOL 675.course_description: GEOL 675 - Groundwater Geochemistry  Units: 3  Prerequisite(s): CHEM 201  and MATH 150 .Processes affecting inorganic solutes in groundwater. Applications to groundwater geochemical evolution, weathering processes, and inorganic contaminant transport.

GEOL 690.course_description: GEOL 690 - Earthquake Physics I  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): GEOL 560 . Recommended: MATH 342B .Structure and theology of fault zones as inferred from geological and geophysical observations. Stress state and frictional behavior of faults, stress interaction models, thermal, and hydrological properties of fault zones. Mechanics and energy budget of earthquakes. Maximum Credits: 3

GEOL 691.course_description: GEOL 691 - Earthquake Physics II  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): GEOL 560  and GEOL 690 . Recommended: MATH 342B .Theoretical and numerical models of earthquake rupture and wave propagation, with applications to ground motion prediction and seismic hazard estimation. Collective behavior of fault networks, seismicity models, earthquake predictability; application to earthquake forecast models. Maximum Credits: 3

GEOL 750.course_description: GEOL 750 - Research and Technical Writing  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Advancement to candidacy.Research and technical report writing in geological sciences for students in Plan B. Maximum Credits: 3

GEOL 797.course_description: GEOL 797 - Research  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of the department.Supervised research in an area of geological sciences. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s or Ph.D. degree.

GEOL 799A.course_description: GEOL 799A - Thesis  Units: 3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): An officially appointed thesis committee and advancement to candidacy.Preparation of a thesis for the master’s degree. Maximum Credits: 3

GEOL 799B.course_description: GEOL 799B - Thesis Extension  Units: 0 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Prior registration in Thesis 799A with an assigned grade symbol of RP.Registration required in any semester or term following assignment of RP in Course 799A in which the student expects to use the facilities and resources of the university; also student must be registered in the course when the completed thesis is granted final approval. Maximum Credits: 0

GEOL 799C.course_description: GEOL 799C - Comprehensive Examination Extension  Units: 0 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Completion or concurrent enrollment in degree program courses.Registration required of students whose only requirement is completion of the comprehensive examination for the master’s degree. Registration in 799C limited to two semesters. Maximum Credits: 0

GEOL 897.course_description: GEOL 897 - Doctoral Research  Units: 1-15 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to doctoral program.Independent investigation in general field of the dissertation. Maximum Credits: 15

GEOL 898.course_description: GEOL 898 - Doctoral Special Study  Units: 1-8 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to doctoral program. Individual study in field of specialization.  Maximum Credits: 8Maximum Credit Statement: eight units applicable to doctoral degree.

GEOL 899.course_description: GEOL 899 - Doctoral Dissertation  Units: 1-15 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): An officially constituted dissertation committee and advancement to candidacy.Preparation of the dissertation for the doctoral degree. Enrollment is required during the term in which the dissertation is approved. Maximum Credits: 15

GERMN 100A.course_description: GERMN 100A - First Course in German  Units: 5 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Pronunciation, oral practice, readings on German culture and civilization, minimum essentials of grammar. Maximum Credits: 5Note: Taught in German. Native speakers of German will not receive credit for taking lower division courses in German except with advance approval from the department. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division German course taught in German. No credit will be given for German 100A, GERMN 100B , GERMN 205A , GERMN 205B  taken out of sequence.

GERMN 100B.course_description: GERMN 100B - Second Course in German  Units: 5 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): GERMN 100A  or two years of high school German.Continuation of GERMN 100A . Maximum Credits: 5Note: Taught in German. Native speakers of German will not receive credit for taking lower division courses in German except with advance approval from the department. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division German course taught in German. No credit will be given for GERMN 100A , 100B, GERMN 205A , GERMN 205B  taken out of sequence.

GERMN 150.course_name: Contemporary German Culture and the New Europe
GERMN 150.course_description: GERMN 150 - Contemporary German Culture and the New Europe  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Introduction to fundamental questions of identity and belonging in contemporary German culture; investigation of Germany’s place within the European Union and cultural responses to the process of European integration. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Taught in English. Native speakers of German will not receive credit for taking lower division courses in German except with advance approval from the department. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division German course taught in German.

GERMN 202.course_description: GERMN 202 - Readings in German  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): GERMN 100B .Reading comprehension through intermediate-level cultural materials. Maximum Credits: 3Note: May be taken concurrently with GERMN 205A  or GERMN 205B . Taught in German. Native speakers of German will not receive credit for taking lower division courses in German except with advance approval from the department. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division German course taught in German.

GERMN 205A.course_description: GERMN 205A - Third Course in German  Units: 4 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Four lectures and one hour of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): GERMN 100B  or three years of high school German.Continuation of GERMN 100B . Practice of all language skills at intermediate level. Maximum Credits: 4Note: Taught in German. Native speakers of German will not receive credit for taking lower division courses in German except with advance approval from the department. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division German course taught in German. No credit will be given for GERMN 100A , GERMN 100B , 205A, GERMN 205B  taken out of sequence.

GERMN 205B.course_description: GERMN 205B - Fourth Course in German  Units: 4 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Four lectures and one hour of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): GERMN 205A .Continuation of GERMN 205A . Practice of all language skills at intermediate level. Maximum Credits: 4Note: Taught in German. Native speakers of German will not receive credit for taking lower division courses in German except with advance approval from the department. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division German course taught in German. No credit will be given for GERMN 100A , GERMN 100B , GERMN 205A , 205B taken out of sequence.

GERMN 296.course_description: GERMN 296 - Experimental Topics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected topics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree. Taught in German. Native speakers of German will not receive credit for taking lower division courses in German except with advance approval from the department. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division German course taught in German.

GERMN 300.course_description: GERMN 300 - Zeitgeist and Popular Culture  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): GERMN 202  and GERMN 205B .Development of advanced proficiency in reading comprehension and oral communication through use of cultural materials. Not open to students who hold a degree from a secondary or post-secondary school in which the primary language of instruction is German. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Taught in German. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division German course taught in German.

GERMN 301.course_description: GERMN 301 - Grammar and Composition  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): GERMN 202  and GERMN 205B . Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required: Copy of transcript.Grammar and stylistics; intensive writing practice; reports based on outside reading. Not open to students who hold a degree from a secondary or post-secondary school in which the primary language of instruction is German. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Taught in German. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division German course taught in German.

GERMN 304.course_description: GERMN 304 - Phonetics of Spoken German  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Three lectures and one hour of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): GERMN 202  and GERMN 205B .Sounds and intonation of German. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Taught in German. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division German course taught in German.

GERMN 320.course_description: GERMN 320 - German Film  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and two hours of activity.Masterpieces of German film. Emphasis on social, political, and cultural changes in modern Germany. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Taught in English.

GERMN 400.course_description: GERMN 400 - German Studies Through the Media  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): GERMN 300  or GERMN 301 .Society and institutions of German-speaking regions through spoken and written texts from the media. Emphasis on topics of importance for business, communications, and German area studies. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Taught in German. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division German course taught in German.

GERMN 410.course_name: Stories and Histories Since the Middle Ages
GERMN 410.course_description: GERMN 410 - Stories and Histories Since the Middle Ages  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): GERMN 202  and GERMN 205B .Historical milestones since the Middle Ages examined through various forms and genres of storytelling, while building advanced German language skills. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Taught in German. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division German course taught in German.

GERMN 411.course_name: Innovation and Transformation in German Culture
GERMN 411.course_description: GERMN 411 - Innovation and Transformation in German Culture  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): GERMN 202  and GERMN 205B .Transformations of German-speaking communities through major cultural, social, and technological innovations since the beginning of the twentieth century, while building advanced language skills. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Taught in German. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division German course taught in German.

GERMN 430.course_description: GERMN 430 - Culture and Society  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): GERMN 202  and GERMN 205B .Artistic, cultural, and intellectual innovations in German-speaking societies in Europe and around the world, while building advanced language skills.  May be repeated with new title and content. Maximum Credits: 6Note: Taught in German. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division German course taught in German.

GERMN 435.course_description: GERMN 435 - German Politics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): GERMN 202  and GERMN 205B .Key institutions in the German political system. Contemporary debates on culture, economics, environmental policy, identity, migration, and the welfare state. Germany’s contributions to the European Union and the world. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Taught in German. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division German course taught in German.

GERMN 495.course_description: GERMN 495 - German Internship  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing in major and consent of instructor.Practical work experience in a field related to German studies. Work done under joint direction of activity sponsor and instructor. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Approved international internships may count towards international experience requirement for major. Taught in German. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division German course taught in German.

GERMN 496.course_description: GERMN 496 - Experimental Topics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): GERMN 300  (for literary topics) or GERMN 301  (for linguistics topics).Selected topics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree. Taught in German. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division German course taught in German.

GERMN 499.course_description: GERMN 499 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Fifteen upper division units in the major with an average of B (3.0) or better and consent of instructor. Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required: Copy of transcript. Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6Note: Taught in German. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division German course taught in German.

GERMN 520.course_description: GERMN 520 - Modern German Literature  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): GERMN 300  and GERMN 301 .Major authors and genres since Enlightenment. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Taught in German. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division German course taught in German.

GERMN 575.course_description: GERMN 575 - Seminar in German Studies  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Two upper division German courses.Directed research on topics in German studies.  May be repeated with new title and content. Maximum Credits: 6Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Taught in German. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division German course taught in German.

GERMN 596.course_description: GERMN 596 - Topics in German Studies  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): GERMN 300  and GERMN 301 . Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required : Copy of transcript.Topics in German language, literature, or linguistics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree. Credit for 596 and 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser. Taught in German. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division German course taught in German.

GERMN 696.course_description: GERMN 696 - Topics in German Studies  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Eighteen upper division units in German.Intensive study in specific areas of German.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 12Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Credit for 596 and 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser.

GERMN 798.course_description: GERMN 798 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Eighteen upper division units in German and consent of staff; to be arranged with department chair and instructor. Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.

GERO 101.course_description: GERO 101 - Introduction to Human Aging  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Overview of field of gerontology, including demographic trends, basic theories, concepts and philosophic ideas, social policies, planning issues, and services available to meet needs and problems of older adults. Maximum Credits: 3

GERO 250.course_description: GERO 250 - Intergenerational Issues and the Elderly  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Controversial issues surrounding interpersonal relations between older adults and other age groups. Maximum Credits: 3

GERO 296.course_description: GERO 296 - Experimental Topics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected topics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

GERO 310.course_description: GERO 310 - Biology of Aging  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): GERO 101  or GERO 250 .Biological aging processes and impact on development of disease in later life. Age-associated diseases, approaches to prevent or reverse adverse effects of biological aging to promote healthy span, biological aging in various body systems, lifespans, mortality rates and senescence, and theories of aging. Maximum Credits: 3

GERO 350.course_description: GERO 350 - Social Policy and Aging  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): GERO 101 .Policy development process including analyses, evaluation, and advocacy. Social controversies about aging of populations. Review of U. S. Social Security and Medicare. Analysis of Older Americans Act. Maximum Credits: 3

GERO 360.course_description: GERO 360 - Diversity and Aging  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Prerequisite(s) recommended: GERO 101 .Attitudes and cultural values related to aging members of ethnic and minority groups. Influences of class, gender, sexual orientation, economic resources and health on aging process. Maximum Credits: 3Note: This course satisfies the general education cultural diversity requirement.

GERO 370.course_name: Images of Aging in Contemporary Society
GERO 370.course_description: GERO 370 - Images of Aging in Contemporary Society  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Prerequisite(s) recommended: GERO 101 .Impact of current cultural attitudes and values on images of older persons. Influence of media and advertising in creating views and perceptions of aging. Major myths and stereotypes. Maximum Credits: 3Note: This course satisfies the general education cultural diversity requirement.

GERO 380.course_description: GERO 380 - Social Issues of Aging  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): GERO 101  or GERO 250 .Attitudes toward aging shaped through various cultural, media, and social institutions. Interaction of personal social status characteristics with both social institutions and policies. Quality of life for people of all ages. Maximum Credits: 3

GERO 400A.course_description: GERO 400A - Practicum in Gerontology  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit  Two hundred hours of internship.Prerequisite(s): GERO 360 , GERO 370 , GERO 380 .Integration of theoretical background and practical experience in providing services to elderly. Fieldwork and observation in settings providing services to the elderly. Direct experience in aging projects relevant to their field of interest. Maximum Credits: 3

GERO 400B.course_description: GERO 400B - Practicum in Gerontology  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit  Two hundred hours of internship.Prerequisite(s): GERO 360 , GERO 370 , GERO 380 .Integration of theoretical background and practical experience in providing services to elderly. Fieldwork and observation in settings providing services to the elderly. Direct experience in aging projects relevant to their field of interest. Maximum Credits: 3

GERO 402.course_description: GERO 402 - Aging Network  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Three units in gerontology.Networks, programs, and services available to older adults in communities. Effectiveness of programs that assist older adults to age successfully. Maximum Credits: 3

GERO 496.course_description: GERO 496 - Experimental Topics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected topics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

GERO 499.course_description: GERO 499 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of department chair. Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6

GERO 520.course_name: Analysis of Programs for the Aging
GERO 520.course_description: GERO 520 - Analysis of Programs for the Aging  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): One upper division course in gerontology.Major programs in aging that support daily functioning of elderly. Effectiveness of programs in serving today’s elderly with attention to ethnic and cross-cultural variations. Maximum Credits: 3

GERO 596.course_description: GERO 596 - Advanced Special Topics in Gerontology  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Advanced selected topics in gerontology.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units of 596 applicable to a bachelor’s degree.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree. Credit for 596 and 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser.

GERO 605.course_description: GERO 605 - Long-Term Care  Units: 3  Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.Issues and problems in a changing long-term care delivery system for older people in a multi-cultural society. Emphasis on frailty of the elderly, demand for affordable long-term care, and analysis of federal and state policies shaping the industry.

GERO 690.course_name: Seminar in Research Methods for Social Work and Gerontology
GERO 690.course_description: GERO 690 - Seminar in Research Methods for Social Work and Gerontology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Same As: SWORK 690 . Research development, design, and methodology. Application to social work and gerontology in testing theories, advancing practice knowledge, and decision-making. Maximum Credits: 3

GERO 696.course_name: Contemporary Topics in Gerontology and Geriatrics Seminar
GERO 696.course_description: GERO 696 - Contemporary Topics in Gerontology and Geriatrics Seminar  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): A graduate level course in gerontology.Areas of gerontology and geriatrics that make an immediate impact on the quality of life and lifestyles of the elderly. To include diverse life situations of older people.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 3Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Credit for 596 and 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser.
