HTM 682.course_name: Sustainability in Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Organizations
HTM 682.course_description: HTM 682 - Sustainability in Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Organizations  Units: 2 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): HTM 651 , HTM 653 , HTM 655 .Development of a comprehensive sustainability management system incorporating marketing and communication, goal setting, developing performance indicators and metrics, benchmarking, and strategies for ongoing, measurable, sustainability performance improvement. Maximum Credits: 2

HTM 683.course_description: HTM 683 - Sustainability in Meetings and Events  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to M.S. program.Development of sustainability plan within meetings and events industries. Analyses of non-compliance. Performance improvement and communication strategies. Maximum Credits: 3

HTM 690.course_description: HTM 690 - Systems Problems Resolution in HTM  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): HTM 651 , HTM 653 , HTM 655 .Project oriented course on solving real problems in hospitality, tourism, and recreation organizations and businesses. Maximum Credits: 3

HTM 696.course_name: Special Topics in Hospitality and Tourism Management
HTM 696.course_description: HTM 696 - Special Topics in Hospitality and Tourism Management  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Classified graduate standing.Study in specific areas of hospitality and tourism management.  May be repeated with new content with the approval of graduate adviser. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Credit for 596 and 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser.

HTM 697.course_description: HTM 697 - Mentoring and Coaching  Units: 2 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): HTM 663 .Collaboration, experiential learning, and mentorship with executives from meetings and events industries. Maximum Credits: 2

HTM 698.course_description: HTM 698 - MentorEDGE Program  Units: 2 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): HTM 601  Mentoring to include customized learning and competency development. Create a leadership vision along with context, relationship, and self-mastery competencies. Maximum Credits: 2

HTM 780.course_name: Seminar: Strategy Development and Critical Analysis in HTM
HTM 780.course_description: HTM 780 - Seminar: Strategy Development and Critical Analysis in HTM  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): HTM 680 , HTM 682 , HTM 690 .Case study analysis requiring command of all previously delivered program course material to include data analysis, effective teamwork and leadership, and overall organizational assessment. Maximum Credits: 3

HTM 781.course_name: Seminar: Strategy Development and Critical Analysis in Meetings and Events
HTM 781.course_description: HTM 781 - Seminar: Strategy Development and Critical Analysis in Meetings and Events  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): HTM 664  and HTM 690 .Comprehensive team case study and presentation. Data analysis, leadership, and teamwork. Maximum Credits: 3

HTM 790.course_name: Directed Readings in Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Management
HTM 790.course_description: HTM 790 - Directed Readings in Hospitality, Tourism, and Recreation Management  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): HTM 680 , HTM 682 , HTM 690 , and advancement to candidacy.Preparation for the comprehensive examination for students in Plan B. Maximum Credits: 3

HTM 791.course_name: Directed Readings in Meetings and Events
HTM 791.course_description: HTM 791 - Directed Readings in Meetings and Events  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): HTM 663 .Analyses of scholarship encompassing events, leadership, management, and meetings disciplines. Maximum Credits: 3

HTM 797.course_description: HTM 797 - Research  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Classified graduate standing and consent of instructor.Supervised research in an area of hospitality and tourism management. Maximum Credits: 3Maximum Credit Statement: three units of HTM 790, HTM 797, or HTM 798 applicable to a master’s degree.

HTM 798.course_description: HTM 798 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Classified graduate standing and consent of instructor. Individual study, generally for thesis research.  Maximum Credits: 3Maximum Credit Statement: three units of HTM 790, HTM 797, or HTM 798 applicable to a master’s degree.

HTM 799C.course_description: HTM 799C - Comprehensive Examination Extension  Units: 0 Grading Method: Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Completion of degree program courses.Registration required of students whose only requirement is completion of the comprehensive examination for the master’s degree. Registration in 799C limited to two semesters.

HUM 101.course_description: HUM 101 - Introduction to Humanities  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Preliminary investigation: how values and ideals are expressed in literary, artistic, and intellectual achievements of individuals and civilizations throughout the world. Maximum Credits: 3

HUM 102.course_description: HUM 102 - Global Humanities  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Themes from standpoint of global interconnections. Interdisciplinary examinations through historical, linguistic, literary, and philosophical lenses. Current issues of global importance. Maximum Credits: 3

HUM 103.course_description: HUM 103 - Introduction to Public Humanities  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC How humanities engage diverse and divergent publics. What makes a public, what makes scholarship public humanities, and what can be done in the university to ensure more access, education, and justice outside of it. Maximum Credits: 3

HUM 130.course_description: HUM 130 - The Jewish Heritage  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: JS 130  Hebraic and Jewish influences on the arts, literature, philosophy, and religion of Western civilization. Maximum Credits: 3

HUM 140.course_description: HUM 140 - World Mythology  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Comparative themes and figures from various mythologies of the world. Interpretation of myths; their influence on art, culture, and history. Maximum Credits: 3

HUM 201.course_description: HUM 201 - The Body: Identity, Crisis, Resistance  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC How bodies shape our understanding of ourselves and others across multiple spheres of private and public life. The body and identity, physiological health challenges and solutions, the social power of physical movement. Maximum Credits: 3

HUM 296.course_description: HUM 296 - Experimental Topics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected topics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

HUM 310.course_description: HUM 310 - French Culture  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Literature and culture stemming from France. Literary, artistic, and intellectual achievements. Traditions and influences to include contributions of the Francophone world. Maximum Credits: 3

HUM 322.course_description: HUM 322 - LGBT History and Culture  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: LGBT 322   Interdisciplinary field of lesbian and gay studies with attention to history and artistic expression. Topics include varying attitudes toward homosexuality in history, as well as literary, artistic, theatrical, and musical contributions of the lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender community. Maximum Credits: 3Note: This course satisfies the general education cultural diversity requirement.

HUM 330.course_description: HUM 330 - Russian Culture  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Religion, literature, philosophy, music, and art of Russia. From the patriarchs of the past to the people of the present. Russia’s influence on European humanities and world culture. Maximum Credits: 3

HUM 360.course_description: HUM 360 - Animal Humanities  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Humanities beyond “the human.” Nonhuman animals as subjects in the world. Animals as focus of ethics, literature, philosophy, theory, and visual culture. Maximum Credits: 3

HUM 370.course_description: HUM 370 - American Culture  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Literary, artistic, and intellectual achievements of the United States from colonial times to the present day. Great cultural traditions and influences represented in the contributions of Americans of diverse gender, ethnic, geographic, and political identity. Maximum Credits: 3

HUM 380.course_description: HUM 380 - Japanese Culture  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: ASIAN 380  and JAPAN 380 . Significant works of literary, performing, and visual arts to include array of artistic trends, cultural phenomena, historical developments, and socio-political discourses throughout the nation’s long and tumultuous history. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Taught in English.

HUM 390W.course_description: HUM 390W - Writing in the Humanities  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): HUM 101  or HUM 102  with a grade of C (2.0) or better. Satisfies Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement for students who have completed 60 units; and completed General Education requirements in Communication and Critical Thinking. Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required: Test scores or verification of exemption; copy of transcript.Theoretical approaches in study of humanities. Writing in discipline of humanities through analysis of key thinkers in history. Maximum Credits: 3

HUM 405.course_description: HUM 405 - Faith and Hope  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: REL S 405  Humanities as expressed in religion. Acquisition and/or loss of faith. Questioning of theological systems. Confrontation with death. Nature of hope. Use of signs, symbols, and narratives to generate social structures. Symbolic and mystical systems of meaning. Influence of religion upon culture. Maximum Credits: 3

HUM 406.course_description: HUM 406 - Renaissance and Self  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Rebirth broadly defined, up to the present. The idea of progress. Humanities and cult of antiquity. Innovation in arts and letters. Traversing the globe. Quest for virtue, fame, glory. Questioning the past. The nature of genius. Maximum Credits: 3

HUM 407.course_description: HUM 407 - Rationalists and Romantics  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Eighteenth century Enlightenment and its descendants. Rational interaction with the world. Literature, philosophy, music, art, and poetry representing rationalist and romantic ideologies. Conquest of nature and retreat to nature. Reason versus passion. Romantic responses to rationalists. Maximum Credits: 3

HUM 408.course_description: HUM 408 - The Modern  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Conceptualizing past and present. Valorization of the new and improved. Cultural products of imperialism, monopoly, consumerism, mass media, and corporate identity. The culture of the “Other.” Literary, artistic, and intellectual breakthroughs of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries and their influences. Maximum Credits: 3

HUM 409.course_description: HUM 409 - The Future  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Conceiving of time and visions for tomorrow in an ever-changing world. Being human in an age of artificial intelligence and cloning. Utopian and dystopian visions. Thinkers, artists, and scientists from past and present contemplate the unknown. Breakthroughs and possibilities. Maximum Credits: 3

HUM 410.course_description: HUM 410 - Studies in Popular Culture  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Popular culture informed by significant cultural discourses, historical developments, and political debates. Representative works to include secondary critical readings, animated film, comics, literature, live-action film, and television. Maximum Credits: 3

HUM 411.course_description: HUM 411 - Understanding Evil  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: REL S 411   Evil and how the language of evil has been used by diverse religious communities. Conceptions and portrayals of demons, hell, Satan, and vampires. Literature on the Holocaust, terrorism, torture, and war. Maximum Credits: 3Note: This course satisfies the general education cultural diversity requirement.

HUM 412.course_description: HUM 412 - Science and the Humanities  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC How developments in science and technology have informed artistic, literary, and philosophical production throughout the modern era. Maximum Credits: 3

HUM 413.course_description: HUM 413 - Theory in the Humanities  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): HUM 101 , HUM 102 , or upper division standing.Humanistic inquiry. Theories and theoretical debates across geographical borders. Foundational theories and recent interventions. Maximum Credits: 3Note: This course satisfies the general education cultural diversity requirement.

HUM 490.course_name: Senior Seminar in Classics and Humanities
HUM 490.course_description: HUM 490 - Senior Seminar in Classics and Humanities  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Classics or humanities major with more than 90 units; others with consent of department chair.Senior capstone seminar in major. Discussion and research on topic in classics and humanities. Formal research paper. Maximum Credits: 3

HUM 496.course_description: HUM 496 - Topics in Humanities  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Interdisciplinary topics in literature and the arts.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 6Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

HUM 499.course_description: HUM 499 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor and department chair. Directed individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6

HUM 504.course_description: HUM 504 - The Dark Ages  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: HIST 504  Europe and the Mediterranean, sixth to eleventh centuries C.E. through various approaches: political, economic, social, and cultural. Topics include: barbarians and Vikings, the Byzantine, Arab, and Holy Roman Empires, the Norman Conquest, Charlemagne, Beowulf, feudalism, and serfdom. Maximum Credits: 3

HUM 506.course_description: HUM 506 - The Renaissance  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: HIST 506  Intellectual, artistic, social, and economic transformation in Europe from fourteenth to seventeenth centuries. Maximum Credits: 3

HUM 580.course_description: HUM 580 - Topics in the Humanities  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Three units of humanities and upper division or graduate standing.Advanced systematic study of a motif or theme in the humanities.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 6Note: See Class Schedule for specific content.

HUM 596.course_description: HUM 596 - Topics in Humanities  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing and consent of instructor.Interdisciplinary topics in literature and the arts.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 6Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree. No more than six units of 596 may be applied to a bachelor’s degree. Credit for 596 and 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser.

HUM 599.course_description: HUM 599 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of major or graduate adviser; to be arranged by department chair and instructor. Directed individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6

INT S 690.course_description: INT S 690 - Seminar in Research Ethics  Units: 1 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.Core content areas that influence responsible conduct of research (RCR) including research misconduct, data management, use of animal and human subjects, conflict of interest and commitment, authorship, publication and peer review, and collaboration and mentoring. Intended for graduate students involved in research projects. Meets NIH and NSF training grant requirements for RCR instruction. Maximum Credits: 1

INT S 797.course_description: INT S 797 - Research  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Advancement to candidacy and completion of Special Study Request Form.Independent research in a specialized subject. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.

INT S 798.course_description: INT S 798 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Completion of Special Study Request Form. Independent study.  Maximum Credits: 3Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.

INT S 799A.course_description: INT S 799A - Thesis or Project  Units: 3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): An officially appointed thesis committee and advancement to candidacy.Preparation of a project or thesis for the master’s degree. Maximum Credits: 3

INT S 799B.course_description: INT S 799B - Thesis or Project Extension  Units: 0 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Prior registration in Thesis 799A with an assigned grade symbol of RP.Registration in any semester or term following assignment of RP in Course 799A in which the student expects to use the facilities and resources of the university; also the student must be registered in the course when the completed thesis or project is granted final approval. Maximum Credits: 0

INT S 799C.course_description: INT S 799C - Comprehensive Examination Extension  Units: 0 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Completion or concurrent enrollment in degree program courses.Registration required of students whose only requirement is completion of the comprehensive examination for the master’s degree. Registration in 799C limited to two semesters. Maximum Credits: 0

I B 295.course_description: I B 295 - Internship Experience  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor and a minimum of 15 units taken at SDSU with a GPA of 2.9 or better.Internship in business or community setting. Work done under joint direction of activity sponsor and instructor. Project assignments and minimum hour requirement depending on units. Not applicable to the major. Maximum Credits: 6

I B 296.course_description: I B 296 - Topics in International Business  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected topics in international business.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 6Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

I B 299.course_description: I B 299 - Special Study  Units: 3-6  Prerequisite(s): Pre-International Business major. Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6

I B 410.course_description: I B 410 - Doing Business in Latin America  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): B A 310 , B A 350 , and B A 370  with a grade of C (2.0) or better in each course.Business and managerial methods, practices, and systems in Latin American markets. Maximum Credits: 3

I B 420.course_description: I B 420 - Doing Business in Europe  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): B A 310  and B A 350  with a grade of C (2.0) or better in each course.Business and managerial methods, practices, and systems in European markets. Maximum Credits: 3

I B 430.course_description: I B 430 - Doing Business in Asia  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): B A 310  and B A 350  with a grade of C (2.0) or better in each course.Business and managerial methods, practices, and systems in Asian markets. Maximum Credits: 3

I B 495.course_description: I B 495 - International Business Internship  Units: 3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing in the major.Internships with international business firms, nonprofit organizations, and government agencies in U.S. and abroad. Work done under joint direction of activity sponsor and instructor. Project report and internship orientation required. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units with consent of instructor.

I B 498.course_description: I B 498 - Doing Business Internationally  Units: 1 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Upper division status in the major.Required business customs and protocol course pertinent to all regions. Maximum Credits: 1

I B 499.course_description: I B 499 - Special Study  Units: 1-6 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): International business major. Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6

I B 596.course_description: I B 596 - Topics in International Business  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.Selected topics in international business.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 6Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree. Credit for 596 and 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser.

ISCOR 200.course_description: ISCOR 200 - International Security and Conflict Resolution  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Comprehensive picture of multidisciplinary international and conflict resolution (ISCOR) program. Maximum Credits: 3

ISCOR 300.course_description: ISCOR 300 - Global Systems  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Historical and contemporary examination of the global political, social, and economic order; examination of interaction of global forces with local and regional developments; studies of distinct contemporary and past global issues. Maximum Credits: 3This course satisfies the cultural diversity requirement.

ISCOR 301.course_description: ISCOR 301 - Conflict and Conflict Resolution  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Examination of global, regional, and local dynamics that engender conflict, review of distinct diplomatic approaches (formal or informal) to resolve conflicts, case studies of past and ongoing conflicts. Maximum Credits: 3Note: This course satisfies the general education cultural diversity requirement.

ISCOR 310.course_name: Our Global Future: Environment, Climate, and the Prospects of Survival
ISCOR 310.course_description: ISCOR 310 - Our Global Future: Environment, Climate, and the Prospects of Survival  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Examines impact of environmental changes on the global order; how environmental dynamics interact with political, economic, and social forces at the global, regional, and local levels; particular focus on the climate crisis. Maximum Credits: 3

ISCOR 320.course_name: International Security in the Nuclear Age
ISCOR 320.course_description: ISCOR 320 - International Security in the Nuclear Age  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing. Nine units of General Education requirements in Foundations of Learning, to include three units each in Natural Sciences and Quantitative Reasoning, in Social and Behavioral Sciences, and in Humanities.International security issues from historical, ethical, economic and sociopsychological perspectives, including the security environment after the Cold War and current sources of conflict. The proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, including nuclear weapons is discussed. Maximum Credits: 3

ISCOR 324.course_name: Politics of Global Resistance and Solidarity
ISCOR 324.course_description: ISCOR 324 - Politics of Global Resistance and Solidarity  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Study of global resistance movements in such areas as antimilitarism, economic justice, and social equality; includes a section on climate justice; attention to revolutionary and reformist theories of change at the global, regional, and local levels. Maximum Credits: 3

ISCOR 421.course_name: Alternative Dispute Resolution: Theory and International Applications
ISCOR 421.course_description: ISCOR 421 - Alternative Dispute Resolution: Theory and International Applications  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.Theory of collaborative negotiation and mediation, practice of negotiation and mediation skills and techniques, and focus on personal styles of mediation and collaborative negotiating. Emphasis on resolving conflicts on the international level. Maximum Credits: 3

ISCOR 450.course_name: Study Abroad in International Security and Conflict Resolution
ISCOR 450.course_description: ISCOR 450 - Study Abroad in International Security and Conflict Resolution  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing. Class Schedule may have other prerequisites.Selected topics in international security and conflict resolution. Course taught abroad. Potential additional prerequisites and location of course and organizational meetings.  May be repeated once with new content. Maximum Credits: 6Note: See Class Schedule for specific content.

ISCOR 495.course_name: Internship in International Security and Conflict Resolution
ISCOR 495.course_description: ISCOR 495 - Internship in International Security and Conflict Resolution  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Senior standing. Nine units of international security and conflict resolution core courses and nine units in selected specialization. Consent of instructor.Supervised internship of 150 hours in government or nongovernmental agency, office or business in an area directly related to international security and conflict resolution. Maximum Credits: 3

ISCOR 496.course_name: Selected Topics in International Security and Conflict Resolution
ISCOR 496.course_description: ISCOR 496 - Selected Topics in International Security and Conflict Resolution  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected topics in international security and conflict resolution.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

ISCOR 497.course_name: Thesis in International Security and Conflict Resolution
ISCOR 497.course_description: ISCOR 497 - Thesis in International Security and Conflict Resolution  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Senior standing. Nine units of international security and conflict resolution core courses and nine units in selected specialization. Consent of instructor.An original and comprehensive written description and analysis of a problem or problem area in international security and conflict resolution. Maximum Credits: 3

ISCOR 499.course_description: ISCOR 499 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Six units of international security and conflict resolution core courses and six units in specialization. Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6

ITAL 100A.course_description: ITAL 100A - Elementary Italian I  Units: 5 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Pronunciation, speaking and writing, readings on Italian culture and civilization, essentials of grammar. Maximum Credits: 5Note: Taught in Italian. Native speakers of Italian will not receive credit for taking lower division courses in Italian except with advance approval from the department. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division Italian course taught in Italian. No credit will be given when Italian 100A, ITAL 100B , ITAL 211 , ITAL 212 , and ITAL 301  are taken concurrently or out of sequence.

ITAL 100B.course_description: ITAL 100B - Elementary Italian II  Units: 5 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): ITAL 100A  or two years of high school Italian.Continuation of ITAL 100A . Maximum Credits: 5Note: Taught in Italian. Native speakers of Italian will not receive credit for taking lower division courses in Italian except with advance approval from the department. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division Italian course taught in Italian. LATAM 296.course_description: LATAM 296 - Experimental Topics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected topics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

LATAM 306.course_name: Portuguese and Brazilian Cinema and Culture
LATAM 306.course_description: LATAM 306 - Portuguese and Brazilian Cinema and Culture  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: PORT 306  Main movements and productions of Portuguese and Brazilian cinema. Social factors and representations of national identities. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Taught in English.

LATAM 307.course_description: LATAM 307 - Brazilian Music and Culture  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: PORT 307   Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.Brazilian music and culture with emphasis on religious and cultural practices of candomble, capoeira, carnival, and notions of race and class in contemporary Brazilian funk and hip-hop. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Taught in English. This course satisfies the general education cultural diversity requirement.

LATAM 310.course_description: LATAM 310 - Mexican and Chicano Music  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: CCS 310   Music of Mexico and the Southwest including folk dances appropriate for children and adults. Emphasis on the corrido, its history and development in Mexico and the US. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Course will be taught bilingually. This course satisfies the ethnic studies [ES] requirement.

LATAM 320.course_description: LATAM 320 - Culture and Society of Tijuana  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Mexican dance, art, music, cuisine, politics, tourism industry, education, and other facets of daily life through visits to selected venues. Note: Not open to students enrolled in or with prior credit in LATAM 550.

LATAM 325.course_description: LATAM 325 - Political Economy of Brazil  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Recommended: LATAM 101  with a grade of C (2.0) or better.Effects of development policies, global interactions, and neoliberal economic strategies on the cultures and people of Brazil. Maximum Credits: 3Note: This course satisfies the general education cultural diversity requirement.

LATAM 333.course_name: Race, Ethnicity, and Identity in the Americas
LATAM 333.course_description: LATAM 333 - Race, Ethnicity, and Identity in the Americas  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: ANTH 333  Prerequisite(s): LATAM 101  or ANTH 102 .History and contemporary forms of identity to include ethnicity, gender, nationality, race, and sexuality in Canada, Latin America, and United States Maximum Credits: 3

LATAM 350.course_description: LATAM 350 - Globalization and the Americas  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Causes and consequences of international integration in western hemisphere, including United States and Canada. Emphasis on Latin America. Multiple dimensions of integration examined from variety of disciplinary perspectives. Maximum Credits: 3

LATAM 355.course_description: LATAM 355 - The United States-Mexico International Border  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: CCS 355   Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.History, culture, economics, and politics of US/Mexico border region. Theories and policy issues surrounding development of region; local regional problems and major agencies, institutions, organizations addressing these problems. Maximum Credits: 3Note: This course satisfies the ethnic studies [ES] requirement.

LATAM 366.course_description: LATAM 366 - Latin American Politics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: POL S 366  Introduction to Latin American politics. Knowledge of political change and political systems in Latin America, viewed historically and comparatively, using concepts and theories applicable to more general political analysis. Maximum Credits: 3

LATAM 370.course_name: History of Mexico: From Independence to Early Twentieth Century
LATAM 370.course_description: LATAM 370 - History of Mexico: From Independence to Early Twentieth Century  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Recommended: LATAM 101 .Cultural history of Mexico from Mexico’s independence from Spain in early nineteenth century to presidency of Lazaro Cardenas. History of legacy of Caudillos, evolution of PRI, and US/Mexico relations from a Mexican perspective. Maximum Credits: 3Note: This course satisfies the general education cultural diversity requirement.

LATAM 380.course_description: LATAM 380 - US/Mexico Borderlands Folklore  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: CCS 380   Prerequisite(s): Recommended: CCS 110 .Border folklore, its complexities and dynamics via myths, rituals, legends, sayings, corridos (ballads), and literature of Chicanos and Mexicanos in the US-Mexican border region. Maximum Credits: 3Note: This course satisfies the ethnic studies [ES] requirement.

LATAM 400.course_description: LATAM 400 - Mexican Images in Film  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: CCS 400   Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.Comparative study of images presented by Hollywood, Mexican, and Chicano cinemas. Critical analysis and discussion of projected values. Comparison of themes in film and text. Maximum Credits: 3Note: This course satisfies the ethnic studies [ES] requirement.

LATAM 415.course_description: LATAM 415 - Pre-Contact and Colonial Latin America  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: HIST 415   Indigenous and colonial history of Latin America, pre-contact through early national period. Maximum Credits: 3Note: This course satisfies the general education cultural diversity requirement.

LATAM 420.course_description: LATAM 420 - Latin America through Film  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Recommended: LATAM 101 .Exploration of diverse cultures and history of Latin America through feature film by Latin American cinematographers. Political, social, and historic phenomena. Maximum Credits: 3Note: This course satisfies the general education cultural diversity requirement.

LATAM 425.course_name: Illness, Health, and Healing in Latin America
LATAM 425.course_description: LATAM 425 - Illness, Health, and Healing in Latin America  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Cultural, economic, political, and social aspects of healing, health, and illness in Latin America. Maximum Credits: 3

LATAM 430.course_description: LATAM 430 - Immigration and Border Politics  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: POL S 430   Prerequisite(s): Completion of the American Institutions requirement.U.S. immigration and border politics within a global and historical perspective. Transformations of sovereignty, communities, identity, and rights within an area of mass migration and economic interdependence. Policy and popular debates about admission, border control, and incorporation of migrants. Maximum Credits: 3Note: This course satisfies the general education cultural diversity requirement.

LATAM 450.course_name: Study Abroad in Latin American Studies
LATAM 450.course_description: LATAM 450 - Study Abroad in Latin American Studies  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing. See Class Schedule for additional prerequisites.Selected topics in Latin American studies.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units of which three units may be applicable to General Education.Note: Courses taught abroad through a program approved by the Center for Latin American Studies. See Class Schedule for specific content and geographic location. This course satisfies the general education cultural diversity requirement.

LATAM 495.course_description: LATAM 495 - Latin American Studies Internship  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Six upper division units in Latin American content courses.Opportunity for Latin American studies undergraduates to implement area specialist skills. Placement with a local organization with legal, commercial, or social service functions whose activities are primarily Latin American related.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 6

LATAM 496.course_description: LATAM 496 - Experimental Topics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected topics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

LATAM 498.course_description: LATAM 498 - Seminar on Latin America  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Exploration of the interdisciplinary approach to Latin America including evaluation of relevant resources and methods. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Taught by a team of instructors representing two or more disciplines.

LATAM 499.course_description: LATAM 499 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6

LATAM 545.course_description: LATAM 545 - The Latin American City  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division or graduate standing in Latin American studies, anthropology, Chicana and Chicano studies, history, political science, or sociology.History and theory of urbanization in Latin America to include urban landscapes, rural to urban migrations, re-creation of community within urban centers, modified identities, globalized labor, segregation, and community borders. Maximum Credits: 3

LATAM 550.course_name: Mexican-US Border from a Latin American Perspective
LATAM 550.course_description: LATAM 550 - Mexican-US Border from a Latin American Perspective  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Six upper division units with Latin American content. Spanish proficiency.Multidisciplinary analysis of Mexican-US border region. Note: Not open to students enrolled in or with prior credit in LATAM 320.

LATAM 553.course_name: History of Slavery in the Americas
LATAM 553.course_description: LATAM 553 - History of Slavery in the Americas  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: HIST 553  Prerequisite(s): Upper division or graduate standing.Trans-Atlantic slavery from the fifteenth to nineteenth centuries. Liberation movements, nation-states, revolution, slavery, and capitalism. Agency of enslaved people, agricultural and environmental transformations, legacies of trans-Atlantic slavery and contemporary enslavement, new communities and diversities, race and racism. Maximum Credits: 3

LATAM 556.course_description: LATAM 556 - History of Brazil  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: HIST 556  Prerequisite(s): Upper division or graduate standing.Economic, political, and social history of Brazil from precolonial era to present. Democratic and dictatorial rule, industrialization, populism, race and racism, and slavery. Maximum Credits: 3

LATAM 580.course_description: LATAM 580 - Special Topics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Six upper division units in Latin American content courses.Interdisciplinary study of selected Latin American topics.  May be repeated with different content. Maximum Credits: 8Note: Credit will vary depending on the scope and nature of the topic. Whenever appropriate, the course will be taught by a team of instructors representing two or more disciplines. See Class Schedule for specific content.

LATAM 600.course_description: LATAM 600 - Seminar in Latin American Studies  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.Core seminar in Latin American studies. Historical, conceptual, and methodological survey of Latin American studies from first European conquests in western hemisphere to end of twentieth century. Maximum Credits: 3

LATAM 601.course_name: Seminar on Methodology of Latin American Studies
LATAM 601.course_description: LATAM 601 - Seminar on Methodology of Latin American Studies  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.Theories and methodologies of Latin American Studies. Maximum Credits: 3

LATAM 696.course_description: LATAM 696 - Experimental Topics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.Intensive study in specific areas of Latin American studies.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 12Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Credit for 596 and 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser.

LATAM 750.course_description: LATAM 750 - Seminar: Study in Latin America  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing and acceptance into COLEF/SDSU Exchange program or other relevant exchange program with partner university in Latin America.Selected topics seminar in Latin American studies. Students will be required to attend classes at a partner university in Latin America.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.

LATAM 795.course_description: LATAM 795 - Latin American Studies Internship  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): LATAM 601  and consent of instructor.A 160-hour internship approved by instructor in public and private agency.

LATAM 797.course_description: LATAM 797 - Research  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of graduate adviser.Research in one of the fields of Latin American studies. Maximum Credits: 3Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.

LATAM 798.course_description: LATAM 798 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of staff; to be arranged with the director and instructor. Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.

LATAM 799A.course_description: LATAM 799A - Thesis  Units: 3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): An officially appointed thesis committee and advancement to candidacy.Preparation of a project or thesis for the master’s degree. Maximum Credits: 3

LATAM 799B.course_description: LATAM 799B - Thesis Extension  Units: 0 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Prior registration in Thesis 799A with an assigned grade symbol of RP.Registration required in any semester or term following assignment of RP in Course 799A in which the student expects to use the facilities and resources of the university; also student must be registered in the course when the completed thesis is granted final approval. Maximum Credits: 0

LDT 296.course_description: LDT 296 - Experimental Topics  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected topics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

LDT 410.course_description: LDT 410 - Social Media for Learning  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and one hour of discussion.Prerequisite(s): Admission to a major or minor in the School of Journalism and Media Studies.Social media for learning and workforce training. Current and prospective social media practices in learning organizations. Integration of social media strategies into learning experiences. Maximum Credits: 3

LDT 432.course_description: LDT 432 - Producing Digital Learning Media  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  One lecture and four hours of activity.Prerequisite(s): JMS 408  with a grade of C (2.0) or better. Admission to a major in the School of Journalism and Media Studies.Design and development of technology-delivered multimedia training and education materials. Principles of training design applied to diverse organizations and audiences. Production of digital media and tools for learning in organizations. Maximum Credits: 3

LDT 496.course_description: LDT 496 - Experimental Topics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected topics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

LDT 499.course_description: LDT 499 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Open only to senior and graduate students in education who have shown ability to work independently. Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6

LDT 515.course_description: LDT 515 - Games, Play, and Learning  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division or graduate standing.Analysis of games and play from cognitive, historical, motivational, and social perspectives. Design of simple learning games. Survey of the game industry and use of games in education and training. Maximum Credits: 3

LDT 520.course_description: LDT 520 - Consciousness Hacking  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or admission to a Journalism and Media Studies or Learning Design and Technology graduate program.Personal investigation into conscious awareness, identity, and mind. Exploration of mindfulness, self-inquiry, and similar contemporary approaches to personal awakening. Opportunities for direct experience with meditation, yoga, and related methods for expanding awareness, quieting mind, and cultivating communication, creativity, and intelligence. Maximum Credits: 3

LDT 525.course_name: Virtual Reality, Imaginary Worlds, and Future of Learning
LDT 525.course_description: LDT 525 - Virtual Reality, Imaginary Worlds, and Future of Learning  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or admission to a graduate program in learning design and technology or journalism and media studies.Learning experiences using virtual reality and worlds. Cognitive load in novel environments, sensory perception, theories and models of social interaction. Implications of virtual interaction. Maximum Credits: 6

LDT 540.course_description: LDT 540 - Educational Technology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Six hours of activity.Rationale, foundations, theories, careers, trends, and issues in educational technology. Implications of educational technology for instruction and information in schools, government, and corporations.Formerly numbered Educational Technology 540. Maximum Credits: 3

LDT 544.course_description: LDT 544 - Instructional Design  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  One lecture and six hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): LDT 540 .Systematic design of products for education and training. Use of analyses and content mapping to set instructional goals. Instructional methods derived from learning theories for use in schools, universities, corporations, and other settings. Rapid prototyping of instructional products.Formerly numbered Educational Technology 544. Maximum Credits: 3

LDT 561.course_description: LDT 561 - Advanced Multimedia Design for Learning  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Six hours of activity.Prerequisite(s): LDT 540 .Educational visualization with digital video, animation, sound, 2D and 3D graphics for mobile and web-based learning.Formerly numbered Educational Technology 561. Maximum Credits: 3

LDT 572.course_description: LDT 572 - Active Learning Strategies with Technology  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNO - Letter (No Cr/NC)  Two lectures and two hours of activity. Prerequisite(s): Upper division or graduate standing.Use of technology to support designing and managing instructor-led courses. Topics include building interactive activities, creating flipped videos and screencasts, developing online instruction that supports learners using Universal Design for Learning strategies, and harnessing the power of a learning management system.Formerly numbered Educational Technology 572.

LDT 596.course_name: Topics in Learning Design and Technology
LDT 596.course_description: LDT 596 - Topics in Learning Design and Technology  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected problems in educational technology.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units of 596 applicable to a bachelor’s degree.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree. Credit for 596 and 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser.

LDT 630.course_description: LDT 630 - Mobile Applications for Learning  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and two hours of activity.Prerequisite(s): LDT 540 .Mobile learning models and examples. Design principles and development processes. Adapting mobile learning for different environments, settings, and cultures. Future trends. Maximum Credits: 3

LDT 640.course_description: LDT 640 - Psychology of Technology-Based Learning  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Six hours of activity.Prerequisite(s): LDT 544 .Principles of human learning and cognition applied to design and use of technology-based learning systems. Development of research-based guidelines for designing educational products and services.Formerly numbered Educational Technology 640. Maximum Credits: 3

LDT 670.course_description: LDT 670 - Learning Through Games and Simulations  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  One lecture and six hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): LDT 540 .Design, evaluation, and use of simulations and games for education and training. Instructional applications of role plays, board games, and multiplayer virtual worlds. Theories of motivation and interest.Formerly numbered Educational Technology 670. Maximum Credits: 3

LDT 671.course_description: LDT 671 - Learning Environment Design  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  One lecture and six hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): LDT 544  and LDT 561 .Design and development of individualized instruction delivered through e-learning; learning management systems; informal learning for corporate and museum education.Formerly numbered Educational Technology 671. Maximum Credits: 3

LDT 680.course_name: Evaluation Techniques for the Performance Technologist
LDT 680.course_description: LDT 680 - Evaluation Techniques for the Performance Technologist  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and two hours of activity.Prerequisite(s): LDT 540 . Recommended: LDT 690 .Design and use of tools to collect, analyze, and communicate data about learning and performance.Formerly numbered Educational Technology 590 and 680. Maximum Credits: 3

LDT 684.course_description: LDT 684 - Managing the Learning Design Process  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Six hours of workshop and activities.Prerequisite(s): LDT 540  and LDT 541 . Recommended: LDT 544 .Management of instructional design and performance interventions. Development of timelines, staffing plans, communication strategies, and budgets.Formerly numbered Educational Technology 684. Maximum Credits: 3

LDT 685.course_description: LDT 685 - Performance Technology for Organizations  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Six hours of workshop and activities.Prerequisite(s): LDT 540 .Organizational and informational systems that support instructional products and services. Individual, team, and organizational analyses. Incentives, feedback, coaching, job-aids, selection, knowledge management, and other performance improvement strategies.Formerly numbered Educational Technology 685. Maximum Credits: 3

LDT 690.course_description: LDT 690 - Research Methods for Learning Design  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of activity.Prerequisite(s): Admission to the master’s degree program.Planning and executing research in learning design. Analyzing, interpreting, and reporting results to stakeholders. Maximum Credits: 3

LDT 696.course_name: Advanced Topics in Learning Design and Technology
LDT 696.course_description: LDT 696 - Advanced Topics in Learning Design and Technology  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.Intensive study in specific areas of learning design and technology.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 6Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Credit for 596 and 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser.

LDT 700.course_name: Seminar in Learning Design and Technology
LDT 700.course_description: LDT 700 - Seminar in Learning Design and Technology  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): LDT 540 .Selected areas, topics in educational technology.Formerly numbered Educational Technology 700.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content.

LDT 775.course_name: Directed Internship in Learning Design and Technology
LDT 775.course_description: LDT 775 - Directed Internship in Learning Design and Technology  Units: 2-6 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Consent of staff; to be arranged with department chair.Supervised internship in an educational or training setting. Application to take course must be made during preceding semester.Formerly numbered Educational Technology 775. Maximum Credits: 6

LDT 795.course_description: LDT 795 - Advanced Seminar: Capstone Project  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Advancement to candidacy and LDT 690 .An intensive study culminating in a written project for a community-service-based learning client. Limited to students following Plan B for the Master of Arts degree. Maximum Credits: 3

LDT 798.course_description: LDT 798 - Special Study  Units: 1-6 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of staff; to be arranged with department chair and instructor.May involve fieldwork.Formerly numbered Educational Technology 798. Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.

LDT 799A.course_description: LDT 799A - Thesis or Project  Units: 3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): An officially appointed thesis committee and advancement to candidacy.Preparation of a project or thesis for the master’s degree. Maximum Credits: 3

LDT 799B.course_description: LDT 799B - Thesis or Project Extension  Units: 0 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Prior registration in Thesis or Project 799A with an assigned grade symbol of RP.Registration required in any semester or term following assignment of RP in Course 799A in which the student expects to use the facilities and resources of the university; also student must be registered in the course when the completed thesis or project is granted final approval. Maximum Credits: 0

LGBT 101.course_description: LGBT 101 - Introduction to LGBTQ+ Studies  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Diversity of LGBTQ+ communities, identities, politics, sexual and gender bodies. Intersectionality of age, class, color, embodiment, ethnicity, gender, personhood, religion, and sexuality. Maximum Credits: 3

LGBT 296.course_description: LGBT 296 - Experimental Topics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected topics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

LGBT 321.course_name: LGBT Identities in the Modern World
LGBT 321.course_description: LGBT 321 - LGBT Identities in the Modern World  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Interdisciplinary field of lesbian and gay studies with attention to social and political institutions and development of personal identity. Topics include discrimination, internalized homophobia, political activism, and diversity within lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender community. Maximum Credits: 3Note: This course satisfies the general education cultural diversity requirement.

LGBT 322.course_description: LGBT 322 - LGBT History and Culture  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: HUM 322   Interdisciplinary field of lesbian and gay studies with attention to history and artistic expression. Topics include varying attitudes toward homosexuality in history, as well as literary, artistic, theatrical, and musical contributions of the lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender community. Maximum Credits: 3Note: This course satisfies the general education cultural diversity requirement.

LGBT 333.course_description: LGBT 333 - Trans/Gender Studies  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Diversity of queer/trans identities in history and now. Trans lives and cultures to include oppression and resistance. Cis privilege and alliances. Intersections of ability, age, class, color, and sexuality with trans identities. Maximum Credits: 3

LGBT 350.course_description: LGBT 350 - Queer of Color Studies  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.LGBTQ+ identities and color. Critiques of assumed whiteness. Intersections of difference based on ability, age, class, ethnicity, gender identity, nationality, race, and sexual orientation. Forms of knowledge, lives and histories, representations, self-expression, and stereotypes. Maximum Credits: 3

LGBT 496.course_description: LGBT 496 - Experimental Topics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected topics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

LGBT 499.course_description:
LGBT 499 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Three upper division units and consent of the program adviser and instructor.
 Individual study. Maximum Credits: 6

LGBT 550.course_description: LGBT 550 - Queering Comics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division or graduate standing. Exploration of LGBTQ+ culture, ideas, aesthetics, identity, and politics through sequential art. The politics of LGBTQ+ representation in culture. Queer methods of reading comic strips, comic books, and graphic narratives. Introduces LGBTQ+ comic creators.

LGBT 596.course_name: Selected Topics in Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Transgender Studies
LGBT 596.course_description: LGBT 596 - Selected Topics in Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Transgender Studies  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division or graduate standing.Selected topics in lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender studies.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree. Credit for 596 and 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser.

LGBT 597.course_description: LGBT 597 - Research Project  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Six upper division units in lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender studies and consent of adviser.Individual research project. Maximum Credits: 3

LGBT 598.course_name: Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Transgender Studies Internship
LGBT 598.course_description: LGBT 598 - Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Transgender Studies Internship  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual Transgender, Queer, and Plus Studies major or minor.Lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender studies theories and scholarship to community service and activism. Internship includes 120 hours of work in local public and private agencies serving LGBT populations and working towards LGBT equality. Maximum Credits: 6

LGBT 798.course_description: LGBT 798 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of staff; to be arranged with adviser and instructor.Independent study. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.

LIB S 296.course_description: LIB S 296 - Experimental Topics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected topics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

LIB S 300.course_description: LIB S 300 - Introduction to Liberal Studies  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): ED 200  and preparation for the major completed or to be completed concurrently.Introduction to ideas, structures, and values within and among the various disciplines in this interdisciplinary major. Exploration of issues of diversity in contemporary society through directed field experience and required readings. Individual qualitative evaluation process required by major included. Maximum Credits: 3

LIB S 351.course_description: LIB S 351 - International Experience-Mexicali  Units: 1 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Completion of the General Education requirement in Communication and Critical Thinking I.3., Critical Thinking.International experience in Mexicali, Mexico. History and culture of region, microcredit businesses to include bee keeping, border issues, education in Baja California. Service learning project. Maximum Credits: 1

LIB S 498.course_description: LIB S 498 - Assessment in Liberal Studies  Units: 0.5-1 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Senior standing and LIB S 300 . Not open to premajors.Senior assessment including reflections upon educational experiences in each subject area and role as future educator. Students will explore differences between subject areas and reflect upon learning and teaching. Maximum Credits: 1

LIB S 499.course_description: LIB S 499 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6

LING 100A.course_name: English Composition for International Students and English Learners I
LING 100A.course_description: LING 100A - English Composition for International Students and English Learners I  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Open to international students or other students whose first language is not English and who have not satisfied the SDSU Written Communication Assessment requirement.Introduction to college-level writing for language/grammar needs of first-semester English learners. Understanding written argument, comprehension of college-level academic texts, and integrating ideas and information from multiple text sources in formal written papers. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Not open to native speakers of English.

LING 100B.course_name: English Composition for International Students and English Learners II
LING 100B.course_description: LING 100B - English Composition for International Students and English Learners II  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): LING 100A  with a grade of C- (1.7) or better.College-level writing; attention to language needs of advanced English learners. Written argument, comprehension and analysis of college-level academic texts, and use of multiple text sources for written synthesis and argument.Formerly numbered Linguistics 100. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Not open to native speakers of English. Not open to students with credit in a higher-numbered composition course or AFRAS 120  or AMIND 120  or CCS 111B  or POL S 100  or RWS 100  [or ECL 100 ] or RWS 105B .

LING 101.course_description: LING 101 - Introduction to Language  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available.
