PHIL 576.course_description: PHIL 576 - A Major Philosophical Tradition  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division or graduate standing.Focused study of a major philosophical tradition (e.g., Platonism, Confucianism, positivism).  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to the major, six units applicable to a master’s degree.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content.

PHIL 577.course_description: PHIL 577 - A Major Philosophical Problem  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division or graduate standing.Focused study of a major philosophical problem (e.g., the problem of evil, the problem of other minds, the existence of God).  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to the major, six units applicable to a master’s degree.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content.

PHIL 578.course_description: PHIL 578 - Philosophical Methods  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division or graduate standing.Focused study of major philosophical methods (e.g., uncertain inferences and non-bivalent logics, phenomenological method, deconstruction).  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to the major, six units applicable to a master’s degree.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content.

PHIL 596.course_description: PHIL 596 - Selected Topics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division or graduate standing.A critical analysis of a major problem or movement in philosophy.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: nine units of 596 applicable to the major in philosophy. Maximum Credit Statement: nine units of PHIL 596 applicable to the major in philosophy.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree. Credit for 596 and 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser.

PHIL 599.course_description: PHIL 599 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division or graduate standing. Directed individual study in philosophy on a theme or topic chosen in consultation with the instructor.  Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units, maximum combined credit six units of PHIL 599 and PHIL 798 applicable to the M.A. degree in Philosophy.

PHIL 600.course_name: Seminar in the History of Philosophy
PHIL 600.course_description: PHIL 600 - Seminar in the History of Philosophy  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in philosophy.A major philosopher, school, or problem. Their historical roots and subsequent historical significance.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 12Maximum Credit Statement: 12 units applicable to a master’s degree.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content.

PHIL 610.course_description: PHIL 610 - Seminar in Philosophical Problems: Values  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in philosophy.Problems in such fields as ethics, politics, aesthetics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 12Maximum Credit Statement: 12 units applicable to a master’s degree.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content.

PHIL 620.course_name: Seminar in Philosophical Problems: Knowledge and Reality
PHIL 620.course_description: PHIL 620 - Seminar in Philosophical Problems: Knowledge and Reality  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in philosophy.A problem or group of problems in metaphysics, epistemology and logic.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 12Maximum Credit Statement: 12 units applicable to a master’s degree.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content.

PHIL 630.course_description: PHIL 630 - Seminar in Current Philosophical Issues  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in philosophy.Problems in current philosophical publications.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 12Maximum Credit Statement: 12 units applicable to a master’s degree.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content.

PHIL 650.course_description: PHIL 650 - Seminar in Teaching Philosophy  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in philosophy.Critical thinking and writing skills to teach philosophy. Syllabus construction, teaching techniques, assessment, and outcomes measurement.Formerly numbered Philosophy 701. Maximum Credits: 3

PHIL 696.course_description: PHIL 696 - Seminar in Selected Topics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in philosophy.Intensive study in specific areas of philosophy.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 12Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Credit for 596 and 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser.

PHIL 796.course_description: PHIL 796 - Studies in Philosophy  Units: 3 Grading Method: NOG - Cr/NC (No Letter) Prerequisite(s): Advancement to candidacy; minimum GPA of 3.0 or better (which is required for candidacy). Approval of graduate adviser.Preparation for the comprehensive examination for students taking the M.A. (non-thesis option). Maximum credit three units applicable to a master’s degree. Offered Credit/No Credit only.

PHIL 798.course_description: PHIL 798 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Twelve upper division units in philosophy and consent of staff; to be arranged with department chair and instructor. Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.

PHIL 799A.course_description: PHIL 799A - Thesis  Units: 3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): An officially appointed thesis committee and advancement to candidacy.Preparation of a project or thesis for the master’s degree. Maximum Credits: 3

PHIL 799B.course_description: PHIL 799B - Thesis Extension  Units: 0 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Prior registration in Thesis 799A with an assigned grade symbol of RP.Registration required in any semester or term following assignment of RP in Course 799A in which the student expects to use the facilities and resources of the university; also student must be registered in the course when the completed thesis is granted final approval. Maximum Credits: 0

PHIL 799C.course_description: PHIL 799C - Comprehensive Examination Extension  Units: 0 Grading Method: Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Completion or concurrent enrollment in degree program courses.Registration required of students whose only requirement is completion of the comprehensive examination for the master’s degree. Registration in 799C limited to two semesters.

PHYS 180A.course_description: PHYS 180A - Fundamentals of Physics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Satisfaction of the SDSU Mathematics/Quantitative Reasoning Assessment requirement. Physics 180A is prerequisite to PHYS 180B . Recommended: Concurrent registration in Physics PHYS 182A .Mechanics, wave motion, sound, and fluids. Physics 180A not open to students with credit in Physics 195. Biological sciences majors must complete entire sequence of Physics 180A-PHYS 180B  or PHYS 195 , PHYS 196 , PHYS 197 . Maximum Credits: 3Maximum Credit Statement: 12 units for any combination of Physics 180A, PHYS 180B, PHYS 182A, PHYS 182B, PHYS 195, PHYS 195L, PHYS 196, PHYS 196L, PHYS 197, PHYS 197L.

PHYS 180B.course_description: PHYS 180B - Fundamentals of Physics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Satisfaction of the SDSU Mathematics/Quantitative Reasoning Assessment requirement. PHYS 180A  is prerequisite to 180B. Recommended: Concurrent registration in PHYS 182B .Electricity, magnetism, optics, and modern physics. Maximum Credits: 3Maximum Credit Statement: 12 units for any combination of Physics 180A, PHYS 180B, PHYS 182A, PHYS 182B, PHYS 195, PHYS 195L, PHYS 196, PHYS 196L, PHYS 197, PHYS 197L.Note: Presented in a two-semester algebra/trigonometry based sequence. Physics 180B not open to students with credit in PHYS 196 . Biological sciences majors must complete entire sequence of PHYS 180A -180B or PHYS 195 , PHYS 196 , PHYS 197 .

PHYS 182A.course_description: PHYS 182A - Physical Measurements Laboratory  Units: 1 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): Credit or concurrent registration in PHYS 180A .A laboratory course to accompany PHYS 180A -PHYS 180B . Properties of matter, mechanics, sound, and wave motion. Maximum Credits: 1Maximum Credit Statement: 12 units for any combination of Physics 180A, PHYS 180B, PHYS 182A, PHYS 182B, PHYS 195, PHYS 195L, PHYS 196, PHYS 196L, PHYS 197, PHYS 197L.Note: Not open to students with credit in PHYS 195L .

PHYS 182B.course_description: PHYS 182B - Physical Measurements Laboratory  Units: 1 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): Credit or concurrent registration in PHYS 180B .A laboratory course to accompany PHYS 180A -PHYS 180B . Electricity, DC circuits, oscilloscope measurement techniques, electric and magnetic fields, and optics. Not open to students with credit in PHYS 196L . Maximum Credits: 1Maximum Credit Statement: 12 units for any combination of Physics 180A, PHYS 180B, PHYS 182A, PHYS 182B, PHYS 195, PHYS 195L, PHYS 196, PHYS 196L, PHYS 197, PHYS 197L.

PHYS 195.course_description: PHYS 195 - Principles of Physics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): MATH 150  with a minimum grade of C (2.0) or higher.Fundamental principles of physics in areas of mechanics and oscillatory motion. Designed for students requiring calculus-based physics. Maximum Credits: 12Maximum Credit Statement: 12 units for any combination of Physics 180A, PHYS 180B, PHYS 182A, PHYS 182B, PHYS 195, PHYS 195L, PHYS 196, PHYS 196L, PHYS 197, PHYS 197L.Note: Recommended: High school physics or PHYS 180A.

PHYS 195L.course_description: PHYS 195L - Principles of Physics Laboratory  Units: 1 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): Credit or concurrent registration in PHYS 195 .Experiments in mechanics, wave motion, resonance phenomena using precision air tracks. Not open to students with credit in PHYS 182A . Maximum Credits: 1Maximum Credit Statement: 12 units for any combination of Physics 180A, PHYS 180B, PHYS 182A, PHYS 182B, PHYS 195, PHYS 195L, PHYS 196, PHYS 196L, PHYS 197, PHYS 197L.

PHYS 196.course_description: PHYS 196 - Principles of Physics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): PHYS 195  and MATH 151  with a minimum grade of C (2.0) or higher in each course.Fundamental principles of physics in areas of electricity and magnetism. Designed for students requiring calculus-based physics. Maximum Credits: 12Maximum Credit Statement: 12 units for any combination of Physics 180A, PHYS 180B, PHYS 182A, PHYS 182B, PHYS 195, PHYS 195L, PHYS 196, PHYS 196L, PHYS 197, PHYS 197L.

PHYS 196L.course_description: PHYS 196L - Principles of Physics Laboratory  Units: 1 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): Credit or concurrent registration in PHYS 196 .Experiments in DC circuits, AC circuits, electrical resonance, oscilloscope measurement techniques, and electric and magnetic fields. Not open to students with credit in PHYS 182B . Maximum Credits: 1Maximum Credit Statement: 12 units for any combination of Physics 180A, PHYS 180B, PHYS 182A, PHYS 182B, PHYS 195, PHYS 195L, PHYS 196, PHYS 196L, PHYS 197, PHYS 197L.

PHYS 197.course_description: PHYS 197 - Principles of Physics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): PHYS 196 .Fundamental principles of physics in areas of electromagnetic waves, modern physics, optics, relativity, thermodynamics, and wave motion. Designed for students requiring calculus-based physics. Maximum Credits: 3Maximum Credit Statement: 12 units for any combination of Physics 180A, PHYS 180B, PHYS 182A, PHYS 182B, PHYS 195, PHYS 195L, PHYS 196, PHYS 196L, PHYS 197, PHYS 197L.

PHYS 197L.course_description: PHYS 197L - Principles of Physics Laboratory  Units: 1 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): Credit or concurrent registration in PHYS 197 .Experiments in optics, lasers, holography, and nuclear counting. Maximum Credits: 1Maximum Credit Statement: 12 units for any combination of Physics 180A, PHYS 180B, PHYS 182A, PHYS 182B, PHYS 195, PHYS 195L, PHYS 196, PHYS 196L, PHYS 197, PHYS 197L.

PHYS 296.course_description: PHYS 296 - Experimental Topics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected topics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

PHYS 299.course_description: PHYS 299 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of department chair and instructor. Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6

PHYS 311.course_description: PHYS 311 - Electronics for Scientists  Units: 4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Three lectures and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): PHYS 180B  and PHYS 182B , or PHYS 196  and PHYS 196L .AC and DC circuits, diodes, transistors, conventional and operational amplifiers, analog to digital conversion, pulse and digital electronics. Introduce science majors to modern electronic devices and their utilization in scientific instrumentation. Maximum Credits: 4

PHYS 317.course_description: PHYS 317 - Introduction to Computational Physics  Units: 3 Grading Method: CR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  One lecture and six hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): MATH 342A  or A E 280 . Credit or concurrent registration in PHYS 197 .Numerical methods applied to a variety of physics topics. Use of computers to solve and plot problems involving differential equations, matrices, root finding, numerical integration.

PHYS 350.course_description: PHYS 350 - Classical Mechanics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): PHYS 196  and MATH 252  with a grade of C (2.0) or better in each course. Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 342A .Newtonian mechanics, gravitation, small oscillations, collisions, motion of rigid bodies, Lagrangian mechanics.

PHYS 354.course_description: PHYS 354 - Modern Physics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): PHYS 197  and MATH 252  with a grade of C (2.0) or better in each course. Credit or concurrent registration in MATH 342A .Special theory of relativity. Particle properties of electromagnetic radiation, and wave properties of particles. Introduction to quantum theory with applications to atomic structure. Maximum Credits: 3

PHYS 357.course_description: PHYS 357 - Advanced Physical Measurements  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  One lecture and six hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): PHYS 197L , PHYS 311 , and PHYS 354. Stresses both laboratory experiments and techniques of data and error analysis. Experiments are taken from major areas of physics.

PHYS 360.course_description: PHYS 360 - Thermal Physics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): PHYS 350 , MATH 342A , PHYS 354  or CHEM 410A .Classical thermodynamics and statistical mechanics. Applications of equilibrium thermodynamics. Statistical mechanics, including concepts from probability and statistics. Maxwell-Boltzmann, Fermi-Dirac, and Bose-Einstein statistics. Applications of statistical mechanics in calculating macroscopic properties of simple systems. Maximum Credits: 3

PHYS 400A.course_description: PHYS 400A - Classical Electromagnetism  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): PHYS 196  with a minimum grade of C; PHYS 197  and MATH 342A .Electrostatics, magnetostatics, electromagnetic induction, Maxwell’s equations, radiation and wave propagation. Maximum Credits: 3

PHYS 400B.course_description: PHYS 400B - Classical Electromagnetism  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): PHYS 400A .Electrostatics, magnetostatics, electromagnetic induction, Maxwell’s equations, radiation and wave propagation. Maximum Credits: 3

PHYS 406.course_description: PHYS 406 - Optics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): PHYS 197 , PHYS 197L , MATH 342B .Reflection, refraction, matrix methods, dispersion, polarization, double refraction, interference, diffraction, Fourier optics, coherence theory, lasers, and holography with applications to optical instruments, wave propagation, and the nature of light. Maximum Credits: 3

PHYS 410.course_description: PHYS 410 - Quantum Mechanics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): PHYS 350 , MATH 342B , PHYS 354  or CHEM 410A .Mathematical and physical foundations of quantum theory in terms of wave and matrix mechanics. Applications to properties of atoms and solids. Maximum Credits: 3

PHYS 412.course_description: PHYS 412 - Processes and Inquiry in Physics  Units: 4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Three lectures and two hours of activity.Prerequisite(s): Completion of the General Education requirement in Foundations of Learning II.A., Natural Sciences and Quantitative Reasoning.Investigation of processes of inquiry and rational thinking skills characteristic of physics, focusing on energy transformations, heat transfer and thermodynamics, force and motion, electricity and magnetism, and waves. Maximum Credits: 4

PHYS 496.course_description: PHYS 496 - Selected Topics in Physics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.Selected topics in classical and modern physics.  May be repeated with consent of instructor. Maximum Credits: 6Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

PHYS 498A.course_description: PHYS 498A - Senior Research  Units: 1 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit  One discussion period and two additional hours per week to be arranged.Prerequisite(s): PHYS 357  and consent of instructor.Selection and design of individual research project. Oral and written progress reports. Maximum Credits: 1

PHYS 498B.course_description: PHYS 498B - Senior Research  Units: 2 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Two discussion periods and four additional hours per week to be arranged.Prerequisite(s): PHYS 498A .Laboratory work, progress reports, oral and written final reports. Maximum Credits: 2

PHYS 499.course_description: PHYS 499 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Individual study or laboratory work on a special problem in physics selected by the student. Each student will be assigned a member of the staff who will supervise his/her work. Maximum Credits: 6Note: Credit, hours and topics to be arranged in each case.

PHYS 532.course_description: PHYS 532 - Condensed Matter Physics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): PHYS 410  with a grade of C (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.Elastic, electric, magnetic, optical, and thermal properties of solids. Energy band theory of solids and practical application with metals and semiconductors. Maximum Credits: 3

PHYS 538.course_description: PHYS 538 - Polymer Science  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: CHEM 538  Prerequisite(s): CHEM 200  or CHEM 202 ; and credit or concurrent registration in CHEM 410B  or PHYS 360  or M E 350 .Structure, synthesis, physical properties, and utilities of polymers and biopolymers. Maximum Credits: 3

PHYS 552.course_description: PHYS 552 - Modern Optics and Lasers  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): PHYS 406  with minimum grade of C; credit or concurrent registration in PHYS 400B .Electromagnetic theory, matrix methods of optics, propagation of Gaussian beams, optical resonators, interaction of radiation and atomic systems, theory of laser oscillation, nonlinear optics, specific laser systems, optical detectors, applications of lasers in physics. Maximum Credits: 3

PHYS 553.course_description: PHYS 553 - Modern Optics Laboratory  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  One lecture and six hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): PHYS 357  with minimum grade of C; PHYS 406  with minimum grade of C; credit or concurrent registration in PHYS 552 .Experiments in various fields of modern optics such as holography, physics of lasers, Fourier transform spectroscopy, Raman spectroscopy, light modulation techniques, fiber optics, spatial filtering, diffraction grating spectroscopy, radiometry, and nonlinear optics. Maximum Credits: 3

PHYS 560.course_description: PHYS 560 - Radiological Physics and Dosimetry  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Credit or concurrent registration in PHYS 354 .Ionizing radiation fields, interactions of radiation with matter, cavity theory, external radiation dosimetry. Maximum Credits: 3

PHYS 564.course_description: PHYS 564 - Nuclear Physics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): MATH 342A  and PHYS 354  with a grade of C (2.0) or better in each course.Nuclear and elementary particle phenomena including nuclear structure, decay, and radioactivity. Nuclear reactions and devices. Experimental methods and applications.

PHYS 565.course_description: PHYS 565 - Radiobiology and Radiation Safety  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Credit or concurrent registration in PHYS 560  and consent of instructor.Effects of ionizing radiation on physical and biological systems in medical imaging and radiation therapy. Associated radiation safety precautions. Maximum Credits: 6

PHYS 567.course_description: PHYS 567 - Nuclear Medicine Physics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): PHYS 560 .Physical principles of nuclear medicine and operating principles of nuclear medicine instrumentation. Radionuclide production, dose calibrators, well counters, gamma cameras, SPECT, PET, image quality, tomographic reconstruction, and image processing. Maximum Credits: 6

PHYS 570.course_description: PHYS 570 - Relativity  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): PHYS 350 and PHYS 354 . Credit or concurrent registration in PHYS 400A  and PHYS 410 .Relative coordinates, Lorentz transformation, covariant formation of the laws of physics, applications of special relativity, introduction to curved space time, cosmology.

PHYS 580.course_description: PHYS 580 - Computational Physics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): PHYS 354 ; COMPE 160 ; and credit or concurrent registration in PHYS 400A .Computer programming for numerical solution of problems in classical mechanics, electromagnetism, optics, and quantum mechanics. Use of Fortran and C programming languages and the UNIX operating system. Incorporation of standard subroutines for linear algebra and differential equations into student written programs. Maximum Credits: 3

PHYS 596.course_description: PHYS 596 - Special Topics in Physics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.Selected topics in classical and modern physics.  May be repeated with the consent of the instructor. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units of 596 applicable to a bachelor’s degree Credit for 596 and 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

PSY 622.course_description: PSY 622 - Seminar in Organizational Psychology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): PSY 421  and consent of master’s program adviser.Applications of psychological principles and methods of investigation to problems of industrial relations and motivation of employees; factors influencing morale and employee productivity; criteria of job proficiency; psychological aspects of worker-management relationships and leadership. Maximum Credits: 3

PSY 630.course_name: Seminar in Organizational Research and Ethics
PSY 630.course_description: PSY 630 - Seminar in Organizational Research and Ethics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in psychology.Design of field research, quasi-experimental, and non-experimental techniques to address applied psychology questions in organizational settings. Consideration of ethical and professional issues related to organizational research. Selected topic areas within applied psychology include multi-level research, survey research, or program evaluation.

PSY 632.course_name: Theories and Methods in Developmental Science
PSY 632.course_description: PSY 632 - Theories and Methods in Developmental Science  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): PSY 331  or PSY 332 .Philosophical and biological origins of developmental psychology. Examination of processes that shape perception, language acquisition, socialization, and cognition. Maximum Credits: 3

PSY 670A.course_description: PSY 670A - Advanced Statistics in Psychology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and two hours of activity.Prerequisite(s): PSY 370 , PSY 410 , and consent of master’s program adviser.Fundamentals of multiple regression and correlation. Principles of experimental design. Analysis of variance including factorial and repeated-measures designs and a priori and post hoc comparisons including trend analysis. Computer-based statistical packages in the analysis of data from psychological research.

PSY 670B.course_description: PSY 670B - Advanced Statistics in Psychology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and two hours of activity.Prerequisite(s): PSY 370 , PSY 410 , and consent of master’s program adviser.Fundamentals of multiple regression and correlation. Principles of experimental design. Analysis of variance including factorial and repeated-measures designs and a priori and post hoc comparisons including trend analysis. Computer-based statistical packages in the analysis of data from psychological research.

PSY 675.course_description: PSY 675 - Seminar in Psychological Measurement  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): PSY 370  and consent of master’s program adviser.General principles, theory and methods underlying measurement in studies of group and individual differences in controlled experiments. Maximum Credits: 3

PSY 696.course_description: PSY 696 - Selected Topics in Psychology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.Intensive study in specific areas of psychology.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 12Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Credit for 596 and 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser.

PSY 721.course_description: PSY 721 - Advanced Seminar in Personnel Psychology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): PSY 621  and consent of master’s program adviser.Selected areas within personnel psychology including selection, classification, performance appraisal, test development, criterion development, measurement and scaling techniques.  Course may be repeated with new content with permission of instructor and master’s program adviser. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.

PSY 722.course_description: PSY 722 - Advanced Seminar in Organizational Psychology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): PSY 622  and consent of master’s program adviser.Selected areas within organizational psychology including leadership, motivation, organizational development, and organizational effectiveness.  Course may be repeated with new content with permission of instructor and master’s program adviser. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.

PSY 740.course_description: PSY 740 - Seminar in Social Psychology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Undergraduate course in social psychology and graduate level status.Classic and contemporary issues in social psychology including social influence, person perception, attitudes and attitude change, group dynamics, intergroup conflict, and cultural influence. Maximum Credits: 3

PSY 751.course_name: Clinical Psychological Science: Theory and Methods
PSY 751.course_description: PSY 751 - Clinical Psychological Science: Theory and Methods  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in psychology and PSY 350 .Methodological and theoretical foundations in clinical psychological science. Dissemination/implementation, nosology, and professional issues in clinical psychology. Maximum Credits: 3

PSY 760.course_name: Seminar in Physiological Correlates of Behavior
PSY 760.course_description: PSY 760 - Seminar in Physiological Correlates of Behavior  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): PSY 260  or six units of biology; and consent of master’s program adviser.  Course may be repeated provided it is offered by a different instructor and the subject matter is substantially different. To enroll in the seminar for the second time, the student must submit a petition to be approved by the professor of the course and the master’s program adviser. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.

PSY 767.course_name: Seminar in Cognitive and Behavioral Neuroscience
PSY 767.course_description: PSY 767 - Seminar in Cognitive and Behavioral Neuroscience  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor for programs outside of psychology master of arts and doctoral program.Issues of contemporary importance in neuroscience.  Course may be repeated provided it is offered by a different instructor and the subject matter is substantially different. To enroll in the seminar for the second time, the student must submit a petition to be approved by the professor and the master’s program adviser. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content.

PSY 768.course_description: PSY 768 - Advanced Systems Neuroscience  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and two hours of activity.Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor for programs outside of Master of Arts degree in psychology and doctoral program in clinical psychology.Neuroanatomy and neurophysiology of the mammalian through a signals and systems lens to include auditory, cell physiology, motor and limbic systems, neural development, simple neural models, somatosensory, and visual components. Neuroimaging physics. Maximum Credits: 3

PSY 769.course_description: PSY 769 - Advanced Foundations of Neuroimaging  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and two hours of activity.Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor for programs outside of Master of Arts degree in psychology and doctoral program in clinical psychology.Physical and mathematical foundations of diffusion, functional, structural, perfusion MRI, and fMRI time series analysis. Cortical- surface based reconstruction and data analysis. Neural basis, localization, and recording of EEG and MEG signals. Maximum Credits: 3

PSY 770A.course_name: Experimental Design and Data Analysis in Behavioral Research
PSY 770A.course_description: PSY 770A - Experimental Design and Data Analysis in Behavioral Research  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and two hours of activity.Prerequisite(s): PSY 370 , PSY 410 , a passing score on the departmental statistics placement test, and consent of master’s program adviser.Principles and methods of behavioral research stressing interdependence of experimental design and statistical evaluation of results. General linear model in its regression and ANOVA formulations. Advanced multiple regression and correlation techniques using computer-based statistical packages. Maximum Credits: 3

PSY 770B.course_name: Experimental Design and Data Analysis in Behavioral Research
PSY 770B.course_description: PSY 770B - Experimental Design and Data Analysis in Behavioral Research  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and two hours of activity.Prerequisite(s): PSY 370 , PSY 410 , a passing score on the departmental statistics placement test, and consent of master’s program adviser.Principles and methods of behavioral research stressing interdependence of experimental design and statistical evaluation of results. General linear model in its regression and ANOVA formulations. Advanced multiple regression and correlation techniques using computer-based statistical packages. Maximum Credits: 3

PSY 775.course_description: PSY 775 - Multivariate Statistics in Psychology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and two hours of activity.Prerequisite(s): PSY 670A -PSY 670B  or PSY 770A -PSY 770B  and consent of instructor.Introduction to multivariate techniques. Latent structure models with attention to relationship between latent constructs and observable data. Includes causal models, factor analysis (both exploratory and confirmatory), canonical correlation, path analysis, discriminant function analysis, and loglinear analysis. Maximum Credits: 3

PSY 776.course_description: PSY 776 - Multilevel Modeling for Psychological Research  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): PSY 670A  and PSY 670B  or PSY 770A  and PSY 770B  with a grade of C (2.0) or better in each course.Statistical analysis of nested or hierarchical data generated by cross-sectional and longitudinal designs common to psychological science. Examine, critique, and discuss methodological articles regarding multilevel modeling. Maximum Credits: 3

PSY 787.course_description: PSY 787 - Seminar in Cognitive Psychology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in psychology.Empirical data, methods, principles, and theories in cognitive psychology.Formerly numbered Psychology 587. Maximum Credits: 3

PSY 790.course_name: Practicum in the Teaching of Psychology
PSY 790.course_description: PSY 790 - Practicum in the Teaching of Psychology  Units: 1 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Award of a graduate teaching associateship in psychology.Supervision in the teaching of psychology, covering lecture writing, style of lecture presentation, in-class demonstration and exercise, test and syllabi construction, and grading system. Not applicable to an advanced degree. Maximum Credits: 1

PSY 792.course_description: PSY 792 - Internship in Applied Psychology  Units: 3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC  Up to 20 hours of supervised work per week in a program approved internship setting.Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor and master’s program adviser based on good standing in the Psychology, Applied Psychology, Industrial and Organizational Specialization, M.S.Supervised training in applied psychology in a program approved internship setting. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: Six units with consent of instructor.

PSY 796.course_description: PSY 796 - Selected Topics in Psychology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Advanced master’s and doctoral standing in psychology.Intensive study in specific areas of psychology. In-depth investigation of controversial issues in the field as well as introduction to current and emerging technologies. Cognition, cognitive neuroimaging, and social perception. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units of 696 and 796 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of graduate adviser.

PSY 797.course_description: PSY 797 - Research  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of master’s program adviser.Research in one of the fields of psychology. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units of PSY 797 and PSY 798 applicable to a master’s degree.

PSY 798.course_description: PSY 798 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of master’s program adviser.Individual projects involving library or laboratory research in any area of psychological investigation or interest. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units of PSY 797 and PSY 798 applicable to a master’s degree.

PSY 799A.course_description: PSY 799A - Thesis  Units: 3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): An officially appointed thesis committee and advancement to candidacy.Preparation of a project or thesis for the master’s degree. Credit is contingent upon acceptance of the completed thesis by the Department of Psychology. Maximum Credits: 3

PSY 799B.course_description: PSY 799B - Thesis Extension  Units: 0 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Prior registration in Thesis 799A with an assigned grade symbol of RP.Registration required in any semester or term following assignment of RP in Course 799A in which the student expects to use the facilities and resources of the university; also student must be registered in the course when the completed thesis is granted final approval. Maximum Credits: 0

PSY 801.course_name: Seminar in History and Ethics in Psychology
PSY 801.course_description: PSY 801 - Seminar in History and Ethics in Psychology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to doctoral program in clinical psychology.Historical background of modern psychology; in-depth examination of the American Psychological Association code of ethics and its application to the conduct of clinical psychologists. Maximum Credits: 3

PSY 820.course_description: PSY 820 - Seminar in Cultural Psychology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to doctoral program in clinical psychology.Cultural origins of human behavior; cultural limits of psychological knowledge. Maximum Credits: 3

PSY 833.course_description: PSY 833 - Seminar in Developmental Psychopathology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to doctoral program in clinical psychology.Research and theory in biological and social origins of psychopathology. Methods of assessing developmental change and stability, issues related to vulnerability and resiliency, developmental appropriateness of approaches to interventions, and role of culture as a developmental context. Maximum Credits: 3

PSY 840.course_name: Seminar in Personality and Social Psychology
PSY 840.course_description: PSY 840 - Seminar in Personality and Social Psychology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to doctoral program in clinical psychology.Research and theory in personality and social psychology. Theories of personality and individual differences, group processes, sex roles, social perception, and cross-cultural issues. Maximum Credits: 3

PSY 842.course_description: PSY 842 - Behavioral Medicine Seminar: Assessment  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to doctoral program or approval by instructor and program director.Assessment methods and issues in behavioral medicine. Development and implementation of assessment plans. Theoretical and practical aspects of psychological, behavioral, and physiological assessment methods for various health issues. Maximum Credits: 3

PSY 843.course_description: PSY 843 - Behavioral Medicine Seminar: Intervention  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to doctoral program and PSY 842 .Design and implement interventions by stressing empirically supported approaches to improve health and change health behaviors. Strengths and weaknesses of clinical community interventions. Maximum Credits: 3

PSY 849.course_name: Seminar and Laboratory in Counseling and Psychotherapy
PSY 849.course_description: PSY 849 - Seminar and Laboratory in Counseling and Psychotherapy  Units: 4 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and six hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): Consent of graduate adviser.Supervised practice in application of psychotherapeutic and counseling techniques from selected cognitive, dynamic, interpersonal, and behavioral approaches. Open only to students accepted in the doctoral program. Maximum Credits: 4

PSY 850.course_name: Seminar in Theory and Practice in Clinical Interventions
PSY 850.course_description: PSY 850 - Seminar in Theory and Practice in Clinical Interventions  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to doctoral program in clinical psychology.Theory and application of clinical interventions, advanced study of interviewing techniques, behavioral interventions, cognitive/ behavioral interventions, and family/child interventions. Maximum Credits: 3

PSY 852.course_description: PSY 852 - Seminar in Experimental Psychopathology Research  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to doctoral program in clinical psychology.Analysis of experimental and theoretical literature as it pertains to research methodology for the study of disordered behavior. Maximum Credits: 3

PSY 855.course_description: PSY 855 - Seminar in Psychological Assessment I  Units: 4 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and six hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): PSY 350 , PSY 370 , and consent of graduate adviser.Theory and practice in assessment of intelligence and special abilities. Open only to students accepted in the doctoral program. Maximum Credits: 4

PSY 856.course_description: PSY 856 - Seminar in Psychological Assessment II  Units: 4 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and six hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): PSY 855  and consent of graduate adviser.Theory and practice in assessment of special abilities, personality and behavior disorders. Open only to students accepted in the doctoral program. Maximum Credits: 4

PSY 860.course_name: Seminar in Physiological Foundations of Behavior
PSY 860.course_description: PSY 860 - Seminar in Physiological Foundations of Behavior  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to doctoral program in clinical psychology.Research and theory in physiological psychology. Advanced study of biological rhythms, sleep and waking, stress responses, the neurophysiology of learning and memory, and research methods in physiological psychology. Maximum Credits: 3

PSY 875.course_description: PSY 875 - Advanced Multivariate Statistics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and two hours of activity.Prerequisite(s): Admission to the doctoral program in clinical psychology, PSY 770A -PSY 770B , and consent of instructor.Use of multivariate techniques. Relationship between latent constructs and observable data. Analyses such as causal models, exploratory and confirmatory factor analysis, canonical correlation, path analysis, discriminant function analysis, loglinear analysis, and hierarchical linear modeling using computer-based statistical packages. Maximum Credits: 3

PSY 887.course_name: Seminar in Cognition, Affect, and Cognitive-Affective Interactions
PSY 887.course_description: PSY 887 - Seminar in Cognition, Affect, and Cognitive-Affective Interactions  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to doctoral program in clinical psychology.Research and theory pertaining to interactions among affective and cognitive processes. Maximum Credits: 3

PSY 894.course_description: PSY 894 - Clinical Internship  Units: 3-15 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Completion of coursework, second year project, and advancement to candidacy.Clinical training in an APA-approved internship setting. Maximum Credits: 15

PSY 895.course_name: Practicum in the Teaching of Psychology
PSY 895.course_description: PSY 895 - Practicum in the Teaching of Psychology  Units: 1-6 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Admission to doctoral program in clinical psychology.Supervision in the teaching of psychology, covering lecture writing, style of lecture presentation, in-class demonstration and exercises, test and syllabi construction, and grading systems. Maximum Credits: 6

PSY 896.course_description: PSY 896 - Clinical Practicum  Units: 1-15 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to the doctoral program.Supervision of advanced intervention strategies applied to clinical populations. Maximum Credits: 15

PSY 897.course_description: PSY 897 - Doctoral Research  Units: 1-15 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to the doctoral program.Independent investigation in the general field of the dissertation. Maximum Credits: 15

PSY 898.course_description: PSY 898 - Doctoral Special Study  Units: 1-8 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to the doctoral program. Individual study in the field of specialization.  Maximum Credits: 8Maximum Credit Statement: eight units applicable to the doctoral degree.

PSY 899.course_description: PSY 899 - Doctoral Dissertation  Units: 1-15 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): An officially constituted dissertation committee and advancement to candidacy.Preparation of the dissertation for the doctoral degree. Enrollment is required during the term in which the dissertation is approved.

P A 200.course_description: P A 200 - The Urban Scene  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Key issues in public administration, social policy, and city planning. Emphasis on government structure and public decision-making process, organizational behavior, effectiveness of criminal justice policies, zoning, and land use considerations. Maximum Credits: 3

P A 301.course_name: Concepts and Issues in Public Administration
P A 301.course_description: P A 301 - Concepts and Issues in Public Administration  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC - Letter (Cr/NC OK) Prerequisite(s): Sophomore, junior or senior standing; upper division major status; only open to Criminal Justice, Economics, Geography, History, Interdisciplinary Studies in Three Departments; Social Work, Political Science, Public Administration, Sociology, and Urban Studies majors.Theory and practice of governmental administration in differing environments, role of administrators in public policy, issues facing administrators, techniques of administration.

P A 310.course_description: P A 310 - Management of Urban Governments  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC - Letter (Cr/NC OK) Prerequisite(s): Sophomore, junior or senior standing; upper division major status; only open to Criminal Justice, Geography, Economics, History, Social Work, Political Science, Public Administration, Sociology, and Urban Studies majors.Problems of local units of government in the urban environment. Organization and function of local agencies. Emphasis on California.

P A 312.course_description: P A 312 - Management of State Governments  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC - Letter (Cr/NC OK) Prerequisite(s): Sophomore, junior or senior standing; upper division major status; only open to Criminal Justice, Geography, Economics, History, Social Work, Political Science, Public Administration, Sociology, and Urban Studies majors.Administrative and constitutional problems of state management in the American federal system. Emphasis on California.

P A 315.course_description: P A 315 - Management of the Federal Government  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC - Letter (Cr/NC OK) Prerequisite(s): Sophomore, junior or senior standing; upper division major status; only open to Criminal Justice,Geography, Economics, History, Social Work, Political Science, Public Administration, Sociology, and Urban Studies majors.Problems in the administration of the federal government. Leadership, specialization, unity of command, and oversight.

P A 320.course_description: P A 320 - Introduction to Urban Planning  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC - Letter (Cr/NC OK) Prerequisite(s): Sophomore, junior or senior standing; upper division major status; only open to Criminal Justice, Geography, Geological Sciences; Economics, History, Social Work, Political Science, Public Administration, Sociology, and Urban Studies majors.Introduction to community planning: regional, county, and city. Consideration of master plan including its purposes, contents, and method of adoption.

P A 321.course_description: P A 321 - Foundations of Urban Leadership  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Key underpinnings and critical concepts associated with urban leadership. Maximum Credits: 3

P A 322.course_description: P A 322 - Personal Dimensions of Urban Leadership  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P A 321 .Characteristics and traits of effective leaders. Research and application to personal and professional contexts. Maximum Credits: 3

P A 323.course_description: P A 323 - Community Dimensions of Urban Leadership  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P A 322 .Alternative leadership styles to deliver change and positive reform in urban communities. Maximum Credits: 3

P A 324.course_description: P A 324 - Leadership and the Public Sector  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P A 323  Leadership concepts, theories, and practices with a focus on the public sector. Topics include building trust, ethics, human relations, law, organizational dynamics, and politics. Maximum Credits: 3

P A 325.course_description: P A 325 - Nonprofit Organizations and Government  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P A 324  Comprehensive review of nonprofit organizations. Topics include activism, effects of nonprofit influence, and policy advocacy; partnerships with government in contracting, policymaking, and public service provision. Maximum Credits: 3

P A 330.course_description: P A 330 - Public Personnel Administration  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC - Letter (Cr/NC OK) Prerequisite(s): Sophomore, junior or senior standing; upper division major status; only open to Criminal Justice, Geography, Economics, History, Social Work, Political Science, Public Administration, Sociology, and Urban Studies majors.Analysis of personnel problems. Supervision and management of public employees and public organizations in an age of change.

P A 340.course_description: P A 340 - Administrative Behavior  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC - Letter (Cr/NC OK) Prerequisite(s): Sophomore, junior or senior standing; upper division major status; only open to Criminal Justice, Geography, Economics, Health Communication, History, Social Work, Political Science, Public Administration, Sociology, and Urban Studies majors.Social, psychological, and behavioral theories of organization; concepts of administrative leadership; organization and the individual; emphasis on governmental organizations. Note: Not open to students with credit in PSY 421 .

P A 341.course_description: P A 341 - Administrative Management  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Areas and problems of administrative research. Management and operations in public organizations including forecasting, resource allocation, planning and administration of programs, preparation of administrative reports. Quantitative models of managerial decision making. Maximum Credits: 3

P A 350.course_description: P A 350 - Contemporary Urban Issues  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC - Letter (Cr/NC OK) Prerequisite(s): Sophomore, junior or senior standing; upper division major status; only open to Criminal Justice, Geography, Economics, History, Social Work, Political Science, Public Administration, Recreation Administration, Sociology, and Urban Studies majors.Focus on urban areas and urbanism from a public policy perspective; course examines and critiques the physical, economic, social and political dimensions of contemporary American cities utilizing a multidisciplinary approach.

P A 420.course_name: Methods of Analysis in City Planning
P A 420.course_description:
P A 420 - Methods of Analysis in City Planning  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC - Letter (Cr/NC OK) Prerequisite(s): P A 320 ; sophomore, junior or senior standing; upper division major status; only open to Criminal Justice, Geography, Economics, History, Social Work, Political Science, Public Administration, Sociology, and Urban Studies majors.
 Methods of primary data collection and analysis of secondary data sources for problem solving in city planning, techniques associated with urban design and urban development.

P A 440.course_name: Microcomputer Applications in Criminal Justice and Public Administration
P A 440.course_description: P A 440 - Microcomputer Applications in Criminal Justice and Public Administration  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC - Letter (Cr/NC OK)  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): Sophomore, junior or senior standing; upper division major status; only open to Criminal Justice and Public Administration majors.Operation and use of microcomputer hardware and software in criminal justice. Laboratory instruction focuses on applicability of programs to criminal justice operations.

P A 450.course_description: P A 450 - Fiscal and Budgetary Policy  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC - Letter (Cr/NC OK) Prerequisite(s): P A 301 ; sophomore, junior or senior standing; upper division major status; only open to Criminal Justice, Geography, Economics, History, Social Work, Political Science, Public Administration, Sociology, and Urban Studies majors.Policies of fiscal administration and budgeting; political implications of the governmental budget process; revenue, debt, and treasury management; the functions of accounting and financial reporting.

P A 460.course_description: P A 460 - Administration and Public Policy Development  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC - Letter (Cr/NC OK) Prerequisite(s): Sophomore, junior or senior standing; upper division major status; only open to Criminal Justice, Geography, Economics, History, Social Work, Political Science, Public Administration, Sociology, and Urban Studies majors.Process of formulating public policy with emphasis on the role of public agencies.

P A 480.course_description: P A 480 - Leadership and Public Sector  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC - Letter (Cr/NC OK) Prerequisite(s): P A 301 ; sophomore, junior or senior standing; upper division major status; only open to Criminal Justice, Geography, Economics, History, Social Work, Political Science, Public Administration, Sociology, and Urban Studies majors.Leaders as energizing forces for public administration. Analysis of leadership theories and case studies.

P A 485.course_name: Planning and Public Policy in U.S.-Mexico Border Region
P A 485.course_description: P A 485 - Planning and Public Policy in U.S.-Mexico Border Region  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC - Letter (Cr/NC OK) Prerequisite(s): P A 301 ; sophomore, junior or senior standing; upper division major status; only open to Criminal Justice, Geography, Geological Sciences, Economics, History, Social Work, Political Science, Public Administration, Sociology, and Urban Studies majors.City planning, regional, and public policy issues in the binational Mexico-U.S. border region. Policy analysis: macro/regional and micro/urban.

P A 496.course_description: P A 496 - Experimental Topics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Selected topics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

P A 497.course_description: P A 497 - Investigation and Report  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC - Letter (Cr/NC OK) Prerequisite(s): P A 301 ; senior standing; upper division major status; only open to Public Administration majors and minors; GWAR completion.Analysis of special topics.

P A 498.course_description: P A 498 - Internship in Public Administration  Units: 2-6 Grading Method: NOG - Cr/NC (No Letter) Prerequisite(s): P A 301 , P A 330 , P A 340 , P A 450 ; senior standing; upper division major status; 3.0 or higher Major GPA; and instructor approval.Students will be assigned to various government agencies and will work under joint supervision of agency heads and the course instructor. Participation in staff and internship conferences.  May be repeated with instructor approval.  Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: Six units with consent of instructor.

P A 499.course_description: P A 499 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Twelve upper division units in public administration. Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6

P A 501.course_description: P A 501 - Nonprofit Organizations and Government  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC - Letter (Cr/NC OK) Prerequisite(s): P A 301  and P A 460 ; sophomore, junior or senior standing; upper division major status; only open to City Planning, Criminal Justice and Criminology, Geography, Economics, History, Social Work, Political Science, Public Administration, Sociology, and Urban Studies majors; or graduate standing in lieu of P A 301 and P A 460.How nonprofit organizations interact with government institutions, influence and pressure government through policy advocacy and activism, and partner with government in contracting, public service provision, and policymaking.

P A 520.course_name: Decision Making in the Urban Community
P A 520.course_description: P A 520 - Decision Making in the Urban Community  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC - Letter (Cr/NC OK) Prerequisite(s): P A 301  and P A 310 ; sophomore, junior, senior or graduate standing; upper division major status; only open to City Planning, Criminal Justice and Criminology, Geography, Economics, History, Social Work, Political Science, Public Administration, Sociology, and Urban Studies majors. Graduate standing in lieu of P A 301 and P A 310.Processes of decision making in the management of urban communities.

P A 525.course_description: P A 525 - The U.S. City Planning Process  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC - Letter (Cr/NC OK) Prerequisite(s): P A 301  and P A 320 ; sophomore, junior, senior or graduate standing; upper division major status; only open to City Planning, Criminal Justice and Criminology, Geography, Economics, History, Social Work, Political Science, Public Administration, Sociology, and Urban Studies majors. Graduate standing in lieu of P A 301 and P A 320.Description and critique of traditional city planning process; styles and roles of city planner; city planning values and ethics.

P A 530.course_name: Negotiation and Bargaining in the Public Service
P A 530.course_description: P A 530 - Negotiation and Bargaining in the Public Service  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC - Letter (Cr/NC OK) Prerequisite(s): P A 301 ; sophomore, junior, senior or graduate standing; upper division major status; only open to City Planning, Criminal Justice and Criminology, Geography, Economics, History, Social Work, Political Science, Public Administration, Sociology, and Urban Studies majors. Graduate standing in lieu of P A 301.Specific issues such as strategies, the effects of threat, the physical setting, use of a third-party observer and theories of advocacy. Emphasis on analyzing simulations of the bargaining process and developing effective negotiation skills.

P A 531.course_description: P A 531 - Governmental Employer-Employee Relations  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC - Letter (Cr/NC OK) Prerequisite(s): P A 301  and P A 330 ; sophomore, junior, senior or graduate standing; upper division major status; only open to City Planning, Criminal Justice and Criminology, Geography, Economics, History, Social Work, Political Science, Public Administration, Sociology, and Urban Studies majors. Graduate standing in lieu of P A 301 and P A 330.Historical development, legal basis, and organizational implications of governmental employer-employee relations; emphasis on California local government.

P A 540.course_description: P A 540 - Community Mapping: Geographic Information Systems  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC - Letter (Cr/NC OK) Prerequisite(s): P A 301  with a grade of C (2.0) or better; sophomore, junior, senior or graduate standing; upper division major status; only open to City Planning, Criminal Justice and Criminology, Geography, Economics, History, Social Work, Political Science, Public Administration, Sociology, and Urban Studies majors. Graduate standing in lieu of P A 301.GIS principles for purposes of community mapping and relevant policy decision-making.

P A 570.course_description: P A 570 - Public Sector Professional Skills  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division or graduate standing.Skills development in preparation for a career in the public sector. Listening, reading, and thinking critically; speaking and writing with clarity; delivering convincing and organized oral presentations; leading teams; developing team management skills; and engaging the public. Maximum Credits: 3

P A 571.course_description: P A 571 - Managing Water and Energy Resources  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P A 301 .Management and economics of water and energy resources, delivery systems, regulatory framework, and renewable resources. Contemporary water and energy management issues.

P A 580.course_description: P A 580 - Comparative Public Administration  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC - Letter (Cr/NC OK) Prerequisite(s): P A 301 ; sophomore, junior, senior or graduate standing; upper division major status; only open to City Planning, Criminal Justice and Criminology, Geography, Economics, History, Social Work, Political Science, Public Administration, Sociology, and Urban Studies majors; graduate standing in lieu of P A 301.Administrative organization and process of selected foreign and American governments. Analysis of the cultural basis of administrative systems.

P A 581.course_name: War, the State, and Governance: Global Perspectives
P A 581.course_description: P A 581 - War, the State, and Governance: Global Perspectives  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNO - Letter (No Cr/NC) Prerequisite(s): P A 301  with a grade of C (2. 0) or higher; sophomore, junior, senior or graduate standing; upper division major status; only open to City Planning, Criminal Justice and Criminology, Geography, Economics, History, Homeland Security, International Security and Conflict Resolution, Political Science, Public Administration, Social Work, Sociology, and Urban Studies majors; graduate standing in lieu of P A 301.Defense and security challenges through global perspectives. Budgetary, intelligence, leadership, logistical, military, organizational, policy, political, and strategic challenges and opportunities confronted by government via case studies.

P A 582.course_name: War, the State, and Governance: U.S. Perspectives
P A 582.course_description: P A 582 - War, the State, and Governance: U.S. Perspectives  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNO - Letter (No Cr/NC) Prerequisite(s): P A 301  with a grade of C (2. 0) or higher; sophomore, junior, senior or graduate standing; upper division major status; only open to City Planning, Criminal Justice and Criminology, Geography, Economics, History, Homeland Security, International Security and Conflict Resolution, Political Science, Public Administration, Social Work, Sociology, and Urban Studies majors. Graduate standing in lieu of P A 301.Defense and security challenges through U.S. perspectives. Budgetary, intelligence, leadership, logistical, military, organizational, policy, political, and strategic factors confronted by government via case studies.

P A 596.course_description: P A 596 - Experimental Topics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected current topics in public administration.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units of 596 applicable to a bachelor’s degree Credit for 596 and 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

P A 600.course_description: P A 600 - Scope of Public Administration  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC The development of public administration as an academic discipline; a systematic evaluation of the rise and operations of largescale public bureaucracies. Maximum Credits: 3

P A 604.course_name: Methods of Analysis in Public and Urban Affairs
P A 604.course_description: P A 604 - Methods of Analysis in Public and Urban Affairs  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Credit or concurrent registration in P A 600 .Research design for problems and cases in public affairs; summarizing and organizing data; methods of projection; sampling theory and application; using census and other secondary data sources. Maximum Credits: 3

P A 605.course_description: P A 605 - Seminar in Applied Research  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P A 604  Qualitative and quantitative research designs to address public affairs issues. Maximum Credits: 3

P A 606.course_name: Seminar in Quantitative Approaches to Public Administration
P A 606.course_description: P A 606 - Seminar in Quantitative Approaches to Public Administration  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P A 604 .Advanced techniques for analyzing problems in public and urban affairs; emphasis on computer applications. Maximum Credits: 3

P A 620.course_name: Seminar in Management of Urban Governments
P A 620.course_description: P A 620 - Seminar in Management of Urban Governments  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Selected problems in the management of urban governments. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.

P A 630.course_description: P A 630 - Seminar in Public Personnel Administration  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P A 600 .Analysis of selected problems in personnel administration; special emphasis on organizational development and consultation skills as emerging personnel functions. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.

P A 632.course_name: Seminar of Organization Development in the Public Sector
P A 632.course_description: P A 632 - Seminar of Organization Development in the Public Sector  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P A 600 .Organization development theory and practice. Emphasis on organizational diagnosis, intervention theory, team building and process consultation skills as they apply to public sector organizations. Maximum Credits: 3

P A 640.course_description: P A 640 - Seminar in Public Administration  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Selected topics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content.

P A 642.course_description: P A 642 - Seminar in Administrative Theory  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P A 600 .Organization and management; the executive role, decision making; bureaucracy; authority and power; communication and control and organizational system; tactics and strategies in effective management. Maximum Credits: 3

P A 643.course_description: P A 643 - Seminar in Administrative Behavior  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P A 340 .Intrapersonal, interpersonal and group development knowledge which enhances the administrator’s effectiveness. Simulations and structured experiential designs examine behaviors encountered in public bureaucracies. Maximum Credits: 3

P A 650.course_description: P A 650 - Seminar in Public Financial Management  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P A 600 .Economics and politics of the public sector. Theories of public expenditure analysis and revenue generation. Issues of ethics and efficiency in government financial policy. Maximum Credits: 3

P A 660.course_description: P A 660 - Administration and Public Policy Development  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P A 600 .Social, political and administrative problems involved in governmental program development and change. Maximum Credits: 3
