P A 791.course_description: P A 791 - Readings in Public Administration  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): P A 600  and advancement to candidacy.Selected readings in the literature of public administration. Maximum Credits: 3

P A 792.course_description: P A 792 - Problem Analysis  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Analytical treatment of selected problems in Public Administration. Review of methods for investigation and reporting of data. Consideration of problems in preparation of projects or thesis. Maximum Credits: 3

P A 795.course_description: P A 795 - Capstone Seminar in Public Affairs  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Advancement to candidacy for the Master of City Planning, Master of Public Administration, or Master of Science in criminal justice and criminology.Needs assessment and program/policy design, development, or evaluation for public service problems and opportunities. Group projects and reports with community stakeholders. Knowledge integration attained throughout city planning, criminal justice, and public administration graduate programs. Maximum Credits: 3

P A 796.course_description: P A 796 - Internship in Public Administration  Units: 3-12 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.The 12 units of 796 will be exempt from the university’s requirement that courses graded Cr/NC be limited to 30 percent of units for the master’s degree. Maximum Credits: 12

P A 797.course_description: P A 797 - Research in Public Administration  Units: 3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of director of public affairs.Research in one of the areas of public administration. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.

P A 798.course_description: P A 798 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of staff, to be arranged with the director and instructor.Individual study. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.

P A 799A.course_description: P A 799A - Thesis  Units: 3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): An officially appointed thesis committee and advancement to candidacy.Preparation of a project or thesis for the master’s degree. Maximum Credits: 3

P A 799B.course_description: P A 799B - Thesis Extension  Units: 0 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Prior registration in Thesis 799A with an assigned grade symbol of RP.Registration required in any semester or term following assignment of RP in Course 799A in which the student expects to use the facilities and resources of the university; also student must be registered in the course when the completed thesis is granted final approval. Maximum Credits: 0

P A 799C.course_description: P A 799C - Comprehensive Examination Extension  Units: 0 Grading Method: Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Completion or concurrent enrollment in degree program courses.Registration required of students whose only requirement is completion of the comprehensive examination for the master’s degree. Registration in 799C limited to two semesters.

P H 101.course_description: P H 101 - Introduction to Public Health  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Epidemics, environment, and community health challenges, including educational, political, environmental, regulatory, and organizational factors that support health of population groups and communities. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 250.course_description: P H 250 - Infections and Epidemics  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Concepts and impacts of infectious diseases on human populations. Quantitative reasoning to solve epidemiologic mysteries. Case studies and outbreak investigations. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 292.course_description: P H 292 - History of Public Health  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 101  with a grade of B (3.0) or better. Open only to public health majors.Historical and contemporary issues surrounding population health. Public health responses, outcomes of those responses, and concerns over time. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 296.course_description: P H 296 - Experimental Topics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected topics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

P H 300.course_description: P H 300 - Professionalism and Public Health  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 101  with a grade of B (3.0) or better. Open only to public health majors.Best practices for healthcare working professionals. Job searches, résumés, statements of purpose, written communications. Organizational behaviors, culture, and structure. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 302.course_description: P H 302 - Communicable and Chronic Disease  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Open to public health majors and minors.Impact of infectious and chronic diseases on health of the population. Epidemiologic methods, behavioral and biologic determinants, modes of transmission, and risk factors. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 303.course_description: P H 303 - Health Behavior in Community Settings  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s):  P H 302 .Behavior change theory, principles, predictive models, and their application to health behavior change programs. Review of research methods related to individuals and communities. Analysis of major health behavior change programs. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 304.course_description: P H 304 - Environment and Public Health  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s):  P H 302 . Open to public health majors and minors.Environmental hazards of living and working in both industrialized and lesser developed societies. Chemical, biological, and physical agents in food, air, water, and soil. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 305.course_description: P H 305 - Medical Care Organization and Delivery  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s):  P H 302 .Organizational, economic, financial, political, and cultural factors affecting finance and delivery of health and medical services in the U.S. Topics include insurance, managed care, reimbursement, private and public programs, and regulation. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 306.course_description: P H 306 - Public Health Research  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 101 . Open only to public health majors.Methodological, ethical, topical issues in current public health research. Basic principles and different approaches to research designs and methods applicable to writing proposals and other documents in academic and professional settings.Formerly numbered Public Health 295. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 307.course_description: P H 307 - Applied Biostatistics in Public Health  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Credit or concurrent enrollment in P H 302. Data analysis and statistical inference in public health sciences to include data description and exploratory analysis, and statistical methods for evaluating association of factors with health outcomes. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 330.course_description: P H 330 - Plagues Through the Ages  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Political, economic, religious, and cultural effects of disease. Significant role epidemics and disease have played in development of civilizations from beginning of recorded history to present.Formerly numbered General Studies 330. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 331.course_description: P H 331 - Emergency Preparedness and Disaster Response  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 302 .Roles and responsibilities of public health in disaster preparation, mitigation, planning, and response to epidemics, pandemics, natural disasters and bioterrorism, includes disaster assessment, surveillance, risk management, and principles of disaster planning. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 332.course_description: P H 332 - Public Health Nutrition  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 101 .Importance of nutrition to the health of populations throughout the life-course. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 333.course_name: Health Equity: Exploring Root Causes of Disparities
P H 333.course_description: P H 333 - Health Equity: Exploring Root Causes of Disparities  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 101  with a grade of B (3.0) or better.Causative factors that contribute to health disparities and inequities. Advocacy and policy. Health, race/ethnicity, and social justice. Social determinants of health. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 353.course_description: P H 353 - Human Sexuality and Disease  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Development of sexual values, attitudes, and behaviors across ages, including evolution and occurrence of sexually transmitted infections worldwide. Focus on biological, medical, psychological, sociocultural, and political factors. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 362.course_description: P H 362 - Global Health  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC - Letter (Cr/NC OK) Population dynamics, vital statistics, global disease patterns, and analysis of variations among nations and cultures with respect to health problems and health care services. Note: This course satisfies the general education cultural diversity requirement.

P H 395.course_description: P H 395 - Emerging Topics in Public Health  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Open only to public health majors.Emergent topics that may include global warming, gun violence, health disparities, LGBTQ+ health, and the penal system. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 401.course_description: P H 401 - Biological Basis of Disease  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Credit or concurrent enrollment in P H 302. Prevalent health issues, problems, and social consequences surrounding conditions such as substance use, cancer, heart disease, and stroke. Disease protective factors, risks, and screening processes.

P H 402.course_description: P H 402 - Public Health Communications  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Credit in P H 306 and credit or concurrent enrollment in P H 490B.Effective communication techniques used in public health campaigns, social marketing, and risk communication. Use of technology to design and conduct public health campaigns which focus on recognizing and overcoming communication barriers, including cross-cultural communication.

P H 450.course_description: P H 450 - Public Health Policy  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 302 . Recommended: P H 305 .Political, economic, cultural, institutional, and social factors influencing development and implementation of policy. U.S. and international private and public health organizations and their roles in shaping health policy. Public health advocacy by organizations. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 451.course_description: P H 451 - Public Health and Food Safety  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.Risk factors for foodborne illness, to include case studies of domestic and international outbreaks. Food safety, foodborne illness, food safety measures and prevention, management and regulation, sustainability. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 452.course_description: P H 452 - Health Impacts of Climate Change  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC - Letter (Cr/NC OK) Prerequisite(s): Credit in P H 101 and P H 292.Biological, chemical, physical, and social factors contributing to climate change and human health. Greenhouse effect, health impacts and adaptation, climate change projections, and climate mitigation.

P H 480.course_description: P H 480 - Peer Health Education  Units: 2-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Communicating health information to peers. Health issues relevant to university population. Health promotion strategies and tactics. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 485.course_description: P H 485 - Applied Public Health Research  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNO - Letter (No Cr/NC) Prerequisite(s): Public Health Majors with Senior-Standing. Credit or concurrent enrollment in P H 490B Planning Public Health Programs.Hands-on experience in applied public health research to address local public health challenges and respond to community health needs. Completion of this course will fulfill either the Area A or Area B graduation requirement for Public Health majors.

P H 490A.course_description: P H 490A - Health Data Analysis  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNO - Letter (No Cr/NC) Prerequisite(s): P H 307 and credit or concurrent enrollment in P H 306.Identifying, retrieving, and using health data, with emphasis on statistical applications and interpretation of results for changing policy and health programs.

P H 490B.course_description: P H 490B - Planning Public Health Programs  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 304  and P H 306 .Public health programming models, including community needs assessment, goals, objectives, and strategies for effective public health interventions. Preparation of grant proposals. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 490C.course_description: P H 490C - Public Health Program Evaluation  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 490B .Quantitative and qualitative evaluation methods in public health programs. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 496.course_description: P H 496 - Experimental Topics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected topics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

P H 497.course_description: P H 497 - Supervised Specialization in Public Health  Units: 1-6 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Junior or senior standing in public health and P H 300 , P H 302 , P H 307 , and credit or concurrent registration in P H 304 , P H 305 , and P H 306 .Placement in a public health environment. Maximum Credits: 6

P H 499.course_description: P H 499 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of special study adviser. Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6

P H 538A.course_description: P H 538A - Principles of Toxicology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division or graduate standing.Dose-response and other principles for evaluating the effects of toxic chemicals on organ systems and physiological processes.Formerly numbered P H 638A Maximum Credits: 3

P H 550.course_description: P H 550 - Applied International Public Health  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 101  or graduate standing.Global cultural, economic, health, political, and social challenges of different countries. Application of public health concepts in a particular country. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 601.course_description: P H 601 - Epidemiology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.Distribution and determinants of diseases; role of epidemiology in public health. Descriptive, analytic, and experimental epidemiology. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 602.course_description: P H 602 - Biostatistics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.Statistical reasoning applied to public health; probability, hypothesis testing, regression and correlation, analysis of variance, measurement theory and modeling. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 603.course_name: Behavioral and Social Science in Public Health
P H 603.course_description: P H 603 - Behavioral and Social Science in Public Health  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.Role of psychological, social and environmental variables in health and illness. Multifactorial psychosocial model of disease susceptibility. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 604.course_description: P H 604 - Environmental Determinants of Human Health  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Environmental determinants and their influence on human health. Biological, physical, and chemical factors which affect the health of a community. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 605.course_description: P H 605 - Health Services Administration  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Overview of health services administration and delivery in U.S. Characteristics of utilization of health care, financing and system structure, types of providers, nonfinancial resources, and assessment and regulation. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 606.course_name: Applied Research Methods in Public Health
P H 606.course_description: P H 606 - Applied Research Methods in Public Health  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 601 and P H 602 or instructor consent. Emphasizes applied skills in literature searching and interpretation, identification of gaps, scientific writing, interpretation of statistical software, and effective communication. Gain preparation skills for completion of concentration-specific Integrated Learning Experience.

P H 607.course_description: P H 607 - Research Methods  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNO - Letter (No Cr/NC)  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Direct observation measurement, group and intensive experimental designs. Laboratory exercises and proposal writing applicable to public health.

P H 620.course_description: P H 620 - SAS for Biostatistics I  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNO - Letter (No Cr/NC) Prerequisite(s): Credit or concurrent registration in P H 602 .Programming in SAS. Analysis, processing, and reading of biomedical data.

P H 621.course_description: P H 621 - Epidemiology of Infectious Diseases  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 601 .Utilizing selected infectious diseases and environmental settings, provides scientific background on which epidemiological investigations and control measures are based. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 622.course_description: P H 622 - Epidemiology of Chronic Diseases  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 601 .Epidemiology of selected chronic diseases. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 623.course_description: P H 623 - Epidemiological Methods  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 602 , P H 621  or P H 622 .Topics include: analysis of descriptive data, design of studies, evaluation of data, development of biological models. Examples of both acute and chronic diseases. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 624A.course_description: P H 624A - Emergency Preparedness and Response I  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Classified graduate standing.Dynamics of natural and man-made disaster management to include planning, organization, management of relief services, and emergency service organizations. Prevention, mitigation, and response to emergency situations, both nationally and internationally. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 625.course_description: P H 625 - Control of Infectious Diseases  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 621 Theoretical and practical experience in techniques available for control of infectious diseases. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 626.course_description: P H 626 - International Health Epidemiology Practicum  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  One lecture and two hours of activity.Prerequisite(s): P H 601  and P H 602 .Integrated public health experience with US and Mexican graduate student and faculty teams, culminating with four days in Mexico. International public health projects in underserved indigenous populations. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 627.course_name: Advanced Statistical Methods in Public Health
P H 627.course_description: P H 627 - Advanced Statistical Methods in Public Health  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 602 .Applications of advanced statistical methods for analysis of public health and biomedical data. Topics include multiple linear regression, analysis of variance, logistic regression, and introduction to survival analysis. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 628.course_name: Applications of Multivariate Statistics in Public Health
P H 628.course_description: P H 628 - Applications of Multivariate Statistics in Public Health  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 627 .Statistical methods for multivariate problems in public health including regression diagnostics, cluster analysis, discriminant analysis, principal components, multivariate discrete analysis and Poisson regression. Computer applications included. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 629.course_description: P H 629 - SAS for Biostatistics II  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNO - Letter (No Cr/NC) Prerequisite(s): P H 620  and credit or concurrent registration in P H 602 .Advanced programming in SAS. Higher-level analyses, processing, and readings of biomedical data.Formerly numbered Public Health 700A.

P H 630.course_description: P H 630 - Environmental Health Risk Assessment  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Four major steps of risk assessment to include hazard identification, dose-response assessment, exposure assessment, and risk characterization. Will also include risk communication and risk management in environmental arena. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 632.course_description: P H 632 - Air Quality  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.Properties of airborne gases, vapors, and particulate matter. Effects of air pollution on community. Mobile and stationary sources of air pollution. Meteorology and dispersion of air pollutants. Ambient air quality standards. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 634.course_description: P H 634 - Environmental Protection  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Rationale and mechanisms for control of environmental hazards in areas of food protection and vector control, solid waste, and community issues. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 635.course_description: P H 635 - Environmental and Disaster Medicine  Units: 3  Etiology, diagnosis of disease, and stress in the modern global environment. Detection and control of intentional biological, chemical disasters, and nuclear threats.

P H 636.course_description: P H 636 - Hazardous Waste Management  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Rationale, methods, and regulations governing the proper management of hazardous and toxic wastes. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 639.course_description: P H 639 - Water Quality Investigation  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Human health problems associated with water usage and with various aquatic environments. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 641.course_description: P H 641 - Introduction to Health Services  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Health care systems in the U.S. Underlying needs, insurance and uninsurance, public programs, reimbursement, managed care, resources, providers, regulation outcome measurement and evaluation, and health policy issues. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 642.course_description: P H 642 - Health Insurance and Financing Systems  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 641 .U.S. healthcare financial systems at macro-level. Principles of public programs and private health insurance, types of reimbursement for healthcare organizations and providers, issues of cost containment, effects of uninsurance and underinsurance, and financial practices of other advanced nations.Formerly numbered Public Health 742B. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 644A.course_description: P H 644A - Health Services Organization Management  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Credit or concurrent registration in P H 641 .Structure and functioning of organizations that provide and finance health services using a systems theory approach to visions/ goals, strategies, structure, and processes. Functions of managers in health care organizations, focusing on interpersonal, informational, decision, ethical, and conflict resolution roles.Formerly numbered Public Health 644. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 644B.course_name: Managing High Performing Health Care Organization
P H 644B.course_description: P H 644B - Managing High Performing Health Care Organization  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 641  and P H 644A .Applications of management theory to health care organizations. Organizational change for performance, behavior, quality management, law and ethics, human resource management, and information technology. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 645.course_description: P H 645 - Health Economics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 641 .Economics of health care, including supply and demand factors, efficiency, incentives facing physicians, hospitals, and health plans, economic evaluation of provider performance, health workforce issues, and cost-effectiveness analysis. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 646.course_description: P H 646 - Health Services Research Methods  Units: 2 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.Effectiveness of interventions. Changes in delivery, financing, and organization of health care. Analysis of large data sets related to health care industry. Maximum Credits: 12

P H 647.course_name: Quantitative Methods and Health Data Analysis
P H 647.course_description: P H 647 - Quantitative Methods and Health Data Analysis  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 602  and P H 641 .Quantitative methods and data analyses in health services administration. Topics include decision analysis, forecasting and regression, project management techniques, data analysis, and data and information management applications. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 648.course_description: P H 648 - Health Policy  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Credit or concurrent registration in P H 641 .History and future of health policy. Research on major health policy issues including economic, social, ethical, and political forces that influence priorities and decisions. Role of government and private sector in health care. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 649.course_name: Border and Global Public Health Surveillance
P H 649.course_description: P H 649 - Border and Global Public Health Surveillance  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 601  and P H 602 .Data sources for border and global surveillance, including hospital system syndromic data. Methods of data quality control, data analysis, and alerting and communication of information. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 650A.course_description: P H 650A - Field Practice: Epidemiology  Units: 3-6 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Field instruction in public health settings. Application of public health principles and skills to practical problems. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units of Public Health 650 applicable to a master’s degree.

P H 650F.course_name: Field Practice: Health Promotion and Behavioral Science
P H 650F.course_description: P H 650F - Field Practice: Health Promotion and Behavioral Science  Units: 3-6 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Field instruction in public health settings. Application of public health principles and skills to practical problems. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units of Public Health 650 applicable to a master’s degree.

P H 650R.course_description: P H 650R - Field Practice: Required Community Practice  Units: 3-6 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Field instruction in public health settings. Application of public health principles and skills to practical problems. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units of Public Health 650 applicable to a master’s degree.

P H 661.course_description: P H 661 - Theoretical Foundations of Health Promotion  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNO - Letter (No Cr/NC) Psychological, sociological, economic, and political theories relevant to the mission and processes of health promotion.

P H 662.course_description: P H 662 - Motivating Health Behavior  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.Application of behavioral change techniques and health education methodology to health promotion targeting individuals and whole communities. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 663.course_name: Health Promotion Communications Theory and Design
P H 663.course_description: P H 663 - Health Promotion Communications Theory and Design  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 402 .Theory, design and implementation of health education communications in community contexts. Extensive use of student design, analysis, and projects. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 664.course_description: P H 664 - Health, Society and Human Behavior  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): PSY 101 , SOC 101 .Historical and contemporary examination of health problems of individuals and communities. Health needs, resources; impact of society on health and health on society. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 666.course_name: Health Promotion Program Planning and Assessment
P H 666.course_description: P H 666 - Health Promotion Program Planning and Assessment  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 661 .Program planning and assessment, theories, systems and procedures relevant to health promotion and education. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 667.course_name: Prevention and Control of Chronic Diseases
P H 667.course_description: P H 667 - Prevention and Control of Chronic Diseases  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 601  and P H 602 .Health promotion strategies for modification of individual behaviors and social practices to lower risk of chronic disease. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 668.course_description: P H 668 - Seminar in Health Promotion Research  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in public health.Philosophical, ethical and methodological issues in current health promotion research and services. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 672.course_description: P H 672 - Public Health Program Evaluation  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNO - Letter (No Cr/NC) Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing. Recommended: P H 666 .Evaluation of health promotion programs in public health. Activities, processes, and skills to include communicating results, contextual issues, design, methods, steps, and ensuring summative findings are used.

P H 682.course_name: Geographic Information Systems and Public Health Spatial Analysis
P H 682.course_description: P H 682 - Geographic Information Systems and Public Health Spatial Analysis  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and two hours of activity.Prerequisite(s): P H 601  and P H 602 .Theoretical concepts of geographic information systems (GIS) and applications of GIS in public health. ArcGIS 9 software to illustrate the capabilities and uses of GIS in both academic research and regulatory decision making. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 696.course_description: P H 696 - Contemporary Topics in Public Health  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Intensive study in specific areas of public health and health services administration.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 12Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Credit for 596 and 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser.

P H 700.course_description: P H 700 - Seminar in Public Health  Units: 1-3  Prerequisite(s): P H 601 , P H 602 , and P H 603 .Investigation of current problems in one of the fields of public health.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Maximum Credit Statement: nine units of P H 700 applicable to a master’s degree. These units may be in a single concentration area or any of the public health concentration areas.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content.

P H 700A.course_description: P H 700A - Seminar in Public Health: Epidemiology  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 601 , P H 602 , and P H 603 .Investigation of current problems in one of the fields of public health.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Maximum Credit Statement: nine units of P H 700 applicable to a master’s degree. These units may be in a single concentration area or any of the public health concentration areas.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content.

P H 700D.course_name: Seminar in Public Health: Environmental Health
P H 700D.course_description: P H 700D - Seminar in Public Health: Environmental Health  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 601 , P H 602 , and P H 603 .Investigation of current problems in one of the fields of public health.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Maximum Credit Statement: nine units of P H 700 applicable to a master’s degree. These units may be in a single concentration area or any of the public health concentration areas.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content.

P H 700E.course_name: Seminar in Public Health: Health Management and Policy
P H 700E.course_description: P H 700E - Seminar in Public Health: Health Management and Policy  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 601 , P H 602 , and P H 603 .Investigation of current problems in one of the fields of public health.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Maximum Credit Statement: nine units of P H 700 applicable to a master’s degree. These units may be in a single concentration area or any of the public health concentration areas.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content.

P H 700F.course_name: Seminar in Public Health: Health Promotion and Behavioral Science
P H 700F.course_description: P H 700F - Seminar in Public Health: Health Promotion and Behavioral Science  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 601 , P H 602 , and P H 603 .Investigation of current problems in one of the fields of public health.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Maximum Credit Statement: nine units of P H 700 applicable to a master’s degree. These units may be in a single concentration area or any of the public health concentration areas.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content.

P H 700G.course_name: Seminar in Public Health: Preventive Medicine
P H 700G.course_description: P H 700G - Seminar in Public Health: Preventive Medicine  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 601 , P H 602 , and P H 603 .Investigation of current problems in one of the fields of public health.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Maximum Credit Statement: nine units of P H 700 applicable to a master’s degree. These units may be in a single concentration area or any of the public health concentration areas.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content.

P H 720A.course_description: P H 720A - Capstone I  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 601 , P H 623 , P H 627 .Develop hypotheses and research questions, use publicly accessible dataset, write epidemiologic report based on analysis. Institutional Review Board review process, literature review, table and figure creation, technical writing. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 720B.course_description: P H 720B - Capstone II  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 720A .Complete discussion, hypotheses, research questions, results, tables and figures for a final report. Create oral presentation to describe results. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 724.course_description: P H 724 - Advanced Methods in Epidemiology  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 601 , P H 623 , and P H 627 .In-depth methodological issues in performance and interpretation of epidemiologic studies. Study design, cluster analysis, effect modification, accuracy and precision, adjustment of attributable risk, life tables, Kaplan-Meier, Cox proportional hazards modeling, and meta-analysis. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 725.course_description: P H 725 - Scientific Writing for Epidemiology  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Completion of one year of master’s level coursework in epidemiology or biometry.Prepares students to generate a feasible hypothesis, perform, organize and write a literature review, and summarize proposed methodology. Topics include research development and organization, finding data sources, principles of scientific writing and revising, plagiarism, and citation management. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 726.course_description: P H 726 - HIV/AIDS Epidemiology and Public Health  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 601 . Recommended: P H 621 .State-of-the-art review of HIV and AIDS within a public health framework. Biology, transmission, host susceptibility, screening and surveillance, domestic and international epidemiology, study design, intervention, and options for prevention (including community- based trials). Maximum Credits: 3

P H 728.course_description: P H 728 - Applied Data Analysis  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 627  with a grade of B (3.0) or better.Public health data and presentation of results. Linear regression, logistic regression for binary, missing data analysis, nominal and ordinal data, and survival analysis. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 742A.course_description: P H 742A - Health Services Financial Management  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in public health.Financial reporting statement including balance sheet and income statement. Financial management indicators including discounted cash flow analysis, long-term debt financing, equity valuation, risk and return, capital budgeting, financial forecasting, and short-term financing. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 743.course_description: P H 743 - Hospital and Ambulatory Systems Management  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 641  and P H 644A .Organization and management of hospitals, integrated healthcare systems, medical group practices, and other ambulatory or outpatient facilities. Emphasis on service provision, programs, and plans. San Diego regional healthcare organizations highlighted. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 747.course_description: P H 747 - Quality Improvement and Program Evaluation  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 647 .Health services quality measurement and improvement to include quality systems policy and management; outcomes and performance measurement; process quality improvement methods; program evaluation methods; development of evidenced-based practices and electronic medical records; and administrative databases. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 748.course_name: Health Services Competitive Strategy and Marketing
P H 748.course_description: P H 748 - Health Services Competitive Strategy and Marketing  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 644B .Ways in which healthcare organizations can gain and sustain competitive advantage. Both organization and service level competition and strategies/tactics examined. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 750.course_description: P H 750 - Advanced Field Practice  Units: 3-6 Grading Method: CNC - Letter (Cr/NC OK) Prerequisite(s): P H 650 .Field instruction in public health setting. Application of public health principles and skills to public health problems. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units of P H 750 applicable to a master’s degree.

PHYS 604.course_description: PHYS 604 - Electromagnetic Theory  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): PHYS 400B .Electrostatics, magnetic induction, and magnetostatics, Maxwell’s equations, electromagnetic waves and radiation, fields in macroscopic media, special relativity. Maximum Credits: 3

PHYS 606.course_description: PHYS 606 - Statistical Mechanics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): PHYS 360 , PHYS 410 , PHYS 608 .Statistical basis of thermodynamics. Microcanonical, canonical, and grand canonical ensembles. Ideal Bose and Fermi systems. Interacting systems. Phase transitions. Maximum Credits: 3

PHYS 608.course_description: PHYS 608 - Classical Mechanics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): PHYS 350  and MATH 342B .Vector and tensor methods, motion of rigid bodies, vibration, coupled circuits, Lagrange’s and Hamilton’s equations, principle of least action. Maximum Credits: 3

PHYS 610A.course_description: PHYS 610A - Quantum Mechanics  Units: 3-3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): PHYS 410 .Physical and mathematical basis of quantum mechanics. Wave mechanics and the Schroedinger Equation, matricies and Hilbert space, angular momentum and spin, atomic structure, bound-state perturbation theory, many particle systems, transition rates and time-dependent perturbation theory, scattering, and relativistic quantum mechanics. Maximum Credits: 3

PHYS 670A.course_description: PHYS 670A - Medical Physics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): PHYS 560  and PHYS 561 .Radiological physics, dosimetry, imaging, and radiation protection in medical environments including diagnostic radiology, nuclear medicine, and radiation oncology. Maximum Credits: 3

PHYS 670B.course_description: PHYS 670B - Medical Physics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): PHYS 560  and PHYS 561 .Radiological physics, dosimetry, imaging, and radiation protection in medical environments including diagnostic radiology, nuclear medicine, and radiation oncology. Maximum Credits: 3

PHYS 672A.course_description: PHYS 672A - Radiation Therapy Physics Laboratory  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  One lecture and six hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): PHYS 670A .Skills to perform radiation therapy physics procedures. Maximum Credits: 3

PHYS 672B.course_description: PHYS 672B - Diagnostic Imaging Laboratory  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  One lecture and six hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): PHYS 670B .Skills to perform quality assurance and acceptance testing on radiological equipment in a clinical setting. Maximum Credits: 3

PHYS 674.course_description: PHYS 674 - Radiation Treatment Planning  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): BIOL 335 .Fundamental and practical concepts in radiation treatment planning. Hands on experience in clinical treatment planning for external beam radiotherapy. Maximum Credits: 3

PHYS 680.course_description: PHYS 680 - Magnetic Resonance Imaging  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): PHYS 670B  or MATH 342A  and PHYS 354 .Nuclear magnetic resonance, relaxation theory, Fourier transform MR imaging physics, imaging sequences, optimization of signal and contrast, special imaging sequences to include MR angiography, functional MRI, diffusion and perfusion MRI, MR hardware and configuration. Maximum Credits: 3

PHYS 690.course_description: PHYS 690 - Medical Imaging Processing  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and three hours of laboratory.Prerequisite(s): PHYS 670B .Digital image processing to include medical image formats, image enhancement, restoration, registration, segmentation, representation, and programming. Maximum Credits: 3

PHYS 696.course_description: PHYS 696 - Advanced Topics in Physics  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.Intensive study in specific areas of physics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 12Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Credit for 596 and 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser.

PHYS 701.course_description: PHYS 701 - Clinical Rotations I  Units: 1-9 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): PHYS 564 , PHYS 567 , PHYS 672A , PHYS 672B .On-site, full-day clinical training in external beam modalities (megavoltage photons, electrons, superficial x-rays) including equipment selection, radiation protection, acceptance/commissioning, calibration and quality assurance. Theoretical basis and use of the various detectors and dosimeters associated with external beam modalities. Maximum Credits: 9Maximum Credit Statement: Course may be repeatable for credit to a maximum of 9 units.

PHYS 703.course_description: PHYS 703 - Clinical Rotations II  Units: 1-9 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): PHYS 701 .On-site, full-day clinical training in intensity modulated radiation therapy (IMRT) and brachytherapy. Training in quality assurance, calibration, inverse planning, IMRT delivery, and radiation safety. Radionuclides and sealed sources in brachytherapy, clinical applications of the sources, treatment planning, and quality assurance. Maximum Credits: 9Maximum Credit Statement: Course may be repeatable for credit to a maximum of 9 units.

PHYS 705.course_description: PHYS 705 - Clinical Rotations III  Units: 1-9 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): PHYS 703 .On-site, full-day clinical training in the principles of computed tomography (CT) simulator, associated radiation protection/design considerations, CT protocols. Understand the physics of imaging modalities and perform quality assurance on CT, MRI, ultrasound and PET as related to radiation therapy. Train on picture archiving and communication systems. Maximum Credits: 9Maximum Credit Statement: Course may be repeatable for credit to a maximum of 9 units.

PHYS 707.course_description: PHYS 707 - Clinical Rotations IV  Units: 1-9 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): PHYS 705 .On-site, full-day clinical training covering physics concepts and implementation of standard radiation treatment (RT) techniques for common cancer treatment sites, routine quality assurance associated with patient specific RT and planning, special RT procedures, quality assurance of RT planning systems, patient safety with respect to radiation therapy. Maximum Credits: 9Maximum Credit Statement: Course may be repeatable for credit to a maximum of 9 units.

PHYS 797.course_description: PHYS 797 - Research  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of graduate adviser.Research in one of the fields of physics. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.

PHYS 798.course_description: PHYS 798 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of staff; to be arranged with department chair and instructor. Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.

PHYS 799A.course_description: PHYS 799A - Thesis  Units: 3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): An officially appointed thesis committee and advancement to candidacy.Preparation of a thesis in physics for the master’s degree. Maximum Credits: 3

PHYS 799B.course_description: PHYS 799B - Thesis Extension  Units: 0 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Prior registration in Thesis 799A with an assigned grade symbol of RP.Registration required in any semester or term following assignment of RP in Course 799A in which the student expects to use the facilities and resources of the university; also student must be registered in the course when the completed thesis is granted final approval. Maximum Credits: 0

PHYS 799C.course_description: PHYS 799C - Comprehensive Examination Extension  Units: 0 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Completion or concurrent enrollment in degree program courses.Registration required of students whose only requirement is completion of the comprehensive examination for the master’s degree. Registration in 799C limited to two semesters. Maximum Credits: 0

POL S 100.course_description: POL S 100 - Rhetoric of Written Argument  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: ECL 100  and RWS 100 .International students are advised to take LING 100B . Prerequisite(s): Satisfaction of the SDSU Written Communication Assessment requirement. (See Graduation Requirements section of catalog.) Proof of completion of prerequisite required.Writing and reading as critical inquiry, designed to help students undertake university-level writing projects. Focus on rhetoric of written arguments. Students learn to use sources in their writing and make appropriate decisions about structure, cohesion, and rhetorical conventions. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Not open to students with credit in a higher-numbered composition course or AFRAS 120  or AMIND 120  or CCS 111B  or RWS 100  [or ECL 100 ] or LING 100B  or RWS 105B .

POL S 101.course_name: Introduction to American Politics in Global Perspective
POL S 101.course_description: POL S 101 - Introduction to American Politics in Global Perspective  Units: 3 GE-AIGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Politics and basic political concepts as applied to the American political system. American political system as a constitutional democracy viewed in historical and comparative perspectives and within context of the global system. When taken with POL S 102  will satisfy graduation requirement in American Institutions. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 102.course_name: Introduction to American and California Government and Politics
POL S 102.course_description: POL S 102 - Introduction to American and California Government and Politics  Units: 3 GE-AIGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Political processes and institutions in the United States and California. Considers a variety of public policy issues such as environmental quality, health, education, relation between government and business, taxation, and foreign affairs as reflected in the dynamics of national and state politics. Maximum Credits: 3Note: When taken with POL S 101  will satisfy graduation requirement in American Institutions.

POL S 103.course_description: POL S 103 - Introduction to Comparative Politics  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Analytical models and techniques for examination of problems of decision making and control in various political systems. Emphasis on patterns of political action in various cultural contexts. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 104.course_description: POL S 104 - Introduction to Global Politics  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Basic concepts, terms, and institutions of global politics. Explores power and inequality in the global system in a variety of issue areas, such as war and diplomacy, human rights, migration, the global economy, development, and the environment. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 201.course_description: POL S 201 - Statistics and Politics  Units: 3 Foundations - Natural Sciences and Quantitative Reasoning - Quantitative [CSU B4]Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Asking and answering questions about politics with quantitative data. Analyzing and interpreting relationships between real-world political causes and effects. Note: Students with credit or concurrent registration in the following lower division statistics courses will be awarded a total of four units for the two (or more) courses: POL S 201; ARP 201 ; BIOL 215 ; CIV E 160 ; ECON 201 ; LING 270 ; PSY 280 ; SOC 201 ; STAT 119 , STAT 250 .

POL S 296.course_description: POL S 296 - Experimental Topics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Selected topics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

POL S 299.course_description: POL S 299 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor or approval of department chair. Individual study.  Maximum Credits: Six units.

POL S 300.course_description:
POL S 300 - Islam and Politics  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Concepts, interactions, and theories between Islamic actors and political institutions. Islam-state relations.
General Text: Comparative Politics. Maximum Credits: 3Note: This course satisfies the general education cultural diversity requirement.

POL S 301A.course_description:
POL S 301A - History of Western Political Thought  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: Political Theory
Development of political ideas from the Golden Age of Greece until the French Revolution. Relevance of theory to a critical understanding of concrete political and social problems involving power, freedom, equality, justice and action. Emphasizes Plato, Aristotle, Augustine, Aquinas, and Marsilius of Padua. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 301B.course_description:
POL S 301B - History of Western Political Thought  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: Political Theory
Development of political ideas from the Golden Age of Greece until the French Revolution. Relevance of theory to a critical understanding of concrete political and social problems involving power, freedom, equality, justice and action. Stresses major political theorists such as Machiavelli, Hobbes, Locke, and Rousseau. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 302.course_description:
POL S 302 - Modern Political Thought  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: Political Theory
Major writers of political thought in the last two centuries, including Burke, J.S. Mill, Freud, Marx, Weber and Sartre. The following topics may be covered: conservatism, liberalism, utilitarianism, socialism, fascism, positivism and existentialism. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 305.course_description:
POL S 305 - American Political Thought  Units: 3 GE-AIGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: Political Theory
Origin and development of American political ideas from colonial times to the present. Meets the graduation requirement in the United States Constitution. When taken with POL S 320 , POL S 321  or POL S 422 , will also satisfy graduation requirements in American Institutions. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 320.course_description:
POL S 320 - The U.S. Constitution  Units: 3 GE-AIGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: American Politics
Principles inherent to the constitutional framework in the United States, the controversies accompanying those principles, and the political institutions that have developed under them. Meets the graduation requirement in the United States Constitution and California state and local government. When taken with POL S 305 , POL S 321  or POL S 422 , will also satisfy graduation requirements in American Institutions. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 321.course_description:
POL S 321 - State Politics  Units: 3 GE-AIGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: American Politics
Politics and policy making at the state and local levels, relations among national, state, and local governments. Emphasis on California problems and politics. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Meets the graduation requirement in California government. When taken with POL S 305  or POL S 320 , will also satisfy graduation requirements in American Institutions.

POL S 322.course_description:
POL S 322 - Politics and Conflict  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): POL S 102 .Field of Study: American Politics
Nature of interpersonal, group, and societal conflict and mechanisms that can facilitate conflict resolution and bargained agreement. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 331.course_description:
POL S 331 - American Indian Political Experience  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Same As: AMIND 331   Prerequisite(s): POL S 102  or AMIND 110 .Field of Study: American Politics
Social and political responses to dominant group policies by American Indian as compared to other minority groups. Maximum Credits: 3Note: This course satisfies the ethnic studies [ES] requirement.

POL S 333.course_description:
POL S 333 - Politics of Race and Ethnicity  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: American Politics
Race and racism in the United States. History of discriminatory policies and segregation of racial and ethnic communities. How past policy decisions continue to be reflected in modern racial hierarchies and political rhetoric on race with debates in modern policymaking on crime control, immigration, poverty. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 334.course_description:
POL S 334 - Politics of the Environment  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: SUSTN 334 . Field of Study: American Politics
Environmental politics and policy in historical and comparative non-dominant perspective. Alternative environmental world views, cases/materials on sustainability, climate change, social and racial justice, globalization and developing nations. Maximum Credits: 3Note: This course satisfies the general education cultural diversity requirement.

POL S 335.course_description:
POL S 335 - Policy Issues and Debates  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: American Politics
Social problems and the policies developed to address them. Analysis of debates and policy alternatives on issues to include education, health care, and housing. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 336.course_description:
POL S 336 - Gender and Public Policy  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: American Politics
American politics and public policy debates around gendered participation in national and international politics to include intersectionality, legal strategies, new understandings of public and private issues, support of and restrictions to feminism. Maximum Credits: 3Note: This course satisfies the general education cultural diversity requirement.

POL S 338.course_description:
POL S 338 - U.S. Congress: Conflict and Compromise  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: American Politics
Tools and strategies used by majority and minority parties to gain influence in policymaking and electoral politics. Areas of legislative conflict or compromise and the formal procedures used to promote or prevent policy change. Legislative bodies outside of the United States. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 346.course_description:
POL S 346 - Law and the Political System  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: American Politics
Courts as political institutions and judges as political actors. Dynamics of civil and criminal litigation. Law and politics, judicial selection, and impact of political factors on judicial decisions. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 347A.course_name: American Constitutional Law: Institutional Powers and Constraints
POL S 347A.course_description:
POL S 347A - American Constitutional Law: Institutional Powers and Constraints  Units: 3 GE-AIGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: American Politics
Substantive principles of American constitutional law. Constitutionally provided powers of and constraints on government action as defined by the United States Supreme Court. May include study of judicial review, commerce clause, federalism, and separation of powers. Satisfies graduation requirement in United States Constitution. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 347B.course_name: American Constitutional Law: Civil Rights and Civil Liberties
POL S 347B.course_description:
POL S 347B - American Constitutional Law: Civil Rights and Civil Liberties  Units: 3 GE-AIGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: American Politics
Substantive principles of American constitutional law. Civil rights and liberties protected by the Constitution against government action. May include discussion of freedom of speech, religion, press, assembly, as well as defendants’ rights and protection from discrimination. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Satisfies graduation requirement in United States Constitution.

POL S 348.course_name: The Supreme Court and Contemporary Issues
POL S 348.course_description:
POL S 348 - The Supreme Court and Contemporary Issues  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: American Politics
Recent decisions of the Supreme Court of the United States and their relationship to contemporary political and social issues. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Not open to students with credit in both POL S 347A  and POL S 347B .

POL S 356.course_description:
POL S 356 - European Politics  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: Comparative Politics
Politics of the European Union and Western Europe. Contemporary regional challenges to include Euroskepticism, immigration, independence, and populism. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 357.course_description:
POL S 357 - British Politics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: Comparative Politics
History and institutions of the British political system. The monarchy, nationalism and devolution, political parties, relationships with the European Union and Ireland, and the Westminster model of politics.
  Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 359.course_name: Government and Politics in Russia and Eurasia
POL S 359.course_description:
POL S 359 - Government and Politics in Russia and Eurasia  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: Comparative Politics
Transformations of economic, political, and social systems in Russia and the republics of the former Soviet Union. Eurasian union, its implications and prospects for global and regional politics. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 361.course_name: Governments and Politics of the Developing Areas
POL S 361.course_description:
POL S 361 - Governments and Politics of the Developing Areas  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: Comparative Politics
Relationship between economic development and socio-political change in developing countries. Models of development. Role of domestic politics and international institutions. Maximum Credits: 3Note: This course satisfies the general education cultural diversity requirement.

POL S 362.course_name: Governments and Politics of East Asia
POL S 362.course_description:
POL S 362 - Governments and Politics of East Asia  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: Comparative Politics
Change and continuity in foreign policies and internal political institutions of China, Japan, North and South Korea, and Taiwan. Maximum Credits: 3Note: This course satisfies the general education cultural diversity requirement.

POL S 363.course_name: Governments and Politics of the Middle East
POL S 363.course_description:
POL S 363 - Governments and Politics of the Middle East  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: Comparative Politics
Contemporary states in the Middle East. Authoritarianism in the region. Relations between Middle Eastern and Western countries. Maximum Credits: 3Note: This course satisfies the general education cultural diversity requirement.

POL S 364.course_description:
POL S 364 - Political Change in Modern Africa  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: Comparative Politics
Dynamics of political and social change in modern Africa, to include gender issues, e.g. LGBTQ and women’s rights. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 365.course_description:
POL S 365 - Chinese Politics  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: Comparative Politics
In-depth study of contemporary politics, economic development, and political history of China and Taiwan. External relationship between China, Taiwan, and the U.S. Maximum Credits: 3Note: This course satisfies the general education cultural diversity requirement.

POL S 366.course_description:
POL S 366 - Latin American Politics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: LATAM 366 . Field of Study: Comparative Politics
Introduction to Latin American politics. Knowledge of political change and political systems in Latin America, viewed historically and comparatively, using concepts and theories applicable to more general political analysis. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 370.course_description:
POL S 370 - Political Violence  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: International Politics
Underlying conditions, expressions, and consequences of violence within political systems.
  Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 375.course_description:
POL S 375 - Global Politics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: International Politics
Critical and prevailing theories of international relations; innovation, power politics, social resistance; international organizations and law; economy and the environment, global politics; contemporary and historical case studies. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 380.course_name: Human Rights in a Global Perspective
POL S 380.course_description:
POL S 380 - Human Rights in a Global Perspective  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: International Politics
Critical and prevailing theories of human rights; historical developments; global and regional human rights organizations and treaties; contemporary and historical controversies on human rights. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 390W.course_description: POL S 390W - Writing About Politics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Satisfies Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement for students who have completed 60 units; and completed General Education requirements in Communication and Critical Thinking. Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required: Test scores or verification of exemption; copy of transcript.Writing in various political contexts and settings. Citing sources appropriately, critiquing opposing viewpoints, developing coherent political arguments, providing evidence to support conclusions, and revising. Maximum Credits: 3Note: This course may not be used toward the major or minor in political science.

POL S 393.course_description:
POL S 393 - Hostler Institute on World Affairs  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: International Politics
Exploration of a particular theme in global politics, such as global justice. Selected weeks of guest lectures from prominent scholars, diplomats, and activists. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 406.course_description:
POL S 406 - Democracy and Mass Society  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: Political Theory
