Origins and development of democracy as an idea and political reality. Historical and ongoing struggles for mass democracy to include the English Civil War, the Haitian and Russian Revolutions, and the Spanish Civil War. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 422.course_description:
POL S 422 - Urban Politics  Units: 3 GE-AIGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: American Politics
Politics and policy issues in urban areas to include central cities and suburbs. Urban sprawl, suburbanization, local/state/federal relations, regional governance, and local electoral dynamics. Urban policy issues to include public safety, housing, and transportation.  Maximum Credits: 3Note: Meets graduation requirement in California state and local government. Will satisfy all requirements in American Institutions when taken with POL S 102 , POL S 305 , POL S 320 .

POL S 425.course_description:
POL S 425 - Psychology of Politics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): POL S 102 .Field of Study: American Politics
Psychological and social roots of behavior of activists, elected officials, and the mass public. Applications in political science to include campaigns and elections, discrimination, political conflict, public opinion, public policy, and social justice. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 426.course_description:
POL S 426 - Political Communication  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: American Politics
Communication as a political process; the effects of political communication on individuals and groups. May include a substantial amount of material about foreign political systems. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 428.course_description:
POL S 428 - Campaigns and Elections  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): POL S 102 .Field of Study: American Politics
Campaigns and elections are essential to proper functioning of democracy. Theories concerning decision-making processes of individual voters, actors who seek to influence electoral outcomes, and the strategies used by organized political campaigns in attempt to affect voting behavior. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 430.course_description:
POL S 430 - Immigration and Border Politics  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: LATAM 430 . Prerequisite(s): Completion of the American Institutions requirement.Field of Study: American Politics
U.S. immigration and border politics within a global and historical perspective. Transformations of sovereignty, communities, identity, and rights within an era of mass migration and economic interdependence. Policy and popular debates about admission, border control, and the incorporation of migrants. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 435.course_name: Power and Poverty in the United States
POL S 435.course_description:
POL S 435 - Power and Poverty in the United States  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: American Politics
Impact of government upon income inequality and poverty in the United States. Examines programs of U.S. welfare state in comparative perspective and their successes and failures. Minimum standards for distributional justice and inquiries into obligations we have toward our fellow citizens. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 436.course_description:
POL S 436 - The American Presidency  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): POL S 102 .Field of Study: American Politics
History of the presidency, individuals to hold the office, and theoretical approaches to understanding the presidency as an institution. Modern theories of presidential power. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 440.course_description:
POL S 440 - Food Justice  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Same As: GEOG 440 . Prerequisite(s): POL S 102  or GEOG 102 .Field of Study: American Politics
Food justice from perspectives of theory, institutions, markets, law, ethics, social mobilization, politics, and ecology. Political strategies, capabilities of food justice organizations; movements aimed at creating fair, healthy, sustainable food systems locally and globally. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 450.course_description: POL S 450 - Study Abroad in Political Science  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing. See Class Schedule for additional prerequisites.Selected topics in political science.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 6Note: Course taught abroad through a program approved by political science department to include SDSU faculty-led courses abroad. International internships may receive political science credit. See Class Schedule for specific content and geographic location.

POL S 479.course_description:
POL S 479 - National Security Policy  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: International Politics
Theoretical approaches to the politics, practice, and study of national security; major historical developments in US national security strategy; contemporary challenges to security. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 482.course_description:
POL S 482 - United States-Latin American Relations  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Field of Study: International Politics
Diplomatic, military, and political relations between the United States and Latin America. Cold War and its legacies, colonialism and dependency, counter-insurgency, counter-narcotics, and counter-terrorism; economic relations, human rights, military intervention, popular movements, and revolutions. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 485.course_description:
POL S 485 - Politics of Globalization  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): POL S 103  or six units of political science.Field of Study: International Politics
Relationship of culture and politics to the global economy; contemporary controversies; critical and prevailing theories of global capitalism; divisions between rich and poor nations; leading global economic institutions; major historical developments. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 495.course_description: POL S 495 - Internship in Local Politics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Limited to junior and senior political science majors and three upper division units within the American politics field.Juniors and Seniors in the major choose internships within San Diego County in government agencies, offices of elected officials, or others approved by instructor. Requires 80 hours of fieldwork and periodic analytical essays. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 496.course_description: POL S 496 - Experimental Topics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected topics.  May be repeated with new content and used for field-specific credits for the major as approved by the department. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

POL S 497A.course_description: POL S 497A - Senior Thesis Preparation  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing and consent of department thesis adviser. Limited to political science majors with a cumulative 3.0 GPA in upper division political science courses.Preparation for written thesis to include full literature review and formal research proposal. To be taken prior to POL S 497B . Maximum Credits: 3Note: Not open to students with credit in POL S 497B .

POL S 497B.course_description: POL S 497B - Senior Thesis  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): POL S 497A  and consent of department thesis adviser. Limited to senior political science majors with a cumulative 3.0 GPA in upper division political science courses.Completion of written thesis. Satisfies capstone requirement for political science majors. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Can only be taken following successful completion of POL S 497A .

POL S 498.course_description: POL S 498 - Internship in National Politics  Units: 6-12 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.Students will be assigned to political agencies in Washington, D.C., such as congressional staffs, interest groups, executive agencies, legal/judicial offices and political party committees. Maximum Credits: 12Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to the major in political science; three units applicable to the minor in political science.Note: For information on internship opportunities, especially state politics, refer to the internship section on the department website.

POL S 499.course_description: POL S 499 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Twelve upper division units in political science and consent of the instructor. Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6

POL S 507.course_description:
POL S 507 - Marx and Marxism  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Three units in political theory and upper division or graduate standing.Field of Study: Political Theory
Marxism examined as an important tradition of political thought and as a political movement. Theoretical and political debates in the development of Marxism, including works by Marx, Engels, Luxemburg, Lenin, and Trotsky. Contemporary significance of Marxism. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 510.course_description:
POL S 510 - Contemporary Political Thought  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): POL S 301B  or POL S 302  or POL S 305  or POL S 406  and upper division or graduate standing.Field of Study: Political Theory
Contemporary political questions and theoretical attempts to address them. Debates about justice, citizenship, and multiculturalism; as well as controversies over nature and scope of politics. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 530.course_description:
POL S 530 - Political Parties  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division or graduate standing.Field of Study: Comparative Politics
What parties are, why they exist, and how they differ within and across advanced democracies. Party competition during elections and in governing processes. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 531.course_description:
POL S 531 - Movements, Groups, and Political Activism  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): POL S 101 . Upper division or graduate standing.Field of Study: American Politics
Interest group and social movement activism. Electoral involvement, organizational behavior, and protests. Mass society, pluralism, and power elite. Identity and inequality in movement and organizational politics. International political movements. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 533.course_description:
POL S 533 - Democracy in America  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): POL S 102 . Upper division or graduate standing.Field of Study: American Politics
Quality and quantity of democratic experience in contemporary America. Construction of American regime, arrangement of power within that regime, expansion and contraction of citizen participation, and principles that Americans generally espouse. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 535.course_description:
POL S 535 - Gender and Politics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): POL S 101 . Upper division or graduate standing.Field of Study: American Politics
How gender matters in understanding key political science concepts including democracy, public/private participation and representation. Women involved in political institutions as elected officials, activists, and policy makers from U.S. and comparative perspectives. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 541.course_description:
POL S 541 - Special Problems in Public Law  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): POL S 346 , POL S 347A , POL S 347B , or POL S 348 , and upper division or graduate standing.Field of Study: American Politics
Issues of contemporary relevance in field of public law, examining legal, moral, and political implications. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 555.course_description:
POL S 555 - Comparative Political Systems  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division or graduate standing.Field of Study: Comparative Politics
An examination of selected political and governmental systems for purposes of comparative study and analysis to determine similarities, differences and general patterns and universals among political systems. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 560.course_name: Comparative Citizenship in Policy and Practice
POL S 560.course_description:
POL S 560 - Comparative Citizenship in Policy and Practice  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division or graduate standing. Field of Study: Comparative Politics
How different countries address issues of exclusion and membership, marginality and privilege. Policies and practice in relation to indigenous groups, migrants, and ethnic / racial minorities. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 562.course_name: Religion and Politics in Comparative Perspective
POL S 562.course_description:
POL S 562 - Religion and Politics in Comparative Perspective  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division or graduate standing.Field of Study: Comparative Politics
Various types of relationships between contemporary states and religious institutions. Concepts and theories on religion and politics. Cases of state-religion interaction. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 564.course_description:
POL S 564 - Political Ecology of Latin America  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division or graduate standing.Field of Study: Comparative Politics
Ecology and politics of Latin America and the Caribbean. Environmental politics with related policy challenges of economic growth, equity, and social justice. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 565.course_description:
POL S 565 - Nations and Nationalism  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division or graduate standing.Field of Study: Comparative Politics
Debates surrounding origins, meaning and future of nationalism, and its most common embodiment, the nation-state form. Theoretical analyses of phenomenon and empirical case studies. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 566.course_description:
POL S 566 - Political Change in Latin America  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division or graduate standing.Field of Study: Comparative Politics
Latin American political systems and forces of political change, analyzed comparatively and historically, applying general concepts and theories of comparative politics. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 568.course_description:
POL S 568 - Mexican Politics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division or graduate standing.Field of Study: Comparative Politics
Historical, institutional, and comparative analysis of Mexican politics and political change: contemporary issues, economic and foreign policy, popular movements, and the state and the party system. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 575.course_name: International Relations of the Pacific Rim
POL S 575.course_description:
POL S 575 - International Relations of the Pacific Rim  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): POL S 362  or POL S 375  and upper division or graduate standing.Field of Study: International Politics
Conflict and cooperation among nations of the Pacific Rim; economic, historical, and political factors that shape interstate relations and regional dynamics. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 577.course_description:
POL S 577 - Politics of International Law  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division or graduate standing.Field of Study: International Politics
Relationship of international law to politics; contemporary and historical issues; critical and prevailing perspectives on the significance of international law and its relationship to international politics; fundamental principles of international law; major historical developments; UN Charter and other international treaties. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 596.course_description: POL S 596 - Topics in Political Science  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division or graduate standing.Selected topics in political science.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units of 596 Credit for 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

POL S 603.course_name: Seminar in Foundations of Public Policy
POL S 603.course_description: POL S 603 - Seminar in Foundations of Public Policy  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.Theory and practice of the policy making process. Policy design, agenda setting, policy tools, and implementation. Examination of different methods used for policy analysis. Maximum Credits: 3

POL S 605.course_description: POL S 605 - Seminar in Political Theory  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.

POL S 615.course_name: Seminar in Research Design and Analysis in Political Science
POL S 615.course_description: POL S 615 - Seminar in Research Design and Analysis in Political Science  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate Standing.Modeling and design of research projects. Theoretical understanding and logic of social science analysis. Hypothesis specification. Data collection, measurement, testing.Formerly numbered Political Science 515. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 750A.course_description: P H 750A - Advanced Field Practice: Epidemiology  Units: 3-6 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): P H 650 .Field instruction in public health setting. Application of public health principles and skills to public health problems. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units of P H 750 applicable to a master’s degree.

P H 750D.course_description: P H 750D - Advanced Field Practice: Environmental Health  Units: 3-6 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): P H 650 .Field instruction in public health setting. Application of public health principles and skills to public health problems. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units of P H 750 applicable to a master’s degree.

P H 750E.course_name: Advanced Field Practice: Health Management and Policy
P H 750E.course_description: P H 750E - Advanced Field Practice: Health Management and Policy  Units: 3-6 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): P H 650 .Field instruction in public health setting. Application of public health principles and skills to public health problems. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units of P H 750 applicable to a master’s degree.

P H 750F.course_name: Advanced Field Practice: Health Promotion and Behavioral Science
P H 750F.course_description: P H 750F - Advanced Field Practice: Health Promotion and Behavioral Science  Units: 3-6 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): P H 650 .Field instruction in public health setting. Application of public health principles and skills to public health problems. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units of P H 750 applicable to a master’s degree.

P H 762.course_description: P H 762 - Behavioral Medicine  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 661  and P H 662 .Behavioral management approaches to health care problems. Diseases and conditions that arise from physical, psychological and environmental causes; behavioral interventions that attenuate disease process and improve compliance. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 780.course_description: P H 780 - Global Health I  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 601  and P H 602 .Principles of global health. Challenges of urbanization and migration to include demography; main causes of morbidity and mortality, including infectious agents; reproductive health; cultural diversity; and global preparedness. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 781.course_description: P H 781 - Global Health II  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 780 .Global health to include trends and impacts of chronic physical and mental disease; infectious diseases of global importance; nutritional status and disease patterns; resource constrained environments, and design of international health organizations and systems. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 797.course_description: P H 797 - Research  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.Research in one of the fields of public health. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: Six units applicable to a master’s degree. Maximum combined credit six units of P H 797 and P H 798 applicable to a master’s degree.

P H 798.course_description: P H 798 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of staff, to be arranged with the director and instructor.Special Study under supervision of faculty member.  Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: Six units applicable to a master’s degree. Maximum combined credit six units of P H 797 and P H 798 applicable to a master’s degree.

P H 799A.course_description: P H 799A - Thesis  Units: 3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): An officially appointed thesis committee and advancement to candidacy.Preparation of a project or thesis for the master’s degree.

P H 799B.course_description: P H 799B - Thesis Extension  Units: 0 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Prior registration in Thesis 799A with an assigned grade symbol of RP.Registration required in any semester or term following assignment of RP in Course 799A in which the student expects to use the facilities and resources of the university; also student must be registered in the course when the completed thesis is granted final approval. Maximum Credits: 0

P H 799C.course_description: P H 799C - Comprehensive Examination Extension  Units: 0 Grading Method: Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Completion or concurrent enrollment in degree program courses.Registration required of students whose only requirement is completion of the comprehensive examination for the master’s degree. Registration in 799C limited to two semesters.

P H 800.course_description: P H 800 - Seminar  Units: 1-9 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to the doctoral program.Investigation of a particular topic or issue, emphasis on empirical research; topic to be announced in the Class Schedule. Maximum Credits: 9Maximum Credit Statement: nine units applicable to a doctoral degree.

P H 820A.course_description: P H 820A - Modern Epidemiology Methods I  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 601  and P H 627  with a grade of A- (3.7) or better in each course.Fundamentals of causal inference, quantitative measures of occurrence, association and effect, study design. Data analysis and interpretation, sources and mitigation of bias, review and critical appraisal of peer-reviewed literature. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 820B.course_description: P H 820B - Modern Epidemiology Methods II  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 820A  with a grade of B (3.0) or better.Continuing examination of causal inference, quantitative measures of occurrence, association and effect, study design. Data analysis and interpretation, sources and mitigation of bias, review and critical appraisal of peer-reviewed literature. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 823.course_description: P H 823 - Case-Control Studies  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 601 , P H 623 , and P H 627 . Recommended: P H 724 .Design, conduct, and analysis of case-control studies. Methodologic issues, control of biases and misclassification errors, proper use of interpretation of stratification and logistic regression in study of diseases of multifactorial etiology. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 824.course_description: P H 824 - Cohort Studies  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 601 , P H 623 , and P H 627 . Recommended: P H 724 .Design, analysis, and application of cohort studies. Cohort study designs, importance of time-varying exposures and outcomes, external and internal validity, and in-depth treatment of approaches to analysis based on cohort sampling methods. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 826.course_description: P H 826 - Analysis of Case-Control Studies  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 623  and P H 627 .Statistical methods and applications for analyzing case-control studies. Use of conditional and unconditional logistic regression and approaches for incorporating confounding and interaction in models. Computer applications included. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 827.course_description: P H 827 - Analysis of Cohort Studies  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 623  and P H 627 .Statistical models for analyzing cohort studies including general regression methodology, generalized linear models, generalized estimating equations, random effects models and survival analysis. Emphasis on conceptual understanding of these models, implementation with statistical software, and interpretation. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 850.course_description: P H 850 - Global Health Practicum  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 781 , P H 800 , P H 880 .An international research activity, program evaluation, participation in a multinational organization internship, or field work with government or non-governmental organizations. This practicum is required for completion of the Ph.D. in global health under supervision of program directors. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 861.course_description: P H 861 - Behavioral Measurement  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Techniques for assessing behaviors related to health and health risks in key content areas. Multimodel assessment and validation procedures. Students will demonstrate ability to create new measures based on theory and reliability and validity of these measures, using multimodel assessment procedures. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 862.course_name: Advanced Theoretical Foundations of Health Behavior Research and Applications
P H 862.course_description: P H 862 - Advanced Theoretical Foundations of Health Behavior Research and Applications  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Philosophy of science, role of theory development and design and conduct of research, with integration of behavioral and biological theories serving as foundation for behavioral science in public health. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 863.course_name: Advanced Communication Technology as Applied to Health Behavioral Interventions
P H 863.course_description: P H 863 - Advanced Communication Technology as Applied to Health Behavioral Interventions  Units: 3  Prerequisite(s): P H 663 , admission to the doctoral program, and consent of instructor.Health communication theory and social marketing practice as applied to public health behavior change. Audience segmentation, formative research channel selection, and message development applied to chronic and infectious disease prevention.

P H 864.course_description: P H 864 - Advanced Research Methods  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Joint Doctoral Program in public health with a concentration in health behavior.Research process and study design to include conceptualizing research questions and hypotheses, observational study designs, quasi-experimental and experimental study designs, and introduction to qualitative research and mixed methods. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 866.course_name: Global Issues in Health Behavior Research and Application
P H 866.course_description: P H 866 - Global Issues in Health Behavior Research and Application  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to the doctoral program and consent of instructor.Epidemics in infectious diseases, environmental degradation, population explosion, and other problems with behavioral links threaten the world’s population. Global issues such as the role of behavior in disease, bioterrorism, and war. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 867.course_name: Seminar: Grantwriting for Health Behavior Researchers
P H 867.course_description: P H 867 - Seminar: Grantwriting for Health Behavior Researchers  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to Ph.D. in public health with a concentration in health behavior.Skills needed to compete for health behavior research funding. Grant proposal writing, submission, review, and revision processes. Background information about grant review procedures and funding mechanisms, with emphasis on national institutes of health. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 880.course_name: Seminar: Program Planning and Evaluation in International Settings
P H 880.course_description: P H 880 - Seminar: Program Planning and Evaluation in International Settings  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 780 .Theory and skills to evaluate research and service programs in international settings to include methods in program planning and evaluation, distinctions between research and evaluation, special considerations in cross-cultural settings, and transadaptation of planning and evaluation materials. Maximum Credits: 3

P H 897.course_description: P H 897 - Doctoral Research  Units: 1-15 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to the doctoral program.Independent investigation in the general field of the dissertation. Maximum Credits: 15

P H 898.course_description: P H 898 - Doctoral Special Study  Units: 1-9 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to the doctoral program.Individual study in the field of specialization. Maximum Credits: 9Maximum Credit Statement: nine units applicable to a doctoral degree.

P H 899.course_description:
P H 899 - Dr.P.H. Dissertation  Units: 1-12 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 901, P H 902, P H 903, P H 904, P H 905, P H 906A or P H 906B, P H 907, P H 908, P H 909, P H 910; admission to the Public Health, Concentration in Executive Management, Dr.P.H. program, or the Public Health, Concentration in Global Health Management, Dr.P.H. program, or instructor consent. Preparation of a comprehensive program plan, strategic plan, or policy analysis that demonstrates a systems approach to addressing a public health issue, engaging individuals from multiple disciplines and perspectives and collaboration across organizations, demonstrating the application of doctoral-level competencies.  May be repeated with consent of instructor.  Maximum Credits: 12Maximum Credit Statement: Twelve units with consent of instructor.Note: Cohort model; P H 901 through P H 910 must be taken sequentially. This is the final course of the cohort model; students must have completed all required courses prior to enrolling in this course.
 Back to Top | Print-Friendly Page (opens a new window)

P H 901.course_description: P H 901 - Executive Management of Operations  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Public Health, Concentration in Executive Management, Dr.P.H. program, or the Public Health, Concentration in Global Health Management, Dr.P.H. program, or instructor consent. Highlight and practice essential knowledge and skills critical for executive management and leadership at the organization level, including analysis of one’s own capabilities for executive management and leadership. Note: Cohort model; P H 901 through P H 910 must be taken sequentially.

P H 902.course_name: Executive Management of External, Community, and Systems Relationships
P H 902.course_description: P H 902 - Executive Management of External, Community, and Systems Relationships  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 901; admission to the Public Health, Concentration in Executive Management, Dr.P.H. program, or the Public Health, Concentration in Global Health Management, Dr.P.H. program, or instructor consent. Master the executive management skills needed for successful interaction with community health system stakeholders external to one’s own organization, including identifying and analyzing the entities, building partnerships, and sharing community problem-solving.    Note: Cohort model; P H 901 through P H 910 must be taken sequentially.

P H 903.course_description: P H 903 - Policy, Advocacy, and Ethics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 901 and P H 902; admission to the Public Health, Concentration in Executive Management, Dr.P.H. program, or the Public Health, Concentration in Global Health Management, Dr.P.H. program, or instructor consent. Master the skills needed by a healthcare executive to provide leadership in policy analysis, policy development and implementation, and policy promotion through advocacy. Issues of ethics and equity receive special consideration.  Note: Cohort model; P H 901 through P H 910 must be taken sequentially.

P H 904.course_name: Global Health for Public Health Executives
P H 904.course_description: P H 904 - Global Health for Public Health Executives  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 901, P H 902, P H 903; admission to the Public Health, Concentration in Executive Management, Dr.P.H. program, or the Public Health, Concentration in Global Health Management, Dr.P.H. program, or instructor consent. Enhance the knowledge and skills needed for leadership and executive management of health programs that are affected by global health issues; become familiar with a wide range of global health systems. Note: Cohort model; P H 901 through P H 910 must be taken sequentially.

P H 905.course_description: P H 905 - Community Health Systems Management  Units: 6 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 901, P H 902, P H 903, and P H 904.Introduction to a wide range of county/community health organizations to determine if the organizations meet the needs of the populations they serve; visits to eight health departments/services in the Southern California region. Note: Students will be traveling with a faculty member to a variety of public health organizations in the Southern California region. Cohort model; P H 901 through P H 910 must be taken sequentially.

P H 906A.course_name: Executive Management of Public Health in the USA
P H 906A.course_description: P H 906A - Executive Management of Public Health in the USA  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 901, P H 902, P H 903, P H 904, P H 905; admission to the Public Health, Concentration in Executive Management, Dr.P.H. program, or the Public Health, Concentration in Global Health Management, Dr.P.H. program, or instructor consent.Critique the complex organizations and operations of the U.S. public health system using the ten essential functions of public health as a foundation for managing agencies and programs. Note: Cohort model; P H 901 through P H 910 must be taken sequentially.

P H 906B.course_name: Executive Management of Global and Migrant Health
P H 906B.course_description: P H 906B - Executive Management of Global and Migrant Health  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 901, P H 902, P H 903, P H 904, P H 905; admission to the Public Health, Concentration in Executive Management, Dr.P.H. program, or the Public Health, Concentration in Global Health Management, Dr.P.H. program, or instructor consent. Strengthen knowledge and skills needed for leadership and executive management of global health organizations, departments, and programs to address health issues of migrants; understand the effects that international migration has on communities in the countries of origin, transit, and destination.  Note: Cohort model; P H 901 through P H 910 must be taken sequentially.

P H 907.course_description:
P H 907 - Public Finance for Public Health  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 901, P H 902, P H 903, P H 904, P H 905, P H 906A or P H 906B; admission to the Public Health, Concentration in Executive Management, Dr.P.H. program, or the Public Health, Concentration in Global Health Management, Dr.P.H. program, or instructor consent.Designed to enhance knowledge and skills for public service, fiduciary responsibility, financial theories of taxation and redistribution of goods and services for the creation of equilibrium in society as related to public health. Note: Cohort model; P H 901 through P H 910 must be taken sequentially. 
 Back to Top | Print-Friendly Page (opens a new window)

P H 908.course_description: P H 908 - Executive Management of Communications  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 901, P H 902, P H 903, P H 904, P H 905, P H 906A or P H 906B, P H 907; admission to the Public Health, Concentration in Executive Management, Dr.P.H. program, or the Public Health, Concentration in Global Health Management, Dr.P.H. program, or instructor consent. Analyze how communications are used most effectively for management and leadership of health programs; create and deliver communications targeted for specific purposes and designated target audiences.   Note: Cohort model; P H 901 through P H 910 must be taken sequentially.

P H 909.course_description: P H 909 - Executive Management of Human Resources  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 901, P H 902, P H 903, P H 904, P H 905, P H 906A or P H 906B, P H 907, P H 908; admission to the Public Health, Concentration in Executive Management, Dr.P.H. program, or the Public Health, Concentration in Global Health Management, Dr.P.H. program, or instructor consent. Practice-oriented; build skills in interacting with people internal and external to organization; develope a well-qualified workforce; executive level management in interactions with staff, professionals, teams, stakeholders, clients, students; education and relationships with educational institutions for a well-educated workforce and public. Note: Cohort model; P H 901 through P H 910 must be taken sequentially.

P H 910.course_name: Executive Management of Strategic Planning and Marketing
P H 910.course_description: P H 910 - Executive Management of Strategic Planning and Marketing  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 901, P H 902, P H 903, P H 904, P H 905, P H 906A or P H 906B, P H 907, P H 908, P H 909; admission to the Public Health, Concentration in Executive Management, Dr.P.H. program, or the Public Health, Concentration in Global Health Management, Dr.P.H. program, or instructor consent. Strengthen executive-level skills in strategic planning and marketing by developing a strategic plan for a new community-wide collaborative formed to address a multi-faceted public health challenge; creating governance for shared decision-making among various stakeholder organizations. Note: Cohort model; P H 901 through P H 910 must be taken sequentially.

P H 950.course_description: P H 950 - Advanced Practice Experience  Units: 6 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): P H 901, P H 902, P H 903, P H 904, P H 905, P H 906A or P H 906B, P H 907, P H 908, P H 909. Admission to the Public Health, Concentration in Executive Management, Dr.P.H. program, or the Public Health, Concentration in Global Health Management, Dr.P.H. program, or instructor consent. Independent advanced practice experience. Demonstrate executive management skills by completing a management or leadership project for an organization, defined by the student in conjunction with an organization mentor and faculty adviser.  Note: Exact subject of project and schedule for completion of all requirements for the course will be determined by the student, in conjunction with the organizational mentor and faculty adviser.

RTM 100.course_description: RTM 100 - Sustainable Self-Development  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Applications, definitions, key concepts, measures, and theories of sustainable development of individuals and society. Establishment of effective and potentially fulfilling sustainability lifestyle plan for the future. Interrelationships between biodiversity and society.Formerly numbered Professional Studies and Fine Arts 100. Maximum Credits: 3

RTM 102.course_name: Wellness and Recreation for Life Through Surfing
RTM 102.course_description: RTM 102 - Wellness and Recreation for Life Through Surfing  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Links between recreation, society, and wellness through surfing culture and lifestyle. Wellness dimensions and incorporation throughout one’s life via surfing or other recreation-driven lifestyles. Maximum Credits: 3

RTM 200.course_description: RTM 200 - Recreation, Travel, and Self-Awareness  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC How recreation and travel are influenced by economic, environmental, political, and socio-cultural forces. Impacts of recreation and travel on well-being and self-awareness. Maximum Credits: 3

RTM 284.course_description: RTM 284 - Supervised Field Work  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor or department chair and 125 hours experience in recreation leadership.Observation and participation in community recreation leadership. Practical experience in a variety of recreational settings. Eight hours per week at an agency. Maximum Credits: 3

RTM 290.course_name: Quantitative and Qualitative Literacy in Tourism
RTM 290.course_description: RTM 290 - Quantitative and Qualitative Literacy in Tourism  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s):  HTM 201  with a minimum grade of C (2.0).Quantitative and qualitative methods in hospitality, recreation, and tourism fields. Gathering data from sources, summarizing data points, analyses, reporting findings/results, conclusions and recommendations. Maximum Credits: 3

RTM 296.course_description: RTM 296 - Experimental Topics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected topics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

RTM 301.course_description: RTM 301 - Service Leadership Development  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC  Two lectures and two hours of activity.Prerequisite(s): HTM 201 .Communication, creativity, group dynamics and leadership, problem solving, program planning, and publicity in recreation and tourism contexts. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Not open to students with credit in RTM 107 .

RTM 304.course_description: RTM 304 - Leisure and Tourism  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Study of leisure and its impact on contemporary life; issues affecting recreation in today’s urbanized society. Maximum Credits: 3

RTM 305.course_description: RTM 305 - Wilderness and the Leisure Experience  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): BIOL 100  or BIOL 101 .Values of protected landscapes to individuals and society. Scientific, political, international, and ethical dimensions of natural landscapes. Implications for protection, visitor management, and sustainable tourism. Maximum Credits: 3

RTM 340.course_description: RTM 340 - Conduct of Recreational Sports  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC  Three lectures plus outside practical experience in the conduct of recreational sports programs.Organization of competition, community sports programs, administration of intramural athletics, and techniques of officiating. Maximum Credits: 3

RTM 351.course_description: RTM 351 - Recreation Therapy and Special Populations  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Sociopsychological aspects of special populations and their implications for leisure pursuits. Field trips may be included. Maximum Credits: 3

RTM 360.course_description: RTM 360 - Recreation and Tourism Management  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.Through experiential learning incorporating local organizations, students gain real-world experience in, recreation and tourism management to include: needs assessment and services development; marketing; budget development; revenue generation; assets management; risk management; strategic planning; operation of facilities/areas; and, human resources. Maximum Credits: 3

RTM 396W.course_description: RTM 396W - Writing in Recreation Settings  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Satisfies Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement for students who have completed 60 units; and completed General Education requirements in Communication and Critical Thinking. Proof of completion of prerequisite(s) required: Test scores or verification of exemption; copy of transcript.Theory and practice of writing in the field of recreation and parks with application to various settings. Maximum Credits: 3

RTM 404.course_description: RTM 404 - Cross-Cultural Perspectives of Tourism  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Concepts, definitions, and measures of essential cultural components of tourism. Integrated view of interrelated socio-cultural tourism issues with an understanding and appreciation of diverse cultures. Maximum Credits: 3Note: This course satisfies the general education cultural diversity requirement.

RTM 468.course_name: Marketing, Financing, and Assessment in Recreation and Tourism Management
RTM 468.course_description: RTM 468 - Marketing, Financing, and Assessment in Recreation and Tourism Management  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Marketing, financing, and assessment specifically related to recreation and tourism management to include services development, pricing, promotion, distribution; budget development, revenue generation, assets management, controls; evaluation and research process as they relate to service development and delivery. Maximum Credits: 3

RTM 469.course_name: Administration and Operation of Recreation and Tourism Agencies
RTM 469.course_description: RTM 469 - Administration and Operation of Recreation and Tourism Agencies  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): RTM 470  or RTM 475 .Administrative and operational aspects of managing and leading in recreation and tourism agencies to include liability, risk management, administrative regulations; information/decision systems in organizations; strategic planning; operation of facilities/areas; human resource functions related to successful service delivery. Maximum Credits: 3

RTM 470.course_description: RTM 470 - Global Sustainable Tourism Management  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): HTM 201 .Global tourism management, economics, development and sustainability. Social, cultural, and environmental impact indicators and management tools for sustainable development. Maximum Credits: 3

RTM 475.course_description: RTM 475 - Commercial Recreation and Attractions Management  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Analysis of commercial recreation field, including design, development, programming and marketing aspects of various commercial recreation enterprises. Maximum Credits: 3

RTM 477.course_description: RTM 477 - Sustainable Tourism Planning  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): HTM 201 .Nature and scope of sustainable tourism planning. Approaches, principles, and processes for creating sustainability value in tourism. Sustainability assessment and corporate social responsibility for tourism amenities, attractions, services, transportation and facilities. Maximum Credits: 3

RTM 483.course_description: RTM 483 - Outdoor Education and Camp Administration  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): HTM 201 .Philosophy, theory, methods, application, and scope of outdoor education in recreation and ecotourism camp settings. Management of resident, day, and travel camps. Maximum Credits: 3

RTM 484.course_description: RTM 484 - Directed Leadership  Units: 3 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit  One lecture and eight hours of supervised activity.Prerequisite(s): RTM 284 .Supervised leadership experience in public and private recreation agencies. Maximum Credits: 6

RTM 485.course_description: RTM 485 - Outdoor Recreation Planning and Policy  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Nature and scope of recreation in nonurban areas. Public demand for recreation and its impact on natural resources. Management, planning, research and operation of regional and national park and recreation areas. Maximum Credits: 3

RTM 487.course_description: RTM 487 - Environmental and Cultural Interpretation  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): HTM 201 .Philosophy, theory, methods, application, and scope of cultural interpretation in recreation and tourism settings. Maximum Credits: 3

RTM 489.course_description: RTM 489 - Outdoor Leadership and Adventure Programming  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): RTM 305 .Theoretical principles and experience in leadership, judgment, and decision making in outdoor adventure programming. Maximum Credits: 3

RTM 496.course_description: RTM 496 - Experimental Topics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected topics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

RTM 498.course_name: Internship in Recreation and Tourism Management
RTM 498.course_description: RTM 498 - Internship in Recreation and Tourism Management  Units: 6-12 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit  Twenty off-campus hours required per week for 6-unit program, or 40 off-campus hours required per week for 12-unit programs.Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor or department chair, completion of all required lower division recreation courses, and completion of both Standard or Multimedia First Aid certificate and CPR certificate by end of semester.For six unit internship: 250 hours of professional work experience in recreation and tourism management. Maximum Credits: 12Note: For 12 unit internship: 500 hours required Credit for course requires completion of ePortfolio.

RTM 499.course_description: RTM 499 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of special study adviser. Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6

R A 600.course_description: R A 600 - Seminar  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of graduate adviser.An intensive study in specific areas of regulatory affairs.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.Note: See Class Schedule for specific content.

R A 601.course_name: Pharmaceutical, Biotechnology, and Medical Device Industries
R A 601.course_description: R A 601 - Pharmaceutical, Biotechnology, and Medical Device Industries  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Introduction and foundational knowledge of biotechnology, medical device, and pharmaceutical industries. Commercialization- associated activities to include chemical synthesis, control, drug discovery, manufacturing, marketing, post-marketing surveillance, quality assurance, and regulatory affairs. Company organization and product development. Maximum Credits: 3

R A 602.course_description: R A 602 - Food and Drug Law  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): R A 601 .Laws and regulations enforced by the FDA for biotechnology, medical device, pharmaceutical, and related industries. Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, Freedom of Information Act, related laws, and the U.S. legal system. Laws and regulations affecting biologics, cosmetics, devices and diagnostics, drugs, foods, tobacco products, and veterinary products. Combination products, import/ export requirements, international regulations, orphan products, and product liability. Maximum Credits: 3

R A 605.course_name: Medical/Scientific Writing for Life Science Professionals
R A 605.course_description: R A 605 - Medical/Scientific Writing for Life Science Professionals  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): R A 601 .Writing conducted during the development of a new biologic or drug. Effective writing of regulatory documents to include analyses of scientific literature for critical appraisal of drugs, informed consents, and reports of laboratory results. Maximum Credits: 3

R A 696.course_description: R A 696 - Advanced Topics in Regulatory Affairs  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of graduate adviser.Selected topics in regulatory affairs.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 12Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Credit for 696 applicable to a master’s degree with approval of the graduate adviser.

R A 701.course_description: R A 701 - Regulatory Intelligence/Regulatory Strategy  Units: 2 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of graduate adviser.Regulatory intelligence involves gathering, monitoring, analyzing, and communicating regulatory information. This intelligence shapes regulatory strategy for product development and submission routes; develop skills required of regulatory affairs professionals to prepare and use regulatory intelligence to develop regulatory strategy recommendations. Maximum Credits: 2

R A 702.course_description: R A 702 - Pre-Approval Inspections  Units: 1 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of graduate adviser.To include requirements for hosting successful US FDA Pre-Approval Inspections (PAI) for small and large molecules, effective interpretation and application of current Good Manufacturing Practices (cGMPs), and the differences between FDA and EU requirements for the manufacture and control of pharmaceuticals. Maximum Credits: 1

R A 703.course_description: R A 703 - Introduction to Electronic Submissions  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of graduate adviser.To include introduction to elements of electronic submissions for drugs, biologics, and devices to health authorities. Electronic Common Technical Document (eCTD) and eCopy covered. Software practicum to create content, assign content to XML backbone, hyperlink documents, and validate compliance. Maximum Credits: 3

R A 705.course_name: Project Planning for the Biomedical Industries
R A 705.course_description: R A 705 - Project Planning for the Biomedical Industries  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.Introduction to strategies for effective management, planning, and scheduling of regulatory affairs activities and related tasks associated with project development in biomedical industries. Maximum Credits: 3

R A 750.course_name: Leadership for Change and Continuous Improvement
R A 750.course_description: R A 750 - Leadership for Change and Continuous Improvement  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.Control and facilitation of change at a variety of levels within the biotechnology industry. Strategic improvements to increase competitive advantages. Process improvement concepts and methods, quality and statistical tools, and their applications to leadership, manufacturing, and production challenges. Maximum Credits: 3

R A 761.course_name: Drug/Device Product Development and Regulation in Europe and the US
R A 761.course_description: R A 761 - Drug/Device Product Development and Regulation in Europe and the US  Units: 1 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of graduate adviser.The basic concepts of drug/device development, and regulatory and quality requirements in Europe and the US, providing exposure to emerging professions in the life science industry and builds skills interacting with these professionals in international environments. Maximum Credits: 1

R A 770.course_name: Current Good Manufacturing Practices - General Concepts
R A 770.course_description: R A 770 - Current Good Manufacturing Practices - General Concepts  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): R A 602 .Interpretation and application of current Good Manufacturing Practices (GMPs) to drug substance and drug product manufacture. Differentiation between full and appropriate GMPs required for clinical supplies production and commercial manufacturing. Variances between FDA and European Union requirements for the control and manufacture of pharmaceuticals. Aseptic regulatory inspections processing and preparation. Maximum Credits: 3

R A 772.course_description: R A 772 - Post-Approval Activities  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): R A 602 .FDA and FTC rules and regulations governing advertising, labeling, and promotion for biologics, generic, over-the-counter, and prescription drugs; and medical devices. Annual reporting requirements, changes to approved marketing applications, Good Manufacturing Practice inspections, post-marketing adverse reaction reporting, product recalls, and risk management. Maximum Credits: 3

R A 773.course_description: R A 773 - Medical Device Regulations  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): R A 602 .Introduction to regulatory affairs requirements for the medical device industry through stages of product development. FDA medical device regulations, terminology, timelines, and actual steps followed by regulatory affairs professionals. Commercial, operational, and strategic aspects of the regulatory approval process for in vitro diagnostics (IVD) and medical devices. Marketing, regulatory intelligence, risk management, and strategic considerations Maximum Credits: 3Maximum Credit Statement: combined credit six units of R A 773 and R A 774 applicable to a master’s degree

R A 774.course_name: Investigational and Marketing Applications for Drugs and Biologics
R A 774.course_description: R A 774 - Investigational and Marketing Applications for Drugs and Biologics  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): R A 602 .Content, planning, requirements, and strategy for developing and preparing Food and Drug Administration regulatory submissions to include biologics license applications (BLA), device premarket applications (PMA), device premarket notifications (510[k]), investigational device exemptions (IDE), investigational new drug applications (IND), new drug applications (NDA). Combination product submissions, future submission trends, and risk management. Maximum Credits: 3Maximum Credit Statement: combined credit six units of R A 773 and R A 774 applicable to a master’s degree

R A 775.course_name: Clinical Trials: Issues in Design, Conduct, and Evaluation
R A 775.course_description: R A 775 - Clinical Trials: Issues in Design, Conduct, and Evaluation  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): R A 602 .Issues in conduct, design, and evaluation of clinical trials by biotechnology, medical device, and pharmaceutical companies for marketing approval of products being studied in human subjects. Macro view of clinical trials within corporate, legal, and regulatory environments. Key steps required to develop and execute a successful clinical development program. Maximum Credits: 3

R A 778.course_name: Quality Control and Quality Assurance: Pharmaceuticals, Biologics, and Medical Devices
R A 778.course_description: R A 778 - Quality Control and Quality Assurance: Pharmaceuticals, Biologics, and Medical Devices  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): R A 602 .Quality and compliance functions in biotechnology and pharmaceutical companies to include out-of-specification results, developing product specifications, and writing compliant process deviations. Good Laboratory Practices (GLPs). Graded approach for Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients (APIs) manufacturing. Biologics, drugs, and medical device regulations. Quality control (QC) role vs. quality assurance (QA) role. Current trends in industry. Maximum Credits: 3

R A 779.course_description: R A 779 - International Regulatory Affairs  Units: 3 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): R A 602 .International regulations to include those in the European Union and other key areas of the world that pertain to the development and commercialization of biologics, medical devices, and pharmaceuticals. Maximum Credits: 3

R A 781.course_description: R A 781 - Ethics for Life Science Professionals  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): R A 602 .Ethical issues confronting regulatory affairs professionals. Development of capacities to apply, generalize, and translate principles and ideas to modern biomedical practice. Responsible conduct surrounding clinical trials, human subjects, informed consent, institutional animal care and use, institutional review boards, trial design, and whistle blowing. Maximum Credits: 3

R A 783.course_description: R A 783 - Effective Communication for Regulatory Science  Units: 3 Grading Method: LTR: Letter Graded. The class will be offered for letter grade with no option to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): R A 602  and R A 605;  concurrent registration in R A 798  (1 unit).Advanced interpersonal, oral, and written communication strategies for the regulatory affairs business environment. Audience analysis, barriers to entry, and cultural considerations. Communication types including e-mail, executive summaries, informational documentation, persuasive arguments, research-based paper, and visuals for presentations.

R A 797.course_description: R A 797 - Research  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of graduate adviser.Research in the area of regulatory sciences. Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.

R A 798.course_description: R A 798 - Special Study  Units: 1-3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): Consent of graduate adviser. Individual study.  Maximum Credits: 6Maximum Credit Statement: six units applicable to a master’s degree.

R A 799A.course_description: R A 799A - Thesis or Project  Units: 3 Grading Method: RPC: Available grades are RP, CR or NC Prerequisite(s): An officially appointed thesis committee and advancement to candidacy.Preparation of thesis or project for the master’s degree. Maximum Credits: 3

R A 799B.course_description: R A 799B - Thesis or Project Extension  Units: 0 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Prior registration in Thesis 799A with an assigned grade of RP.Registration required in any semester or term following assignment of RP in Course 799A in which the student expects to use the facilities and resources of the university; also students must be registered in the course when the completed thesis or project is granted final approval. Maximum Credits: 0

REL S 100.course_description: REL S 100 - Exploring the Bible  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Basic content and themes of the Hebrew Bible and New Testament using methods of contemporary biblical studies. Attention to ancient Near Eastern and Greco-Roman cultural settings as well as the impact of the Bible on contemporary culture. Maximum Credits: 3

REL S 101.course_description: REL S 101 - World Religions  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Major world and selected tribal traditions from primal times to present. Broad historical development and philosophical overview including founders, teachings, beliefs, practices, and interactions with culture, such as art, literature, politics. Maximum Credits: 3

REL S 102.course_description: REL S 102 - Exploring the Qur’an  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Basic content and themes of the Qur’an from an historical perspective using academic methods of study. Consideration of relationships to other Abrahamic scriptures. Exegetical approaches from sectarian and modern political viewpoints. Maximum Credits: 3

REL S 103.course_description: REL S 103 - American Religious Diversity  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Religious identities and traditions of diverse peoples living in the US. Major world religions in context of contemporary multicultural America. Religions of indigenous peoples and religious movements which have arisen in US. Maximum Credits: 3

REL S 258.course_description: REL S 258 - Death, Dying, and Afterlife  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Diverse ways religions deal with process of dying and rituals involved in transition of life to death. Grieving, end-of-life decisions, views on afterlife.Formerly numbered Religious Studies 358. Maximum Credits: 3

REL S 296.course_description: REL S 296 - Experimental Topics  Units: 1-4 Grading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Selected topics.  May be repeated with new content. Maximum Credits: 9Note: See Class Schedule for specific content. Limit of nine units of any combination of 296, 496, 596 courses applicable to a bachelor’s degree.

REL S 301.course_description: REL S 301 - Hebrew Bible (A)  Units: 3 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Three units of religious studies.Literature, history, major themes of Bible; methods and concerns of contemporary biblical studies. Situates folkloric, political, heroic, poetic, and religious meanings of texts among their original audiences. Maximum Credits: 3Note: Courses for Area (A) Texts, are identified in the course title as (A).

RWS 799B.course_description: RWS 799B - Thesis or Project Extension  Units: 0 Grading Method: CNC: Credit/No Credit Prerequisite(s): Prior registration in Thesis 799A with an assigned grade symbol of RP.Registration required in any semester or term following assignment of RP in Course 799A in which the student expects to use the facilities and resources of the university; also student must be registered in the course when the completed thesis is granted final approval. Maximum Credits: 0

RWS 799C.course_description: RWS 799C - Comprehensive Examination Extension  Units: 0 Grading Method: Cr/NC Prerequisite(s): Completion or concurrent enrollment in degree program courses.Registration required of students whose only requirement is completion of the comprehensive examination for the master’s degree. Registration in 799C limited to two semesters.

RUSSN 100A.course_description: RUSSN 100A - Beginning Russian 1  Units: 5 GEGrading Method: LCR: Letter Grade with Cr/NC available. The grading default for the class will be letter grade, but students can opt to take it for Cr/NC Pronunciation, oral practice, reading, essentials of grammar. Maximum Credits: 5Note: Taught in Russian. Native speakers of Russian will not receive credit for taking lower division courses in Russian except with advance approval from the department. No credit will be given for lower division courses taken after successfully completing any upper division Russian course taught in Russian. No credit will be given for RUSSN 100A, RUSSN 100B , RUSSN 200A , RUSSN 200B , RUSSN 301  taken out of sequence.
